reviewText: This movie is about how Lincoln fought to pass the 13th amendment. It gives insight to the politics of that time but it also shows the kind of personality Lincoln had. It humanizes him more than any other film because he is not treated as a superhero or a myth but it shows how he handled the stress of his presidency and the perseverance and politicking he had to do and deal with in order to get his amendment passed. This movie has also has moments of humor with Tommy Lee Jones' role. The dialogue is quick and it takes a little bit to catch on to the conflict this movie interprets but it is nevertheless entertaining. I find that time in history interesting so I enjoyed this movie. Perhaps it should have one the Oscar.

reviewText: One of the problems with the hype that is generated by film producers and critics alike, is that very often, films simply don't live up to expectations. In short, something described as gold, can often turn out to be merely gold-plated. Such is the case with Lincoln. There is no doubt that the cast do extremely well in their appointed roles, & this is particularly true with Tommy Lee Jones, who plays his role to perfection. The same applies to David Strathairn who is simply outstanding, so much so in fact, that it defies belief that he wasn't nominated for a Best Supporting Actor Oscar. That decision just has to be the oversight of the acting year. As for Daniel Day-Lewis, undoubtedly one of the finest actors in the world today, & normally a guarantee of a stellar performance, he failed to impress me as Abe Lincoln. He mumbled through much of his performance, & constantly held that hang-dog look, so symptomatic of someone with constant back & neck pain. OK, I know Lincoln was no spring chicken, but Day-Lewis made him look older that the man really was. For me it was a disappointing performance. As usual, Sally Field produced a very credible performance as Mrs Lincoln, although whether it's deserving of an Oscar, is another matter. There certainly have been better performances from many actresses this year. On the upside though, the cinematography & production design work exceptional & it's great to see that those responsible are now Oscar nominees. They are certainly deserving. Now to directing; Steven Spielberg has brought us some wonderful films during his career as to date, however, on the basis of some of his more recent works, it would not be wrong to suggest that his talents have been somewhat on the wane in recent years. The heady days of ET, Schindler's List, Indiana Jones, The Colour Purple, Close Encounters, Saving Private Ryan & the like, are well & truly past. War Horse, while a great story, performed by a great cast, again featuring great cinematography & production & set work, was lacking in direction, & this was highlighted in the film's conclusion which seemed limp & contrived. After watching Lincoln, I find it so curious that Spielberg would be Oscar nominated for Directing. Particularly when Ben Affleck was overlooked for his stellar work in Argo, which together with Django Unchained & Silver Linings Playbook, are the only real films deserving of the Best Picture Oscar. Overlong & sometimes tedious to watch (a fate shared by Zero Dark Thirty), Lincoln was a huge disappointment for me.

reviewText: I bought the DVD Blu-Ray based on the general media hype over the film. I really tried to like this film but felt it fell short of what it could have been. I admire Daniel Day-Lewis very much but feel this was not his finest moment. The reason, and why I think the film suffers, is the "Shakespeare syndrome"; that is the way actors in Shakespeare's plays over act because Shakespeare is the highest form of drama.  We have that here, Lewis is enthralled with Lincoln and I felt he was more concerned with the bigness of the person and comes short of really seeing who Lincoln was to himself, I felt he was uncomfortable and it makes you uncomfortable.I also felt the film lumbered along and Lincoln actually comes off as less a great leader but just another politician in Washington. I had high hopes I would like this film, but I'm afraid it just fell short of what could have been a great film.Unfortunately it is a very difficult task to portray a great person and I admire Lewis and his effort, so while this is certainly an informative film and worth seeing I would rent it not buy.

reviewText: Lincoln traces the last few months of the 16th president's life, focusing on his effort to pass the 13th Amendment to the Constitution ending slavery once and for all.Many reviewers have already noted that this is a movie about the US political process rather than the Civil War. But the few brief scenes dealing directly with the fighting - muddy hand to hand combat between black Federal troops and Confederates, Lincoln and his son's visit to an army hospital, and the aftermath a battle outside Richmond - give a powerful sense of the horror of the fighting in that war and the weight that it bore on Lincoln's conscience.The cast of the movie is outstanding and it is difficult to fault a single performance: Tommy Lee-Jones and James Spader deliver scene stealing turns. Jared Harris and David Strathairn less showy performances but no less well judged. And Sally Field brings a great level of sympathy to the role of the often unfairly maligned, though undoubtedly difficult, Mary Lincoln.The centrepiece in this movie is, of course, Daniel Day-Lewis' stunning performance as Lincoln. It is all the more powerful because it is so human: indeed part of Lincoln's greatness arose from his profound humanity and capacity to relate on that level to some of his most intractable rivals.Of course, in spite of Lincoln's efforts, slavery remains a huge problem in the contemporary world. The International Labour Organization estimates that a minimum of 21 million people are in forced labour in every region of the world today. I hope that movie 'Lincoln' inspires this generation of politicians to emulate just a modicum of Lincoln's political and moral courage when they are doing their jobs, and to take positive steps to end slavery once and for all in our lifetimes.
summary: A nice man who was also a great man

reviewText: The great thing about "Lincoln" is not so much that Steven Spielberg directed it (which he did a great job) or that Daniel Day-Lewis starred in it (he did a phenomenal job!), but that the writing (by Tony-winner Tony Kushner) is so spot on when it comes to the details. Sure, it's got all of the political mumbo-jumbo, but I loved that it also showed the very complex portrait of Lincoln, the man. From his troubled relationship to his wife Mary Todd (Sally Field) to his jokes with which nobody seemed to get because of it's dark and thinking humor. It might help the viewer to know going into this movie that the story here centers around Lincoln's struggle to get the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution passed (which would outlaw slavery), and is not a full biography picture (bio-pic). Tommy Lee Jones shines and marvels as Republican Congressional leader Thaddeus Stevens! The best thing about Spielberg's films is the humanity that shines through -- not just from the actors but also in the way he blocks and shoots scenes (i.e., there's a scene inCatch Me If You Can (Widescreen Two-Disc Special Edition)when Leonardo DiCaprio hugs his father, Christopher Walken, and there's a simple shot of Walken's hand on the back of DiCaprio -- it's a simple shot that conveys so much emotion about fathers and sons without any words being said). This alone is why Spielberg seems born to do what he's doing. This was not my favorite of the year, but it was definitely one of the top films!
Title: N/A

reviewText: How to make a film about the most important figure and period in US history? You just go ahead and do it, find a great book Doris Kearns Goodwin's historical account "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln" as a primary source), get a great script writer in Tony Kushner in Munich, get good actors ( Daniel Day-Lewis) and company and helm it under the auspices of Steven Spielberg.It begins with an amazing scene, where an African American soldier recites to Lincoln the words of his Gettysburg address. The nation is at war, and Lincoln is trying to pass the 13th Amendment. His secretary of State William Seward ( David Strathairn) is reluctant and considers it impossible. The film shows Lincoln's political acumen as he relies on lobbyist, cutting deal and pleading to get this done. He was a great politician even before he became a great president. It is intimate look at the happenings behind the 13th Amendment. However the entire film does not focus on this aspect alone, we get glimpses of Lincolns domestic life as a father who struggles to give permission to his son Joseph Gordon Levitt to enlist in the Union Army and his relationship with his adviser and wife, Sally Field.This is an amazing film with very engaging performances helmed by Daniel Day-Lewis and Tommy Lee Jones. Each and every character is well researched and acted. This is an extremelylong movie about 2 hours and 32 minutes, but extremely engaging- no loo breaks.A masterful portrait about one of the greatest figures in the history of America and the period when disagreement was natural but yet political parties were able to work together amidst considerable friction.

reviewText: A wise Oscar prognosticator once said that you can't truly predict the Oscars unless you actually see the films nominated.  I don't always agree with this, but I understand that seeing a film can help you understand why the vote is going to swing a certain way.  I think that `Lincoln' is proof of that.  Up until Oscar night I was holding my breath for a Oscar shock to happen and the envelope to read Hugh Jackman's name, and I held out hope that that could happen.  Had I seen `Lincoln' prior to the Oscar ceremony, I wouldn't have had such hope.  No, Daniel Day-Lewis's steamroll through the critics' awards and Oscar precursors was a bizarre thing for me.  I just didn't understand why he was going to win his third Oscar so soon for playing such a seemingly un-baity character.I get it now.I'm not saying that I agree with the win.  In fact, I consider what Joaquin Phoenix did to be a greater triumph and he was the truly deserved winner, but despite all my preconceived reservations about the film and the actor (Day-Lewis can be far too mannered for my taste, and I find his depiction as the `god of acting' to be complete hyperbole) I was kind of blown away.  I didn't love the movie (a tad too stagey and Spielberg's impulse to go for the preachy was too present in some scenes) but I really liked it, and what Daniel Day-Lewis does was outstanding.  He pulled himself back, he took a deep breath, and he carried this film from start to finish.  I completely understand why he won, and it isn't a win I can fault.  He was a total force of nature, but not in the overbearing way, and he was so well rounded (the bits of humor were fantastically played).Sadly, for me, when Day-Lewis is not on the screen the film doesn't exactly motivate my attention.  I found Kushner's writing to be free-flowing, which was nice, but this was basically a collection of conversations and not all of them were particularly inspired, more like fundamental.  While I liked the spiced personality that was created in Lincoln (he felt like such a real person, which I was afraid was going to get clouded under the political eyes of Spielberg), but I'll admit that some of the humor sprinkled in key scenes felt out of place and unnecessary (Spader's reaction to seeing Lincoln felt out of place).The rest of the cast was well formed but I was not as enamored with them as so many others were.  They felt secondary, very secondary.  Whenever Day-Lewis was on the screen, this was very much HIS movie, and when he wasn't there I was waiting for him to come back.The format for the film itself worked for the most part.  The opening battle sequence was superbly staged, the development of the relationship between Lincoln and his wife (and especially with regard to their eldest son) was surprisingly deep despite being far from the center of attention, and the verbal spattering all over the courtroom scenes, while at times a tad overdone and repetitive, add life to certain characters (I'm still not sure what all that hype was over Jones' performance here, but he was a hoot juggling some of his lines).At the end of the day, this is a good film.  It was both better and worse than I anticipated.  It was presented to me as a masterpiece, and so in that respect this really is highly flawed and doesn't live up, but in the back of my mind I was prepared to find this to be a total bore and was prepared for the worst with Spielberg's heavy handed direction, so in that respect I was pretty happy since I was never bored and Spielberg held back in many key scenes (although those bookends were atrociously overstated in the `Lincoln is a saint' department).
summary: An admirable attempt to anoint a saint...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I think one of the most thankless tasks that can be laid upon an actor is that of portraying a historical personality that is already a national icon. The audience comes to the theater with a firmly held opinion in place and the film is judged by how closely it conforms to that opinion. Daniel Day-Lewis is therefore faced with the problem of not offending the  "Lincoln-Is-Holier-Than-God" crowd while at the same time retaining some degree of artistic integrity. I think he walks that fine line as well as anyone could, but the nature of the task he has undertaken imposes its own limits on what he can do with the role. Kudos to him for his considerable effort.Sally Fields as the unstable Mary Todd Lincoln is, IMHO, shallow, entirely predictable, and as cardboard as a shipping box.Tommy Lee Jones as abolitionist senator Thaddeus Stevens delivers his usual strong performance and is clearly the most memorable supporting character in the cast.The opening, depicting the fighting at Petersburg, Virginia, is extraordinary. It's a shame that it is so short, and that he rest of the script does not live up to the potential that the opening scene seems to promise.

reviewText: OK film fans and movie watchers, stick with me through this review, cause it could be long, but I'll try to keep it from being boring! Shall we begin?Lincoln (2012) was directed by Steven Spielberg, a name synonymous with great film-making. His resume is long, illustrious, and legendary. Jaws. Close Encounters of the Third Kind. E.T. The Extra Terrestrial. Raiders of the Lost Ark. Schindler's List. Saving Private Ryan. Catch Me If You Can. Minority Report. The list goes on and on.In 2012, Spielberg finally got around to doing something he had on his mind for almost 15 years - a biopic of Abraham Lincoln. After a long and detailed pre-production, in which both Liam Neeson and Robert Downey Jr. were subsequently cast as Lincoln and dropped, Spielberg cast the electrifying 2-time Academy Award winning British-Irish actor Daniel Day-Lewis. It was the first of a number of good choices that would end up as the brilliant movie Lincoln.1. Daniel Day-Lewis became the first actor in cinema history to win the coveted Best Actor Oscar award 3 times with his stunning performance as the 16th President of the United States, Abraham Lincoln. And what a towering, electrifying, riveting performance it is. Day-Lewis, as Seth Macfarlane so snidely pointed out at the Oscars, stayed in character for the duration of the shoot - and a relatively hard shoot it was, considering the copious amounts of dialogue and the accent the role required.But man did he succeed! You've heard of method acting, but you haven't seen anything like this. Day-Lewis completely disappears into the character, until (you think to yourself) you could only be watching the real deal - the real Lincoln! It's extraordinary! It's brilliant! It's (insert synonym of amazing)!In my opinion, Lincoln is worth watching for one of the greatest performances in modern history - that of Daniel Day-Lewis as Abraham Lincoln.His is a Lincoln of depth, sensitivity, and fervour, as much a family man as a man of action, one who would just as easily tell a funny anecdote as declare war. It is by far the best portrayal of the man yet.Sally Field plays Mary Todd Lincoln, a woman who, in life, suffered from migraines, depression, and bipolar disorder, yet remained faithful and true to her husband until his assassination. Her portrayal can come off as whiny, but that is precisely the point; that was what Mary Todd was like in life. She and Day-Lewis share what is in my opinion, the best scene of the film - an emotional piece where the two scream at each other, angrily pouring out suppressed emotions and regrets over their son's decision to join the army.Tommy Lee Jones provides a standout, Oscar-nominated performance as Thaddeus Stevens, a grouchy, stolid supporter of the abolishment of slavery. Did I say something about the movie's best scene? I was wrong - the best scene is almost anything with Stevens in it. Take your pick between the "It opens" scene, or the courtroom rant against Lee Pace's slimy lawyer. Tommy Lee Jones was robbed of his Best Supporting Oscar by Christoph Waltz, ironically in a movie also about slavery.Day-Lewis, Field, and Jones are supported by a talented, all star cast of historical figures, some in little more then cameo roles, which I will go through briefly here: Joseph Gordon-Levitt (beyond criticism as Robert Todd Lincoln), David Strathairn, Hal Holbrook, Lee Pace (a favorite role of mine, gets some really good scenes), James Spader, Tim Blake Nelson, John Hawkes (who form a trio providing much of the comic relief), Jared Harris (as Ulysses S. Grant), David Oyelowo, Lucas Haas, and Dane DeHaan. Filling such a rich historical films with actors of this calibre enhances ones viewing experience, and realizes the world more fully.2. The cinematography of Lincoln is very underrated. When compared to the cinematography of Life of Pi or The Hobbit, Lincoln starts to look a little grey and grim, but surprisingly, that is where it succeeds. Most of the movie is filmed indoors, with little more then a few candles, gas lamps, or windows to illuminate the scenery. As the film progressed, I became more and more impressed at the ways the cinematographer (Janusz Kaminski) illuminated the movie. It's a small victory, and one that few people notice, but it's there to admire on return viewings, along with the John Williams score and the brilliant costumes - so authentic you don't even look at them!3. OK, now I'm not an American. And I don't know much about American history. I know who Lincoln is and what he did, but quite frankly couldn't care less about Thaddeus Stevens or William Seward or Edwin Stanton. The most fascinating part of Lincolns life was his assassination, and the conspiracy leading up to it.Sadly, but respectfully, even reverently, Spielberg shies away from showing the assassination, which comes out of a mix of respect and dignity towards the character.[Note: For a detailed, riveting look at the assassination of Lincoln, I recommend the National Geographic documentary, narrated by Tom Hanks,Killing Lincoln]And now we come to my main CON of this otherwise great film - the story. Now keep in mind that I'm not an American, and I really did love the film!The story just couldn't keep me interested. It didn't embroil me in the plot, and for half the time (with my rudimentary knowledge of American history) it seemed like a mix between a documentary and a soap opera. I had no idea what was going on, and strained to hear what fundamental plot points characters were going over in hushed voices.Lincoln jumps right into the heart of American politics without any sort of background or prequel, and to NON-Americans, this can be confusing and non-relevant. It's a movie about Americans, by Americans, for Americans.4. So, in conclusion, Lincoln is a film with stupendous feats of acting that defy comprehension, but the story appeals mostly to the USA (as the international box-office gross shows). I liked Lincoln, and gave it five stars for the acting (3.5 stars for the story), and plus, it's nice to see The Beard back in the game!Lincoln (2012) has my strong recommendation!
summary: Consider THIS review, film fans and moviegoers.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First of all, Daniel Day Lewis's Abraham Lincoln is probably the closest any of us will ever get to seeing the 16th President in the flesh. He is totally believable and his performance is subtle and endearing. When he walks the halls of the White House to leave for Ford's Theater, you truly do not want him to go --so kudos to Daniel Day Lewis and to Mr. Spielberg for providing the "stage" for this performance.Overall, the movie is good, not great. What was missing for me was not so much the context for passage of the 13th Amendment, to the contrary there was almost too much exposition explaining how hard the bill would be to pass and how difficult it would be for the President to move forward with that decision. What is missing is the context for why it was Abraham Lincoln who led this fight, why he was there at that time in history and how he obtained the skills (both personal and political) that helped him lead this fight. We are shown and told repeatedly what a great leader the President is but we are never shown why he is a great leader. His amazing life story, the choices he made, and his evolution from shopkeeper in New Salem to President of the United States all contributed to his leadership during the Civil War.Obviously telling that story would require a larger scope and longer movie (or multiple movies), and I get that the purpose of this movie was to show the passage of the 13th Amendment but the net effect is that, despite the great performance, Steven Spielberg's Lincoln doesn't quite get past the mythological Lincoln of history. He is still a bit of a mystery, and perhaps he should remain a mystery.Unfortunately, there are other actors in this movie that, while good, were ultimately distracting. Tommy Lee Jones, for example, is ALWAYS Tommy Lee Jones. One surprise was James Spader who was nearly unrecognizable. Sally Field also gives a subtle performance as the First Lady (a role that could have been played over-the-top and wasn't) but in the end, she did not blend into her role as well as Daniel Day Lewis did. I wish they would have just cast unknowns for these key parts, but thats a minor quibble. Overall, it's a good movie and definitely worth your time/money to watch but still I can't help but feel Daniel Day Lewis's performance was wasted here.
summary: Amazing performance, but Spielberg's Lincoln is still a mystery
Title: N/A

reviewText: Steven Spielberg and Tony Kushner made some interesting and difficult choices in Lincoln that I think have succeeded in making a brilliant film about one of the most written about historical figures ever, and certainly the most written about and familiar American historical figure.  And yet despite a billion words written about this man he still somehow remains an enigma with something withheld and unrevealable about the man.  No doubt that is his continuing fascination to us and I have no doubt many more millions of words will be written, again vainly trying to get at the essence of the man.  It is far easier to gaze in wonderous respect at the marble statue in his unmatched Memorial than to try to find the human being within the marble.Spielberg and Kushner have done their best to try to find the man with the inestimable assistance of Daniel Day Lewis' genius.  If they haven't succeeded completely, well they are in good company with a thousand other biographers.  I liked the closeness and intimacy of the film.  I liked the quiet.  I liked the touching, beautiful and subtle small details: Lincoln lying down on the floor next to his sleeping son, the ever present shawl on his shoulders, the often stooped gait, Lincoln's ready reach for the illustrative yet sometimes illusive joke or story told with great good humor, Lincoln holding hands with Stimson as the war news comes in, Lincoln's fondness for and engagement with his young aides and soldiers, his gentle touches and the incredible mastery of his emotions, his rectitude and subtle manipulation of the obstreperous, passionate, often obtuse political allies and foes.Throughout, Day Lewis is masterful in his delivery, conveying the homeliness of the man and yet the incredible strength and the sorrow that was with him every day of his Presidency that brought many of his detractors, especially Seward and others in the "team of rivals" to come to respect and love him.  He's got not just the look, the voice, the walk and movements of the man down, he has the gentleness, and the innate dignity of the man as well. This is Lincoln at the end of the war and his soul-aching weariness coupled with his steely resolution is evident in every frame.  He's superb.  The rest of the characters in the drama have been cast carefully with wonderful actors who actually often resemble the real men they're playing.  I could single out Tommy Lee Jones, David Straithairn, James Spader etc., but frankly everyone is marvelous in this cast down to every one of the maddening and quarrelsome Congressmen.And I thought Sally Fields was a fine Mary Lincoln.  Their scenes together played very well and conveyed in a few brief lines the struggles, regrets, tragic losses and difficulties that divide and also unite a long married couple who have weathered many travails.  I found it convincing.And finally, I am glad the focus of the film was the struggle to pass the 13th Amendment.  Unless you're a history buff, I imagine this will come as some surprise to many and I found their handling of the politics and personalities at play both fascinating and engaging.  I was absorbed and I imagine others will find revelatory the difficulty of passing this crucial legislation. And why not focus on this often overlooked struggle?  As the film carefully explains, the whole moral purpose of the war, abolition, could have been undone postwar without it.Some may find this narrowing of the events of the film to the last 6 months of Lincoln's life and the struggle to legislate a disappointment.  Not me.  As mentioned, we have had millions of words and many films and documentaries covering the overview of Lincoln's life. I applaud Spielberg and Kushner making an intimate film closeup and intense and, yes, full of dialogue and argument as the framework to illustrate an exceptional man in unimaginably difficult and tragic times, and finding within this closeup a glimpse of the man and his relations with wife, children, and friends and foes.  It is a brilliantly acted and directed illustration of democracy being tested to its limits, ornery and contentious even within the midst of Civil War, and human beings at their most venal and at their most noble.Many insights and much of this history is conveyed in dialogue (Lincoln's admission of his assumption of powers not necessarily granted him and ignoring of the law when he deemed it necessary is a prime example) and a potent line here and there speaks volumes about the war, the law, the Presidency, his marriage, his sorrow, his guile, and his steadfastness.  Nicely done and will promote repeated viewing.As expected from Spielberg, the production values are marvelous.  Well done in all departments.

reviewText: I found this movie to be not true to the facts.Lincoln was not popular in his time as portrayed in this movie. Like many who make hard choices during their tenure as leaders, Lincoln was, in his time, a very polarizing and controversial figure who only enjoyed popularity after his death (again, like many others of his stature). During his term, there were riots against the draft, the South hated him (half of our nation) and in the end, he was assassinated.But perhaps the worst part of this movie is that they trivialized Lincoln. He suffered great personal anguish over the hard and largely unpopular, but visionary choices he had to make - depth and anguish which is reflected so well in his now famous Gettysburg Address.I know a lot of people really liked the movie, but honestly, we only made it about 1/3 of the way through before turning it off.Lincoln deserves a better, more seriously handled tribute than this to his monumental life.
summary: Movie not true to facts - not worthy tribute to Lincoln's life

reviewText: This is a fascinating watch for anyone interested in US history, and especially in the history of the Civil War. The book and the script attempt to portray an extraordinarily complex point in time when a nation divided was eventually united, but not without the loss of a sea of blood. Also riveting was the handling of the political warfare between Republicans and Democrats in a time in our history when their platforms were almost the opposite of what they are today, with Democrats fighting abolition and Republicans fighting for it. Lincoln's external monologues, where he doubts the legality of some of his decisions and ventures into situation ethics, are intriguing, and vividly illustrate how there are no absolutes in the political arena.
summary: One of the best historical dramas of all times

reviewText: While there is something said about the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution, what wasn't said was how difficult it was to pass. This movie centers largely on that final four months as debate raged on. With the war winding down, Lincoln's dilemma was that he had used his War Powers to free a people from slavery, but that there was, at the moment, no way of keeping them free once the war ended. if the laws remained as they were, those freed could be declared as property and ordered back into bondage again, and while he held a majority, he was still shy a number of votes that could pass the Amendment he proposed. This was political arm wrangling at the time and this movie concentrated more on the political front than the war front. Here we see Lincoln portrayed as a patient, gentle man with friends and family, but also a shrewd mastermind capable of issuing a command as sternly as any general and certainly not afraid of accepting the consequences of any manipulations he might make. This movie also  did not go into much that is already well known, but into those aspects seldom seen. We already knew about his assassination, and so that was mentioned but briefly, yet the power of it was not lost, This was more about the man, than about the President, and a movie well worth watching.

reviewText: Why you shouldn't see it:Talking. If you aren't a fan of having dialog in your movies, then Lincoln probably isn't for you. So if you're one of the folks who voted for The Artist last year, you may not be too fond of this one. But, good thing for this movie, only two films lacking in dialog in the history of the Academy Awards have ever won best picture, and if all of the dialog was removed from this movie, it would probably just consist of opening and closing credits. And that would be a shame, because these are some old school credits without any entertainment value on their own.Politics. It's not that they're spending the duration of the movie talking about anything. They spend the whole time talking in, about, and around politics. Even in what you would think would be personal family moments, there are still at least strong political undertones to the conversation. So you can imagine the scenes that are set in the political arena, where political discourse would make a good deal more sense. There are lots of men with funny hair saying lots of things to posture themselves in the debate.History. In case you hadn't gathered, the plot of this film takes place in an historical setting, a little less than 150 years ago. And no, it's not an historical fiction, where they just take the setting and then add in a really crazy plot, a la Wild Wild West. It's a straight up history, 90% of which takes place within landmarks such as the White House and the Capitol Building (the one in Washington, D.C.). So if histories make you uncomfortable and/or bore you to tears, this one might not hold your interest.Why you should see it:Daniel Day-Lewis. This part is probably obvious. Or maybe it isn't obvious. If I'm going to be honest with you, I'll tell you that I watched this entire movie trying to convince myself that I was, in fact, watching Daniel Day-Lewis and not Abraham Lincoln. Try as I might, I was laughably unsuccessful. I could look the man right in the beard and not tell him from the man who lived a century and a half ago. I'm not sure what to say about Day-Lewis, other than the fact that I'm glad his method acting didn't lead him to demand that they film Lincoln's assassination using a real gun. With real bullets. I want to see more movies with this man being someone completely and totally not himself.Tommy Lee Jones. He plays a supporting character (congressman Thaddeus Stevens), obviously, so his role isn't quite as prominent as Day-Lewis', but that doesn't mean he isn't essential to the film. And it's good for you that he is, because every time he shows up on camera, he steals the scene. His ornery attitude and the fact that he's a representative from Pennsylvania may make you think he's from Philadelphia, but he shockingly is not. His witty, sarcastic characterization frequently brings a much-needed lightness to the film.Steven Spielberg. I'm not sure there was a person I was more disappointed in last year than Steven Spielberg. The fact that he would ever even think about releasing a movie as terrible as War Horse just makes me sad in my heart. The good news is that he has acquitted himself nicely here. He takes a moment of American history, finds the story behind it, and creates a gripping, expertly told tale. Much like Affleck with Argo, Spielberg is somehow able to make the audience feel suspense over the outcome of a plot that it already knows. It's not like Congress skipped the 13th Amendment. He's also done a fantastic job of casting, from the notable (and award-recognized) efforts of Day-Lewis, Jones, and Sally Field to any of the rest of the ensemble cast. Every time you turn around, there is another face that you recognize giving their hand in telling this important tale (keep an eye out for James Spader, who is excellent).History. America hasn't always gotten everything right. Actually, they've gotten a lot of things wrong, but sometimes it's good to be reminded of the things it has gotten right. The 13th Amendment is one of those things, and I'm not sure many people realize just how close this country was to not passing it for many more years. It gives you a whole new appreciation for the will of a few extraordinary men and their clarity of vision to pass such an historically significant piece of legislation in the face of tremendous bigotry.In Short:Spielberg takes a part of history and makes it more. What could have been a drab exercise in the telling of the passage of a bit of legislation is instead a front row seat at one of the most important moments in US history. The whole film is shown in an almost dreamlike quality and pulls the audience into a powerful script featuring an iconic performance and generally excellent ensemble cast. I really want Abraham Lincoln to tell me another story, but sadly he's dead going on 150 years now, so instead I'll give this a 9 out of 10 and recommend it to anyone who can appreciate moments of historical significance.Exceptions to the recommendation:- anyone who would prefer to remain doomed to repeat history due to their lack of knowledge thereof;- states' rights advocates who would be subject to high blood pressure from any increase in the power of the federal government;- anyone who may just get confused that it's the republicans fighting on behalf of the minorities;- people who were expecting to see Daniel Day-Lewis in a movie instead of Abraham Lincoln;- people who are tired of the white-man-as-savior version of history;- anyone who was expecting vampires or hunting thereof.

reviewText: When Americans think of Abe Lincoln, we picture a marble icon, an axe swinging tree chopper, an animated lanky president with an even taller hat.  After you see Daniel Day Lewis and how he sees the Lincoln character, you will forever change those previous opinions you had that I mentioned.  He breaths human life into a very complicated man. He shows how the 4 year Civil War and ending slavery took it's toll on him and his family.  Not just words in a history book, but you live the anguish and torment Abraham Lincoln sacrificed for our country.  Just like us, he's taken down by stress, self doubt, depression, family tragedies....and the joys of victory, a sense of humor keeps his world pushing forward.  I didn't just see a movie but a portrait of our greatest president.  It almost inspires you to go out and accomplish a great feat.

reviewText: There is a critical and individual rush to praise this film, as if  the topic and enormous star power (of Spielberg, Kushner and well-known actors) have guaranteed that it is a masterpiece.  Far from it, in my humble opinion.  First, the direction provides no pacing, is self-indulgent and engages in far too many  loooong shots of scenes or faces when nothing is happening.  I had to keep reminding myself that this was done by Steven Spielberg but it did not match any of his earlier and justifiably praised work.  Second, the writing is just plain poor.  Tony Kushner made some decisions on emphasis, comments and other aspects that do nothing but add ponderousness and length to the film.  Third, while I've admired Daniel Day-Lewis in other work, here he doesn't act, doesn't emote and mumbles most of his lines.  An acting Oscar?  No way.  And I wouldn't vote for the person who glued on his whiskers or created his wig either - both patently unreal-looking.  There are far too many other characters; with all the costumes, various wig styles and incoherent script it is much too difficult to figure out who is who and doing what.  Tommy Lee Jones is identifiable but having the camera focus on the crags in his face does not equal acting.It all reminds me of the emperor's new clothes - people look at the naked emperor and see what they expect to see:  that he is clothed and bedecked.  In fact, he is naked.  The film, while not naked, is overlong, poorly directed and written and a bore.Kudos to Mr. Masloski, above, for writing such an excellent and accurate analysis of the film, showing the many technical mistakes that help make this so much less than it could have been.Disappointing.

reviewText: NOTE: This review DOES NOT contain SPOILERS!Do you remember when you were a young student reading your history textbook and--while you had been up until that moment viewing artists' renditions of famous events and people--you were now in the latter half of the 19th century, and you'd reached the portion of your history text when there were actual photos of these events?In fact, staring at you from the page, is the face of Abraham Lincoln himself.If you do remember such a moment, you might be equally startled by the intimacy and immediacy of "Lincoln," a stunning work of art that marries two of cinema's most powerful forces: Steven Spielberg and Daniel Day Lewis.  How is it that these two amazing legends have not worked together before?The power of this film is captured in the single word of the title; this is no "The Man, The Myth, The Legend" mythology...no sweeping panorama told in glorious panoramic cutaways.  No; it is the story of one man, and how this one man took on one cause, one battle, and fought the good fight away from the dirt and gunpowder of the battlefield, trading it in for the backrooms and chambers of an even more wicked Washington D.C.It is the story behind the passage of the Thirteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, banning slavery as an institution. It may puzzle modern-day viewers that such an amendment ever had to be written, but HOW it was passed is an amazing story well worth telling. (And it's practically impossible to avoid making parallels with today's President, his House of Representatives, and their conflicts.)"Lincoln" is a stirring story, full of intrigue and intelligence, and you will be stirred by the emotional sway conveyed by the camera and the script.  Tony Kushner fashioned the screenplay from Doris Kearn Goodwin's extremely well-research and well-toldTeam of Rivals.  As one might expect, it is the story of how Lincoln was compelled to "work" Washington, how he was able to coerce the varied forces of a warring Union political jungle and make it bend to his will.But it is more than that, and it was this that I found most forceful: the WHY.  And while you think you know it--that it is against human dignity to hold another man's freedom under your thumb--you are of course correct, but also misjudging the ideal for the real, practicality of the amendment.  And when the President lays out his rationale to his cabinet--when he spells out the political REASONS behind the passage of this amendment--it is a stirring, shrewd, and spellbinding moment that is as insightful, intelligent, and (if it were to have failed) as frightening as they come.There were several moments within this movie that moved me like that: one was as tiny as a moment can be, though it occurred at a time that meant as much to American history as any one moment can, and it was simply this: Abraham Lincoln needed a message sent by telegraph, and he found two men in the communications room who were capable of such a thing.  After it was sent, the President of the United States sat with them and conversed, holding them in awe, all while he recounted a lesson he was once taught in math that followed him to this day.And that is the power of this "Lincoln."  It takes a great actor, and a great director, to put their considerable skills hard at work at stepping back and letting the man shine.I WAS those telegraph men, mesmerized by the man--Daniel Day Lewis makes him that real.  It is easy to lose oneself in the moment and believe you are sitting with the man.  It is his hard, worn face, his stooped shoulders, his often grim demeanor, his high, reedy voice, his gentle, intelligent eyes...it is all there in Lewis' portrayal.  And his mind...it is a mark of Lewis' portrait of the man that Lincoln's vaunted intelligence always shows through, and the same is true of his compassion.  It is an amazing thing Lewis and Spielberg have accomplished--a film that is stirring when it needs to be, harried and frazzled when it needs to be, and gentle and mindful of the human soul, ALWAYS.As is usual with his films, Spielberg is best when he sets the scene, brings the actor forward, does the grunt work, then steps back and lets the scene play out, mindful of details as minor as a tapping finger or a twinkle in an eye.  From what I have seen of the director's career (and that's just about every movie he's done) it appears that he stresses over every detail, then lets his people do their work, making sure his camera is there to capture every nuance of the moment.  His movies seem so alive, so frames so full of sight and sound that the film seems close to exploding with energy.  It's no different here in "Lincoln" than it was inJaws,Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Ark (Special Edition), or the dozens of films in between.As is also usual, the film is populated by great actors doing great work.  Sally Field's Mary Todd is a wonder, her ballyhooed "madness" evident, but in Field's hands it's more the anguish of a mother who has lost one son and fears the loss of another--and is powerless to protect either him or the husband she loves.  Joseph Gordon-Levitt, as Lincoln's son Robert Todd, was fine in the small but pivotal role as the son who wished not to be protected any longer from the war.But it is Tommy Lee Jones who really steals the frame each time he is present.  He is simply terrific as the bombastic and bewigged Thaddeus Stevens, an ardent abolitionist.  Other noted roles are filled by Hal Holbrook, James Spader, Jackie Earle Haley, S. Epatha Merkerson, Tim Blake Nelson, Bruce McGill, and there are almost countless others.What this film really left me with was the sense that I was there, and so was Lincoln, the man.  When the film ended--and despite its length it ended far too soon--I was struck by how much I would miss him.  And this...the accomplishment of creating a man out of the ether, is really the most remarkable achievement.  I will miss this man Lincoln, but I will always treasure Spielberg and Lewis for giving me this living, breathing man of history.
summary: A Living, Breathing Lincoln Like No Other

reviewText: Who can't help but love Steven Spielberg? Spielberg, one of the most creative minds in Hollywood, has made films of high historical importance. After making films about World War II and the Holocaust, Spielberg has gone on to another high area of historical importance: Abraham Lincoln and Lincoln's last three months (with a little bit of his four years altogether) as President.The result is Lincoln, starring Daniel Day-Lewis as our sixteenth and, as most people agree, most beloved President.As director, Steven Spielberg takes Day-Lewis and a powerful ensemble cast (most notably Sally Field, Joseph-Gordon Levitt, Hal Holbrook, Tommy Lee Jones, and James Spader)on a ride back through time. Viewers are shown by Spielberg what was going on in the Civil War in early 1865 and, in the meanwhile, the House of Representatives as its members were in the process of deciding either for or against slavery. The stresses of President Lincoln around this time are shown, not only in his job, but also in his personal life, most notably with his wife Mary Todd (portrayed by Sally Field) and son Robert (portrayed by Joseph-Gordon Levitt). Viewers are given a ride inside of President Lincoln's mind, a mind of faith, humor, and sometimes darkness as it was and as it evolved through the most trying times of President Lincoln's life. As a Lincoln scholar, I can tell you that the way Spielberg documents all of these personal traits about President Lincoln--and the way that the personal traits appear themselves--are impeccably portrayed in both quality and quantity. Daniel Day-Lewis, even if his heritage is the polar opposite of President Lincoln's, brings the beautiful talent that we all know and love him for right into his performance as President Lincoln. Every mannerism of President Lincoln, every trait of President Lincoln, is present in Day-Lewis' performance of him.My only real beef to pick with Lincoln is the fact that it does not document the entire life of President Lincoln, which keeps it from (in my opinion) being the ultimate Lincoln biography (compared to the biographies that record all of President Lincoln's life). However, given how many limitations on time filmmakers have, I can't hold it against Spielberg. In "making do," so to speak, Spielberg succeeded in giving viewers a whole glimpse of Lincoln in spite of covering a small (but largely important) part of his life.Recommended for ALL, especially those who are and want to be Lincoln scholars.
summary: Steven Spielberg's brilliant historical imagination vividly captures the Presidency of Abraham Lincoln

reviewText: Steven Speilberg took years to develop the film about Abraham Lincoln.He ended up with a script of mini-series' length then he decided concentratingon the period of the president's efforts in passing the 13th amendment instead.Likewise it took a couple of years of research on the subject by Daniel Day Lewisbefore accepting the role.The resulting film is short of expectations.The film started with a short combat sequence at night in the rain between the Union and Conferatesoldiers.  It was short and inconsequential to start a film of this magnitude.It followed by the out-spoken black Union soldier spoke eloquently to Lincoln about blacksoliders' plight which seemed unrealistic for that period of time and history.Both sequences could serve better if they occur later in the film.The casting also has some problems.Daniel Day Lewis' portrait of Lincoln could be accurate(based on his habitual exhaustive research) butit fell short of general public's expectations of Lincoln based on the stern and serious imagesthe former president left behind.DDL's Lincoln seems more frail and contemplative than a president of Lincoln's statue.This Lincoln also told too many stories at some pivital moments of political discussions(anothersign of weakness, using stories to convey his messages?).There were other casting misfortunes.Tommy Lee Jones, albeit did a good job, his face is too recognizable and modern plus a funny-lookingwig.  James Spader's character was almost like a drunkard.  Was it intentional to achieve some lightmoments?  The large cast of characters with different names was also hard to follow.Only Sally Field gave a strong and heartbreaking performance as a long suffering wife and worriedmother(Best Supporting Actress?).Lincoln's efforts and success in passing the 13th amendment was a seminal historical event for theAmericans.Relying on that event alone might not be enough for a compelling 2 hr film(except the amendment passingsequence).Abraham Lincoln deserves a better film(Watch John Ford's "Young Mr. Lincoln" with Henry Fonda).
summary: It Could Have Been A Better Film About Lincoln

reviewText: I wasn't around when Lincoln was alive -- taking a peek at the Guinness World Record for the oldest human, it looks like no one else living today was -- but my guess while watching this film:  people back then weren't nearly as talkative as the players in this film.  After all, as I believe Lincoln even says during the first act:  "I'm not really into politics myself."  And politicians like to talk, while apolotical people tend to be less loquacious.  People back then were doers, not talkers.I have to admit, I'm not usually a fan of period pieces, as revisionists seemingly either try to not stomp on the graves of those in an earlier period, or they trounce on them and spit on them as well.  There are some exceptions, and one director that I think does a terrific job with period pieces:  Mel Gibson.  Yeah, I know that he's been the kicking boy du jour for surely more than a day.  But Mr. Gibson doesn't like to sugarcoat anything in any way in an unrealistic manner, and he seems to realize the fallibility of human nature, while at the same time showing some bit of dignity where he can and may.  (For those who are snarky, I'm sure that their real-mature response might be something like:  "Takes one to know one.")Another trait of many of Mr. Gibson's films:  he wasn't afraid to use the native tongue of the people at the time, and add subtitles for the viewer.  Surely a risky move for particularly a US audience, but I always thought that there was a huge payoff because of this; it adds to the authenticity.  But here, while the players speak in English -- as you'd expect, since after all it is set in the United States -- most of the people didn't exactly have the accents that I would expect.  This still would have been, say, within 100 years of the Birth of America, and the living at that time weren't too far removed from the initial immigrants.  (I like the television show "Sleepy Hollow," and the male lead in that film is far more convincing to me than anyone in this film.  Once again, I wasn't around back then, but my gut tells me "Sleepy Hollow" might be more accurate.)One other "touchy" subject, but not one you'd expect with this film:  many people, particularly those in the industry, are very afraid to ever criticize anything in which Steven Spielberg is involved.  "Hogwash!" I say, while adding, "A work of art stands strictly on its own."  Mr. Spielberg has had many successes, and he's had some big failures as well; I always believe that those that don't have big failures don't take enough risks, and I commend him for taking the risks that he does.  "Jurassic Park" excellent, "Jurassic Park 2" a dismal failure.  "Indiana Jones" awesome, "Indiana Jones 2" awful.While I'm not prepared to bucket "Lincoln" in with the failures listed above, I would say that it's surely not a huge success.  And the worst thing of all to me:  it's just not very interesting.  While I don't believe that Lincoln is rolling in his grave over this film, I think that if he were to see it, he might just shrug and go back to sleep.
summary: Lincoln Might Shrug in His Grave

reviewText: There was a lot of anticipation about the release of Steven Spielberg's "Lincoln." The book from which it was based, "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln," was re-released, as well as documentaries and magazine articles. Lincoln was the flavor of the month in the media, and all the high expectations were well rewarded. "Lincoln" delivers and Spielberg has created another one for history. It is an impressive film that makes justice to the legend of what has been referred to as the best the president the United States of America has ever had.About the movie itself, let me just start by saying that what you watch is not the story of Lincoln's life, from the cabin days, his career as a lawyer, his political beginnings, and the like. Instead, what you witness is Lincoln during his final four months in office and his efforts to eradicate slavery and end the bloody Civil War. Hence, the story takes place mostly in the confines of Washington and its politicians. We find our 16th President, Abraham Lincoln (Daniel Day Lewis), in a battle against time to pass the constitutional amendment to end slavery and, at the same time, preserve the peace between the north and the south after the war. It is 1965, and it is important to pass this amendment before the war ends, as to prevent the south to boycott it before it becomes law. To accomplish this, he needs the help of William Seward (David Strathairn), his Secretary of State, and Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones), a smart and manipulative Republican who is heavily respected in congress. We witness Lincoln in the war room, making decisions and seeking advice on how to win the war and stop the killing, and also trying to buy key congressmen whose votes are needed to pass the amendment - wow, talk about lobbying! In addition, we watch how Lincoln deals with Mary Todd (Sally Field), his troubled, yet strong wife, as well as his sons Robert and Tad. It is nice to watch Lincoln spend some quality time with them, in such tense and dramatic days. There is also some time given to the assassination, but it is done in a different, surprising way. The ending was also well- handed, satisfying, and surprising as well."Lincoln" is a true gem, and I have to confess that I will probably have to watch it again, as the political plot and constitutional talk were hard to follow at times, and these are the important elements to understand the so-called genius of Lincoln. It is necessary to note that Spielberg was smart enough to place some African-American actors in some small, but key roles in the film. It is also important to mention that Daniel Day-Lewis deservedly won the Academy Award for his portrayal of Lincoln. The Blu-ray + DVD + Digital copy also includes several documentaries about the making of the film and about Day-Lewis. (USA, 2012, color, 150 min plus additional materials)Reviewed on April 1, 2013 by Eric Gonzalez for Dreamworks - Twentieth Century Fox Blu-ray

reviewText: Tony Kushner, the pulitzer prize winning writer of ANGELS IN AMERICA has done it again.  He wrote an absolutely brilliant screenplay about Lincoln.  Ironically, he and director Steven Speilberg had a heck of a time getting Daniel Day-Lewis to play Lincoln, They were even down to saying, "Have you ever looked in a mirror?" Finally, he agreed and we are certainly the richer for it.  Day-Lewis for all intents and purposes IS Lincoln.  Everything I've ever read about Lincoln, he rolls into this performance from the homespun folksiness, to the country lawyer, to the storyteller, to the grieving father to the husband of a very difficult wife.  Mary Todd Lincoln is likewise impeccably recreated by Sally Field.So many things were unearthed in this film that I never fully appreciated before. Just some of these things follow.How in darkness people lived. Unless it is broad daylight and huge windows are open, everyone indoors lives in relative darkness compared to our electrically lit environs. This set the tone for me more than any other period recreation.  I just can't imagine living in that much darkness.No one is particularly attractive of either sex, despite a huge cast. It took me until the film was over to figure out why they were physically well below average.  It is that our eye has changed.  We have gotten used to people having ample access to cleaning and grooming supplies and aides of every sort. We also have medical attention which helps achieve a healthier glow.  It is not that anyone looks dirty precisely in this.  They just look a great deal scruffier and rougher all over and the man have full facial hair and either fairly ugly hair or wigs. I give Speilberg immense credit for pulling this look off as it really helps the auuthenticity.There were many aspects to the thirteenth amendment passage which I did not fully appreciate before. For example, the man on the street thought that passage of the amendment would bring about the end of the war. The war and the amendment were in fact two separate issues. Lincoln explains the legal problem if we win the war without the amendment though.  He, as commander in chief, will have to lay claim to all of the slaves in the South as the property of the USA as the spoils of war. This will happen because without the amendment, they will be legally considered chattels.The abolitionists were against the amendment because it did not go far enough. They wanted more than full legal equality for the blacks. They wanted to address areas other than the law. Tommy Lee Jones plays their lead person in the House and begins to falter over opposing the amendment as he realizes how many rights he would be giving up for blacks if it fails to pass. The abolitionists in any event were wrong as subsequent civil rights cases in the ensuing 150 years tackled one aspect of life after another where inequality was at play. The thirteenth amendment was critical in these cases.IN SUM THOUGH, let me repeat, Daniel Day-Lewis is absolutely phenomenal. It is almost impossible to imagine that anyone could beat him for the Oscar.  It will be his third.
summary: expected it to be a bit tedious but was FASCINATED; SUPERB!

reviewText: I love studying history, so I was really looking forward to this.  I'd seen an interview with the writer of the book, so I was prepared for her disposition of trying to make Lincoln out to be a Joker; but I'd hoped that she'd bring MORE to the table than that!  She might as well have simply listed the names of the people in Congress who voted "yeah" vs. "nay" on the 13th amendment and titled the movie "The 13th Amendment."  She missed the many great stories of the times then--from the horror of the war itself to the fact that it was Lincoln's mission to create a Greenback Currency to take away the PRIVATE control over PUBLIC money that got him assassinated by a European Banker's hit man!  Also, if she was aiming to focus on Lincoln's PERSONALITY, she REALLY should've included the fact that he was a regular cannabis user, as that no doubt was key to his profound sense of diplomacy!
summary: I love history and hated this movie

reviewText: I was highly impressed. I thought Daniel Day Lewis was superb. He seemed more Lincoln than even Lincoln was. He made the character so three dimensional. It was enthralling to see him play Lincoln so memorably. He really was ably supported because the other roles were played with so much verve and excitement. Everyone seemed to be really into playing their characters well. Tommy Lee Jones was simply great as Thaddeus Stevens, Sally Fields was a excellent Mary Todd, the three lobbyists were played by such wonderful character actors that they sprang completely to life.I wish Bruce McGill could have been used more somehow. I thought he was extremely convincing in his few scenes as Stanton. I was very moved by the scene of Stanton and Lincoln waiting for news from Fort Fisher and his reaction to Lincoln telling another story I thought was hilarious.Jackie Earle Haley was very good in his role as Alexander Stephens. I even thought he eerily resembled him. I also liked David Strathairn as Seward.Heck, this movie even had a great Tad portrayal in it! The scene of Lincoln and Tad at the very beginning is very, very moving. The final blowup between Robert Lincoln and Abraham is very startling in its intensity and well played by both actors. I thought relationship with his sons was one of highlights of the film.The scenes in the House of Representatives were superb showing the chaos of our Democratic system and that there never was really `good old days' when no one bitterly disagreed. That there was primal racism on the floor of the House of Representatives. Also, just try to tell these representatives to give women the right to vote! The lesson that is shown is the give and take that is needed to get something done with such a discordant legislative body.All of this greatness made me long for a `Band of Brothers' length miniseries on Lincoln with these actors.If a person is fascinated by America or American history the movie is truly a can't miss.

reviewText: I've had all the months since I saw it in the theater to think about whether this movie made a long-term impact on me.  I think pretty highly of Steven Spielberg, especially in comparison to other directors' lack of skill and lack of concern about the moral effects of their movies.  From what I know about Lincoln, it is quite an accurate portrayal of him, and I think Daniel Day-Lewis indeed deserved that Best Actor Oscar.  But despite its amazing attention to historical detail in the sets, and that an actor was able to portray Lincoln's multifaceted personality really well, its MESSAGE felt lacking to me in two serious ways.  I wish, first, that the screenplay by Tony Kushner had not included all the profanity.  According to Civil War historian James McPherson, "Lincoln rarely if ever used profanity, and some of the dialogue calls for him to do that. I thought that was a bit jarring."  I did, too.  I think the script would've been pretty good if the profuse cussing had been left out.  But it also didn't go far enough in expressing Lincoln's deeply Biblical appreciation of the value of human life.  Lincoln's faith got a little treatment in the movie, but not as much as it should have, because that was what motivated his sense of justice.Summary:  Excellent acting, very engaging direction by Steven Spielberg, but the script was weak for such a momentous subject, due to its inadequate treatment of Lincoln's faith and in that it expressed an inaccurate impiety on Lincoln's part.  In a movie that's more like a play, which this movie is, pretty much everything depends on the script.  I would still recommend seeing it.
summary: After almost a year of considering this movie's effect . . .

reviewText: The movie was more about the passing of the 13th amendment than anything else.I must say that when I watch a movie like this that is based on history, I view the movie with a very critical eye. I cannot imagine that the dialogue was as said, nor can I believe that the machinations involving the passing of this amendment was as portrayed (although I am sure that such political maneuvering occurred). I find such dramatizations as Rep. Stevens being in love with his black housemaid as an effort to play on our current thinking, and, for me, it just is a trick that diminishes the entire plot.Daniel Day-Lewis was superb as Lincoln; Sally Field only so-so as Mrs. Lincoln, although she was exceptionally good when she was yelling at him in their bedroom.  The other actors were plausible.Again, this review is based on my criticisms of the movie as an accurate depiction of the events that unfolded during the last few months of the Civil War. Although I know that this was a drama based on a book, and no one could hardly know what ever transpired during these months, and the conversations among the participants, I did not find that the film presented a believable course of action.
summary: A movie about the last four months of his life?

reviewText: This was a very well done film, portraying an important 'slice' of history during the most important part of Lincoln's Presidency when slavery was abolished and the union was preserved.  Events leading up to The Thirteenth Amendment passing, and the Civil War ending were portrayed accurately and movingly. The acting was absolutely brilliant, and all heart. You felt as if you were there! Those complaining about the rather often drab and dark lighting in certain scenes are clueless. There was no electricity back then, and building interiors were heavy on window treatments as well. Spielberg accurately reflected the visual surroundings, which included proper interior light levels for the time. Don't miss this excellent film about one of our greatest Presidents!
summary: Great, moving film about one of our greatest moral and ethical Presidents!

reviewText: This movie absolutely took my breath away. It was visually stunning, historically accurate to the extent that my husband repeatedly nudged me regarding a lot of very minute details, and was superbly acted. Did I forget to mention that the screen play which was based upon Doris Kearns Goodwin's Team Of Rivals took a huge amount of information and meaningfully compressed themes to tell an important story about the presidency of Abraham Lincoln and the abolition of slavery. This movie made me proud to be a born and raised Illinoisian and explains Lincoln reputation as a history significant president and a self-educated and brilliant man.Without summarizing this expansive movie in detail, I'm going to tell you why I just saw this movie at the theater for the second time and why I am buying a DVD of this film. There is too much in this movie to absorb in just one viewing. I don't mean this as a negative, but there were so many characters, so many opinions and sentiments expressed that I wondered if I got it all the first time around. Turns out I really missed nothing except the opportunity to fully appreciate the wonderful performances that were peppered with slight nuances that transformed the actors from acting to really becoming the characters. In a film populated with a huge cast of superb performers, this movie transported me to a different reality of nearly 150 years ago. I was sitting on the edge of my seat during this movie.Hearing Daniel Day Lewis speak made the hairs on the back of my neck stand up. His demeanor, his gait, his gesturing, and his speech patterns and intonations all made me feel that I was seeing the real Lincoln. I don't think anyone would dispute Lewis' reputation as a versatile performer, but this role really was really difficult as far as I am concerned. Lewis' clearly must have done a huge amount of research on Lincoln to play a historical figure that is legendary but who we never heard.Sally Field had the southern gentility and nervous demeanor I would have expected and looked quite a bit like Mary Todd Lincoln without resorting to obvious trickery. Field's portrayal managed to give depth  to a historical figure that has often been written off as a crazy lady. Brilliant casting despite the criticisms that Sally Field was too old to portray Mary.Tommy Lee Jones was amazing down to the limp dragging leg and ill-fitting wig as Thaddeus Stevens. While beefier looking than the real Stevens, he portrayed Stevens as quick witted, clever and king of one-liners he was reputed to be. There was a nice offset between Lincoln and Stevens who were fundamentally very different people in terms of demeanor as well as motives. In fact, Jones' Stevens did a formidable job of crankily eating up all of his opponents and spitting them out. Leaves me in a state of wonder as to just how good an actor Jones is and how often it seems he is undervalued as an actor.From the acting, to the sets, costuming, make-up, and visuals this movie is incredible.I sat on the edge of my seat both times I saw this movie. I didn't make any rushes to the concession stand or rest room despite its rather long running time.I know that recommending a DVD of this movie that I have yet to see is jumping the gun and probably not the best reason to recommend it. However, a  DVD with pause capability, a comfortable couch, food and toilet facilities, and a big flat screen sound good for my third time around.
summary: Transfixing Movie That Raises The Bar For Intelligent Film Making

reviewText: 3.5 stars. It is a little too talky for sure. There could have been more intrigue and war info passed about. But this Spielberg film is okay for what it is. If you don't want to hear people wandering around in costumes talking then you would do better to avoid this one.Period accuracy is done well. Lewis is astounding as Lincoln and gets the voice done very well. Lincoln never had a booming and deep voice! The direction is mostly solid but the weakness, it's obvious with so much attention put on it, is the script. The thing drags a bit and at times we see just a little too much sentimentality in this one. The opening scene was just a little too much for me and so are a couple more of them a little to nostalgic. All in all it is good film with excellent art direction and it pays homage to some important ideas and parts of history.
summary: A film with a decent but maudlin script.

reviewText: The subject of many films over the decades, Abraham Lincoln has been portrayed to great effect by such top actors as Raymond Massey, Henry Fonda, and on TV by Hal Holbrook.  Steven Spielberg has assembled a great cast headed by Daniel Day-Lewis in Lincoln, a chronicle of the last weeks of his presidency and his final important accomplishment before he was assassinated.  As a slice of history, it is a fascinating insight into the political challenges that went into the 13th Amendment. As a portrayal of a historic figure, it could not be any better.In January, 1865, President Abraham Lincoln (Lewis) has been just re-elected and must contend with major issues particularly the ongoing toll of the Civil War.  Amid the inequality of the `colored' soldiers and a growing personal conviction that was marked by his landmark Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, Lincoln is passionate about getting the 13th Amendment (which would unequivocally free all slaves) passed in Congress.  At odds with his headstrong wife, Mary Todd (Sally Field), and surrounded by a doubting cabinet and strange bedfellows, Lincoln's challenge is to secure enough votes in Congress amid powerful opposition.  With the potential of a Confederate signal for an end to the war, Lincoln must weigh the political fallout of ending a costly conflict and achieving lasting freedom for all Americans.Lincoln is not intended as an all encompassing biography but rather a microscope into the President's last great act of his administration, and it illustrates his sheer will and unshakable faith. It demonstrates his disarming sense of humor and philosophy, and he is depicted as an imperfect human whose relationships are depicted as often dysfunctional whether it is with his paranoid wife Mary Todd over the loss of deceased son or his rebellious older son, Robert (Joseph Gordon-Levitt).Unwilling to compromise on his beliefs, Lincoln realizes that his legacy will be tied to this moment forever.  It is revealing how the political challenges in Congress are dealt with in bold strokes or subtle, delicate wording.  His battles with Congress have direct parallels with the current political climate.Lincoln had the foresight to look ahead and anticipate his legacy and how the world will look on to this moment in history including the proposed Reconstruction of the South once hostilities ceased.  The behind the scenes cajoling and arm twisting make for an interesting insight into the political process. As the momentous day for the important vote arrives, each congressman places his vote in a manner not unlike the founding fathers of 1776.Daniel Day-Lewis has become the Paul Muni of our generation.  By being selective with his roles, he has played larger than life period figures that have transcended their respective films.  He inhabits this role perfectly, and the makeup work and vocal inflections are outstanding.  When the war winds down and has taken an emotional toll on Lincoln, you see the President's line worn face.Sally Field is the perfect foil as Mary Todd, his opinionated wife.  Tommy Lee Jones is a standout in an impressive cast of well known actors (including Holbrook as an influential citizen).  His Thaddeus Stevens, whose support was instrumental in Congress, is an intimidating figure with an imposing demeanor.  He gets some of the best lines.  James Spader makes a fine, slimy operative for Seward, who is played with stern conviction by David Strathairn.  Spielberg consistently gives a slave's point of view to put things in perspective. The war and the amendment are seen through the eyes of former slaves particularly Gloria Reuben's servant to Mrs. Lincoln.The film is magnificently shot by Janusz Kaminski in a manner that emulates the iconic pictures of the period.  You feel at times that you are witness to actual, historic events.  We don't actually see much of the Civil War battles but rather the aftermath in the bodies and limbs that are testimonials to the horror of warfare.  Indeed, such themes recur in Spielberg films depicting World War I (War Horse) and World War II (Schindler's List, Saving Private Ryan, Empire of the Sun).There is a certain reverence and awe when you watch this film because the details are recreated vividly.  Tony Kushner's screenplay is the blueprint that enables Spielberg to add to a body of work that contains some of the best documentations of American history (Amistad).  There will be future film versions on the life of this remarkable historic figure, but it is difficult to imagine a better impersonation, period.

reviewText: Instead of giving us the expanse of Abraham Lincoln's life (which could arguably fill several films), we get here a small slice: the passage of the 13th amendment, outlawing slavery.  This is a smart movie: it gives director Steven Spielberg a focus (which he sorely needs), and keeps the film from meandering all over the place.LINCOLN is truly an actor's piece.  In the lead role, Daniel Day-Lewis is predictably flawless; his rendition of Lincoln is so thorough, the immediate effect is a little underwhelming; it's only after the screen goes dark that you realize you've witnessed such an amazing transformation/performance.  More immediately enjoyable are some of the supporting roles, particularly Tommy Lee Jones as the outspoken Thaddeus Stevens; Sally Field, as Lincoln's troubled spouse; David Straitharn as Lincoln's contentious Secretary of State William Seward; David Costabile, as one of Lincoln's groundlings; Jackie Earle Healey as Confederate VP Alexander Stephens; and Jared Harris as a simmering Ulysses S. Grant.  We also get, in less fleshed-out roles (the script doesn't give them much to do, unfortunately), a who's who of character actors: Joseph Gordon-Levitt; Hal Holbrook; James Spader; Bruce McGill; Tim Blake Nelson; John Hawkes; and others.  The supporting cast flits in and out; most of the performances are believable and top-notch, even when the script falters.And falter it does.  Tony Kershner has written a good script; the only problem is, it's not as impressive at its real-life subject matter.  Everything Lincoln says seems weighted with meaning; Day-Lewis understands what Lincoln was going for--a story or joke to lighten the mood, even if it has the opposite effect--but Spielberg and Kershner want every word this president says to mean something important.  The effect is didactic and off-putting; where we and the cast simply want the story to be about the characters, it suddenly becomes and morality.  We get it: this was an important time in American history.  There can be no disputing that.  But the audience is well aware of the importance; the film's true goal should've been--and, in a few spots, is--the characters involved in that moment.  Day-Lewis anchors the film with his heartfelt portrayal; but if LINCOLN had eschewed politics and focused a tad more on character, this could've been a 5-star movie, easily.  As is, you should definitely watch it; but you might not enjoy it as much as you would have otherwise.
summary: How to make a historical biopic.
