reviewText: Although "Lincoln" takes place over the space of its final four months, this is not a Civil War movie in that there are only two battlefield scenes. And as graphic and grisly as they are, both are rendered superfluous. The film, instead, focuses on the president's need to ram the 13th Amendment banning slavery through the recalcitrant House of Representatives before the Civil War comes to an end.As such, "Lincoln" is the antithesis of an "action" film which might explain why the audience I viewed it with contained few, if anyone, under the age of 40. Instead, its core power comes from scenes of people talking, discussing, and in many cases shouting. Mid-19th century America was a crude, raucous arena and the most exciting scenes take place on the floor of the House where members regularly heckle, browbeat and insult each other. In fact, the eloquent verbal savaging of one's political opponent is so lively that had C-SPAN existed then, it would be the most entertaining channel on television.One of the joys of "Lincoln" is that you are so immersed in the time period, that it is difficult to leave the theater afterwards without getting disoriented. You can feel the mustiness of the furnishings, the chill in the meagerly heated White House, and the constrictions of the clothing. Politics is a game so corrupt that the bribing and manipulating of politicians is openly accepted and Honest Abe is not averse to playing it to get the votes needed to pass the amendment. Ever the lawyer, he knows that the Emancipation Proclamation is not legally binding and that the eventually reunited Southern states will not heed it. Hence, the war can end with a Union victory with slavery still a fact of life below the Mason-Dixon Line.The passing of this landmark addition to the Constitution is always in doubt. The racism of the era is unflinchingly demonstrated, one of the core scenes being when fire-breathing abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens (an acerbically delightful Tommy Lee Jones) cannot avow on the House floor that all men are indeed, "created equal", knowing that such a radical declaration will alienate the swing votes.  The idea that black Americans (and all women might) someday get the vote is met with outcries of rage and disbelief.  It is a deal with the Devil that Stevens makes and he knows it.Much has been made of the acting of Daniel Day-Lewis in the title role and it is indeed a tour-de-force. Midway through, you forget it is an actor you are seeing instead of the actual personage. His Lincoln is sensitive, melancholy, profane, at times riled and always funny as hell, ready at the drop of the hat with a story or tall tale, most laced with R-rated language. Gangly and awkward, were he to run for office today, he wouldn't survive the first primary. Give Day-Lewis the Best Actor Oscar now and save us the ceremony.But I would give a Best Supporting Actress nod to Sally Field who fought for her role as Mary Lincoln. This sad woman, plagued by depression and migraine headaches, devastated by the loss of her son, Willy, is a study in iron tragedy. She both loves and hates her husband for his exalted occupation and his aloofness and the scenes where they argue over their children, both living and dead, have a poignant immediacy. Field inhabits Mary as much as her counterpart inhabits her husband.While not as great as I had anticipated, I woke up in the middle of the night thinking about it and relishing the characters and scenes from one of the most momentous epics of American history. Spielberg has always had a hit ("Saving Private Ryan", "Schindler's List") or miss ("Amistad", "1941") relationship with history but this latest offering is truly in the first category.

reviewText: For those who are not students of history, the 13th Amendment was one of those tests of a country, a moral test, if you will.  And so it was that on January 31, 1865, by a vote of 119 to 56, the Amendment passed ending slavery in America.  All but 4 Democrats abstained or voted against it, while every Republican voted for it.  Even Wikipedia does not mention that fact.  It’s not the first time Republicans have been at the front of the fight for equal rights while Democrats tried to block their efforts (check the Civil Right Amendment in 1964).Perhaps, to me, the most amusing moment in the film was the floor debate on what this amendment would lead to—Blacks being able to vote? Or even … dare I say…votes for women???  This latter suggestion evoked even greater horror among the congressmen of both parties than the amendment itself.This film is a “must see”, every bit as important as “The Help” or “To Kill A Mockingbird”.  But it’s more than just an historical film, as Spielberg tries to give us a personal glimpse into the type of man who led the country through it’s darkest hour since the Revolutionary War.  The political ramifications of that time period are much more complex than generally known.  It’s a history lesson in a bottle, and I hope the popularity of this film will ensure that many in America, young and old, will experience it firsthand.  As late as 1857, just a few years before Lincoln, the U.S. Supreme Court declared slaves were property, not persons, and had no constitutional protections.  America was late in ending slavery: Mexico declared it abolished in 1810, the Dutch in 1814, England in 1834, and Sweden in 1847, just to name a few.  So this world-wide tide had to be something Americans felt washing over them during the middle of the 19th century.This film is truly a first string effort with Kathleen Kennedy producing, Steven Spielberg directing, and music by John Williams.  You may not know Joanna Johnston, who did the costume design, but you have certainly seen all the blockbusters she has worked on.  In short, this is the Oscar nomination club.  And starring such heavyweights as Daniel Day Lewis, Tommy Lee Jones, Sally Field, David Strathairn (portraying William Seward—the same Seward who got us Alaska for 2 cents an acre), and Hal Holbrook (who I first saw in “3 Days of the Condor”), how could you go wrong?  In short, I always try to let you know when a movie will be on the short list for many Academy Awards, and this is just such a movie.Let’s start with Daniel Day Lewis.  I have not liked him in every role, but his performance here is noteworthy.  That being said, I can certainly understand how some might say the portrayal edges on boring.  But that’s what Lincoln was—a shy, soft-spoken, witty, deeply troubled man who aged a full lifetime during the four years of horror that cost his country almost 600,000 men.  To put that in perspective, it would take the World War I, World War II and Vietnam losses combined to equal that figure.  The stakes were high, not just for those in slavery, but for the geographic and political future of America.  Try to picture, if you can, two separate countries with a border right across the middle of what we now call the United States.  Lewis seems to capture the essence of Lincoln, right down to the awkward gait and his shy, eye contact avoiding mannerisms.Sally Field as Mary Todd Lincoln was good, but not great.  She’s one of my favorite actors, but her screen time is a bit short to really get into the character.  To make up for that, or perhaps because of her on screen presence, the scenes that are included seem to ramp up too quickly, as if we are cramming for a final.  One notable exception is the extended scene in which she and Lincoln fight about whether to allow their son to enlist and her moment in the receiving line when she delivers a bit of vitriol toward Representative Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones).  I read that it was not Lincoln who threatened to commit her to an asylum, but her son Robert who actually did it.Tommy Lee really shines in this movie, but he shines in every movie.  His portrayal of a staunch abolitionist congressman was heartwarming and funny.  He’s a master of conveying pages of drama with one close-up shot of his expression.  There’s a nice surprise right at the end of the movie regarding the reason for his passion against slavery.  I found the debates on the floor of the house, and the efforts of W.N. Bilbo (well played by James Spader) to ‘procure’ the votes of hold-out Democrats to be very entertaining.Though not seen until the end of the movie, Jared Harris as Ulysses S. Grant also stands out in my mind for special recognition.  He makes a lot out of a little, and his final moments with Lincoln are moving.This is an historical piece, so there are no spoilers in telling you about the history itself, but there would be in discussing how that history came to be.  So I will let you see the story for yourself, and give you just enough to make you want to pay for a full price ticket.  I don’t believe you will be disappointed, but keeping some of my dispassionate perspective, I will not argue with those who might find the movie to be a bit slow and a bit long.  Could this have been edited down about 30 minutes?  Maybe.  Could some of the scenes with Mary Todd Lincoln have been shortened or eliminated?  At 150 minutes, the film is not too long, but it’s close.  Speaking personally, I never looked at my watch and was engaged in the film from start to finish, but then, I have a better than average attention span (after all, I sat through Muskateers!)The subject of Lincoln has been extensively documented in films and books, and whether you are a history buff or don’t know much about the 16th President outside of school assignments, this movie is worthy of your time and money.
summary: A great study of a man we all think we know

reviewText: By now, we've come to expect any performance by Daniel Day-Lewis is going to be incredible. The time and effort the man puts into his roles is remarkable. Mix in one of the best supporting casts you can think of and you're bound to have one of the best movies of the year. Such is the case with Lincoln.Day-Lewis transcends any expectations you may have about his performance, so much so that the man you're watching on screen IS Abraham Lincoln. He is truly a joy to watch and captures the essence of the iconic figure so well. A huge hand has to be given to Steven Spielberg, who delivers his best film in quite a while. The attention to detail is impeccable, the cinematography is outstanding and the supporting cast is terrific.
summary: Truly Great Film with Legendary Lead Performance

reviewText: I really wanted to love "Lincoln." I was hoping for a biopic that would be both intimate and spectacular. I wanted the film to sweep me away and bring me close to an historical figure in the way that "A Man for All Seasons" allowed audiences to feel close to Sir Thomas More, or "Lawrence of Arabia" created an unforgettable impression of T. E. Lawrence. I was hoping at least for a film as good as John Ford's "Young Mr. Lincoln."Steven Spielberg's "Lincoln" felt more like an educational docudrama than a gripping feature film. Daniel Day-Lewis, though, gives a commanding performance as Lincoln. You should see the film. It is good. It's just not anywhere near good enough.It's hard to believe that Steven Spielberg, one of the most successful and influential Hollywood directors of all time, could have made a film so plodding and wooden. Scriptwriter Tony Kushner is a Pulitzer-prize winner. I would have to guess that Mr. Kushner did not win that prize for crafting gripping, dramatic scripts charged with dramatic tension and driven by character-revealing plot.The film is entitled "Lincoln" but it would be more aptly titled "The Passing of the 13th Amendment Outlawing Slavery." This shift of focus may have been done to make the film "relevant."It's a high school English class truism that the main character of a story is the one who changes. Abraham Lincoln does not change in this film. In many scenes, he feels like a statue in the corner. Lincoln deputizes WN Bilbo (James Spader) to hustle up the necessary votes. Spader is terrific as Bilbo, and he almost steals the movie. It's Bilbo who is moving and shaking. Lincoln just hangs back and comes out with a quip or bon mot or folksy, homespun tale or spooky prophetic dream every now and then. Heck, the animatronic Lincoln at Disneyland could do everything that Spielberg and Kushner allow their Lincoln to do.Sally Field is too old to play Mary Todd Lincoln, who was in her forties at the time, with a young son. In her every scene, all I kept thinking was, "So, how is Sally Field doing as Mary Todd Lincoln?" I was never able to forget that it was Field I was looking at, never able to escape the fact that I was watching a film rather than being immersed in a story.Many of the actors seem to have a hard time delivering Kushner's lengthy sentences. There is a scene where Mary Todd Lincoln is, in a long-winded manner, telling off Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones) at a formal dinner, and it is so stiff it feels like a high school production. Daniel Day-Lewis never has this problem with the dialogue.David Strathairn is terrific as William Seward, Lincoln's secretary of state. He and DDL are utterly convincing in their scenes together. You really get a sense that these are two political partners with differing styles who are struggling as best they can toward a common goal - ending slavery. At one point Lincoln grievously disappoints Seward, and he dismisses Seward by remarking, "Time is a great thickener of things." Seward's response is priceless. The movie comes to life at that moment. It is depicting a vital but trouble relationship, how that relationship vents its anger, how it heals its wounds, how it struggles onward toward a hoped-for goal. If more time had been devoted to Lincoln and Seward's relationship, "Lincoln" would have been a better film.Tommy Lee Jones delivers the biting insults of Thaddeus Stevens, Pennsylvania congressman and chairman of the House Ways and Means committee. Stevens' insults, and his ridiculous wig, and Tommy Lee Jones' persona and voice, are so striking that Stevens almost becomes a caricature. He bellows that another house member is a reptile too low to step upon. The film doesn't get beyond that. It doesn't bring us into the mind of a white man courageous enough to battle slavery. There is a great, brave, brief scene where Lincoln and Stevens speak face-to-face and one-on-one. Stevens talks about his contempt for the common man. How could such a contemptuous person fight for human dignity? It's a conundrum the film doesn't plumb. Lincoln responds to Stevens with a terrific metaphor about compasses and swamps. Again, if there had been more of this kind of intelligent, challenging, and focused dialogue, this would have been a better film.My major disappointment with this film is that it didn't bring me any closer to Lincoln. There is something about Lincoln that defies the limitations of his time and place, and, therefore, understanding of him. He is truly larger than life. In the many photos of him, we see a compelling but inaccessible man. His features, with their marked facial asymmetry, grip and confound us - they invite, and resist, intimacy. He married a woman rumored to be mad. He was rumored to be a homosexual. He was martyred on Good Friday and it is said he haunts the White House. Daniel Day-Lewis' performance made me feel close to Lincoln, but the plot and direction didn't support that. I left disappointed.The production values are lavish. Scenes are chock-a-block with authentic, accurate, books, costumes, boot buckles, mustache combs, clay jugs, corsets, wallpaper. You almost get a whiff of the stale air of a museum. I look forward to watching the extra-feature-packed DVD that will include a chart with little arrows pointing to each object and offering its provenance, age, and construction materials.
summary: A Disappointment. But Daniel Day-Lewis is Great

reviewText: Spielberg and Daniel Day Lewis at their very best! This film should have received more awards than it did. Lewis's Lincoln is so amazing that he has, once again, set an impossibly high bar for any who will portray our 16th President in the future. The rest of the cast is truly outstanding, although unavoidably overshadowed by Lewis's great performance of "Lincoln". And the screenplay and narrow focus of the story (the 13th amendment to the constitution) is a welcome change from other Lincoln films which cover too much ground or simply focus on the assassination at Ford's Theatre. A truly great work of historical and artistic significance.  Begs to be viewed more than once. Highly recommended!
summary: One of the best political films in years.

reviewText: For all of the fine films made about Abraham Lincoln over the years, Steven Speilberg's Lincoln presents us with, arguable, the finest film portrait.  The focus of the film is the pivotal last four months of Lincoln's life, the culmination of the civil war and the search for a way to heal the divided country.  The main focus of the film is the passage of the 13th amendment to end slavery.  However, there are other struggles in film in Lincoln's personal life (focusing on his son Robert's (sensitively played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt0) desire to become a soldier) and the president's feelings on the terrible losses of the war and the question of how to proceed with the place of the freed slaves and how to bring the divided nation back together. Although a narrow focus, Lincoln gives us a full portrait of Abraham Lincoln.Daniel Day-Lewis has given us a very human Abraham Lincoln displaying his humor, his political acumen and his family tragedies.  He also seems a tired man, weary after four years of war that he seen a level of destruction and casualties on an unprecedented level.  Mr. Day-Lewis brings Lincoln to life showing him playing political hardball with the Southern delegation and attempting to deal with his emotions as he deals with family issues.  Sally Field gave a full and convincing portrait of Mary Lincoln, still distraught after the death of their young son Willie but able to insult Thaddeus Stevens at a White House reception.Equally astonishing is the part Thaddeus Stevens plays in the passage of the 13th amendment (marvelously portrayed by Tommy Lee Jones).  Stevens is a firebrand politician, violently abolitionist who come s around to compromise to see the amendment passed.  Mr. Jones brings real passion to his portrayal of Stevens, and for all of his hardness we also see the softer side of Stevens when he takes the House copy of the amendment home to show to his "housekeeper." The turbulent politics of the period are well represented in the debate in the House of Representative that becomes a lesson in civics for us all.  This is well represented by the trio of arm-twisters hired by Secretary of State Seward to ensure there are enough Democrat votes.  The trio actors often played with great humor by John Hawkes, James Spader and Tim Blake Nelson show us how things are done in the 1860's.The large supporting cast for Lincoln have some truly memorable performances.  Secretary of State William Seward is beautifully played by David Strathairn,  Lincoln's secretary John Nicolay is sensitively portrayed by Jeremy Strong) and Secretary of War Edwin Stanton is memorably played by Bruce McGill especially when he snaps at Lincoln, "No, you're not going to tell a story.  I can't bear to hear one."Mr. Spielberg recreates the period so very well.  The White House and other Washington venues were painstakingly recreated.  Lincoln's office was re-created with painstaking accuracy.  Much credit is owed to the production designer (Rick Carter) and costume designer (Joanna Johnson) for turning back the clock.  The costume designers and the actors themselves convincingly conducted themselves as people from the period with their look and manners.  Some of the reviews I have read prefer the mini-series to this film as being a more complete portrait of Lincoln.  I think the film needs to be appreciated and judged on its own merits.  A film is a limited form of communication where an hours long television series can afford details.  There may be events and anecdotes some feel needed to be included but this does not limit the power of Lincoln.

reviewText: The scene in the film that stands out to me is where Lincoln (Daniel Day-Lewis) is conversing with a pair of young telegraph operators.  They wonder if whether the times we are born in are randomly selected or if we are deliberately chosen for a specific moment in time.  Lincoln then goes on to expound on a theory of the philosopher Euclid.  If two things are equal to another thing would they not be equal to one another?  There are many such moments that define this magnificent film.  My brother felt it was when one of Lincoln's war secretaries storms out of the room not willing to subject himself to Lincoln spinning another analogous tall tale. My wife fell asleep(?!).  "Lincoln" is a film whose power cannot be underestimated.  I thought so when I saw it in the theatre being so enthralled with Day-Lewis' portrayal of our greatest president.  Watching it a second time there were details though not overlooked the first time but overwhelmed by the central performance.  What impressed me was the poetry of the script by Tony Kushner adapted from the book by Doris Kearns Goodwin, "Team of Rivals".  Kushner juggles probably a few dozen characters with speaking parts and makes them full fledged players in the Universe of Lincoln. My favorite are the two lobbyists who try to influence wavering Democratic congressmen to vote for the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution.  The language of the film is almost Shakespearean in nature that you find yourself basking in its poetry.  Director Steven Spielberg serving as the master of ceremonies provides the aural and visual landscape for this play to unfold.  The focus, of course, is on Lincoln the man.  There's a tendency to deify him and the first time I saw this film I was taken up with Day-Lewis' charismatic turn.  Things I picked up this time in Day-Lewis' carefully calibrated performance is Lincoln's imperfections notably his wily lawyer trickiness and perhaps his shortcomings as a husband to Mary Todd (Sally Field) particularly in the wake of the death of their son, Willie.  That said these flaws not only accentuate Lincoln's fallibility but highlight his basic decency and empathy for his fellow man.  I could go on and on so rich an experience "Lincoln" is.  This is not merely a film but an event.  Now is definitely the time for this masterpiece.
summary: Landmark Film For Spielberg and Day-Lewis

reviewText: The man needs to stop making movies.  He knows how to open the movie going soul, and he didn't disappoint in Lincoln.  If Daniel Day Lewis doesn't win an Oscar for Best Actor & Tommy Lee Jones doesn't win best supporting actor there's something wrong with the world.  Very moving, wonderful cast, and many of Lincoln's words were so very inspiring, even now.  There were several moments I came to tears, yet it was scenes prior to the Ford's Theater shooting Spielberg spared us from showing, that moved me the most.  It was the telegraph office scene, when Lincoln was talking to two young telegraph operators & his riding through the war dead & visiting with Ulysees S. Grant that were monumental in making this the Best Picture of 2012. Lincoln's courage really set the world in motion of abolishing slavery on a world stage.  I can only image how screwed up the world would be if Abraham Lincoln didn't grace our nation.

reviewText: This review deals not so much with the film itself, which is excellent and highly recommended. But there seems to be a disconcerting tendency in DreamWorks Blu-ray/DVD combo releases in forcing the consumer to shell out an inordinate amount of money just to get a few extra features which are produced on a separate disc even though there seems to be no particular reason (other than corporate greed) for doing so.The extras on the 4-disc combo of LINCOLN, while worthwhile and informative, could quite easily have been included on the disc containing the film--as, for example, they were on Universal's great new LES MISERABLES blu-ray (even though the running time of LES MIS is 8 minutes longer (!) than LINCOLN. One of the big selling points of blu-rays was that you supposedly have more content room on the disc than on a standard DVD, which makes the whole notion of having a separate "extra features" disc all the more mystifying.The reason I'm singling out DreamWorks in particular is that this is almost EXACTLY what they did for the 4-disc combo release of Spielberg's WAR HORSE. I say "almost" because at least in that instance, they packaged all of the  discs separately and correctly in an extra-large sized case.  For LINCOLN, the movie and special features discs were both simply jammed in together on one spindle (and in point of fact, the movie Blu-ray was scratched and skipped when I played it the first time).I realize that with the advent of the Blu-ray format, we were forced to bite our collective tongues and go along with buying into it if we wanted extra features on our discs since the DVD version nowadays is increasingly the "bare-bones" release, but enough is enough.In closing, I just want to reiterate that if the studios want we consumers to continue to support the Blu-ray format, they need to step up to the plate a little bit and not treat us like idiots who will sit still for anything. We deserve better, frankly...
summary: Great film, lousy "contempt for consumer". packaging

reviewText: Most of us have a pretty solid grip on history. Slavery was evil. The 13th Amendment to the Constitution which ended slavery was most excellent, and you would most certainly have voted for it. And Lincoln was a great guy as can be seen by the fact that he is on mineral and paper money.One of the marvelous things Steven Spielberg's film, Lincoln, does is show how difficult some of these choices were a century and a half ago. In April of 1864, the US Senate passed the 13th Amendment with relative ease. The passage of the amendment through the House of Representatives, which was much more of a struggle, is the focus of the film's action.I choose the word "action" carefully. If your knowledge of legislation comes from Schoolhouse Rock's "I'm Just a Bill," you might be surprised by the intrigue, drama and humor that screenwriter Tony Kushner draws from public debate and backroom deals. We're not presented with clear white and black (or blue and grey) hats to root for or against. We see good, wise and, yes, Christian men pitted in opposition.Many Republican Representatives looked to Francis Preston Blair (Hal Holbrook) for direction. Blair was concerned that passage of the amendment would endanger peace talks. As great an evil slavery was, he believed, war was a greater evil. Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones), a leader of the abolitionist movement, had to downplay the scope and consequences of the legislation to help it pass. This galled the abolitionists, and was even more offensive to those of African descent.Other Christian men, primarily Democrats, believed that slavery itself wasn't evil, but was sanctioned by Scripture. Godly men (and women, but they couldn't vote) claimed to seek God's will on the issue of slavery and came to opposing positions. They didn't have history's hindsight to know what position would have the 21st century stamp of approval.Abraham Lincoln admitted as much, even in the midst of the great Civil War. In an 1862 memorandum, he wrote, "In great contests, each party claims to act in accordance with the will of God. Both may be, and one must be, wrong. God cannot be for and against the same thing at the same time." Throughout the film we see Lincoln (portrayed brilliantly by Daniel Day-Lewis) fighting, sometime even underhandedly, for what he believes is right, all the while acknowledging that he might not be right. He acts boldly, yet with great humility.If Lincoln could show so much humility in the issues of slavery, war and suffrage, perhaps we can show some humility when it comes to such issues as abortion, marriage, and immigration. There are great dangers we face as Christians, and especially as a church, when we delve into issues the world views as political.Jesus confronted one such danger when approached on tax policy (Matthew 22: 17 - 21). Jesus said some realms belonged to God and some to Caesar. We need to discern which things are sacred and which are secular, but we must avoid two other great dangers: we must not ascribe ignorance, evil or incompetence to others, just because they disagree with our moral or political points of view, and we must not abandon great issues to the world just because they are controversial.The church played a great role in ending legal slavery in the Western World (don't think slavery itself is dead). The church helped secure civil rights and fought racial prejudice. There are many other moral battles that must be waged, but we must walk in the Lord's footsteps, being as wise as serpents, yet as gentle as doves.(Lincoln is rated PG-13 for graphic battlefield violence and vulgar language, some of it escaping the lips of the 16th President.)
summary: One Christian's View of "Lincoln" and Its Lessons for the Church Today

reviewText: Daniel Day-Lewis nails the character of Lincoln in a way no other actor has (or possibly could). Sally Field and Tommy Lee Jones are also standout performers in this film. This movie does an outstanding job of illustrating a crucial time when Lincoln was struggling to get the 13th Amendment passed before the war ended or he was pressured into making a peace deal with the Confederacy. It is not a biographical film about Lincoln's life, which a lot of people assumed it would be. It's about Lincoln maneuvering this country through some of it's most dark and difficult times, when a lot of the population and many of the politicians they elected would have been all too happy to take the easy way out. This is also not a war/action movie, which I suspect some people might have assumed as well. There is a lot of dialogue, a lot of history, and a lot of character interaction. If you're expecting anotherGlory, you'll be disappointed. If you want to see how American government really worked in the 19th century, you won't. Simply a great, timeless film.

reviewText: "Team of Rivals" by Doris Kearns Goodwin is a wonderful book and it is worthy of recommendation to anyone.This film, however, is not.Steven Spielberg was wildly the wrong person to make this movie. From the very first sequence of dialogue it screamed "Wrong. Wrong. Wrong."  The film hasn't run 30 seconds, and you can tell right away that Spielberg has no natural feel for the material.  The following 135 minutes merely confirm that first impression ad nauseum.  There is nothing subtle or clever or insightful in either the scriptwriting or the direction. The cinematography is good, and there is nothing wrong with DDL's performance. Other than that, though, given the material they were starting from, the screenplay is uncomfortably close to awful.  Ham-fisted, really. Like something out of the 1930's or 1940's - Stilted, and awkward as "Ruggles of Red Gap", or "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington".135 minutes of bathos. Cannot imagine anyone sitting through it twice.What it brought to mind was the contrast between "Schindler's List", which won a bucket of Oscars, and "Remains of the Day", which had the misfortune of being in the same year, and therefore won nothing.  Nobody watches "Schindler's List" anymore, but "Remains of the Day" is rented over and over and is rightly regarded as an enduring classic for the twin outstanding performances of Anthony Hopkins and Emma Thompson."Lincoln" would have been a far, far better film if the screenplay had been written by somebody like Aaron Sorkin.  He would have understood the material and would have brought it to light, in a way that Spielberg apparently could not, and did not.  Spielberg doesn't get subtlety or irony - the qualities more than any others in which President Lincoln's transcendent genius was most often seen.  As for a director? Somebody like Clint Eastwood 15 years ago - at the time of "Unforgiven" - would have had a much better feel for it.  Spielberg was embarrassingly the wrong guy to make this film.

reviewText: As a young child, Steven Spielberg was captivated when he saw the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C.Decades later, the filmmaker would direct and produce the historical drama film "Lincoln" that is based on Doris Kearn Goodwin's biography "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln" focusing on the final four months of Abram Lincoln's life and focusing on his efforts to have the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution passed by the United States House of Representatives. in January 1865.Filmed in the Fall of 2011 and released theatrically int the Fall of 2012, "Lincoln" has received critical acclaim worldwide, earning seven Golden Globe nominations, twelve Academy Award nominations and grossing over $263 million at the box office, making "Lincoln" a financial success.The film would feature an all-star cast including Daniel Day-Lewis ("There Will Be Blood", "Gangs of New York", "The Last of the Mohicans"), Sally Field ("Forrest Gump", "Mrs. Doubtfire", "Brothers & Sisters"), David Strathairn ("The Bourne Ultimatum", "L.A. Confidential", "Good Night" and "Good Luck"), Joseph Gordon-Levitt ("Inception", "Looper", "(500) Days of Summer"), James Spader ("Boston Legal", "Stargate", "Secretary"), Hal Holbrook ("Wall Street", Men of Honor", "Into the Wild"), Tommy Lee Jones ("No Country for Old Men", "Men in Black" films, "The Fugitive"), John Hawkes ("American Gangster, "Identity", "The Sessions") and many more.And now "Lincoln" was released on Blu-ray and DVD, including a 4-Disc Combo Pack which includes the Blu-ray (2), DVD and Digital Copy in March 2013.VIDEO:"Lincoln" is presented in 1080p High Definition (2:40:1 aspect ratio).  With one of the most well-known cinematographers such as Janusz Kaminski ("Saving Private Ryan", "Schindler's List", "Minority Report", "Catch Me If You Can") working on the film, one can expect nothing but the best in terms of cinematography, capturing the characters in fantastic lighting situations.  And once again, Kaminski's cinematography is fantastic!  Featuring incredible detail and like era, using natural color to enhance the overall feeling of the film, skin tones are natural, the film features great contrast with outdoor scenes featuring a variety of colors, from a normal day to a cool, cold night where Abraham Lincoln and soldiers ride their horses through dead bodies during the war.  Black levels are nice and deep, Joanna Johnston's costume design and Rick Carter's production design of capturing authenticity is also captured amazingly on camera courtesy of Kaminski."Lincoln" looks fantastic on Blu-ray!AUDIO & SUBTITLES:As for the audio, "Lincoln" is presented in English 7.1 DTS-HDMA, Envlish DVS 2.0 Dolby Digital, French and Spanish 5.1 Dolby Digital.  I was very impressed with the lossless soundtrack.  It's one thing to expect crystal clear dialogue with wonderful music from legendary composer John Williams ("Star Wars" films, "Harry Potter" films, "Indiana Jones" films) but the amount of ambiance captured through the surrounds is wonderful.  With the constant chattering during the political debates, there is also use of LFE during certain scenes.  But even sounds of storms, sounds of wood upon wood, may it be a closure of a room, wheel making contact on the floor, good use of rear surround channels.  But it's the dialogue and the ambiance along with Williams' music that sounds incredible.Subtitles are in English SDH, French and Spanish.SPECIAL FEATURES"Lincoln" comes with the following special features:The Journey to Lincoln - (9:24) Featuring interviews with Steven Spielberg, producer Kathleen Kennedy and the cast about being part of the film and the creation of it.A Historic Tapestry: Richmond, Virginia - (4:00) Filmmaker Steven Spielberg and crew talk about being able to film at historic structures to recreate the feel of Washington, D.C. and Virginia during the Civil War era in Richmond, Virginia.In the Company of Character - (10:23) A featurette about the casting of the talent to play various characters and working with Daniel Day-Lewis.  Each cast member talks about their involvement in the film and meeting the other talents and how they immersed themselves and prepared for this film.Crafting the Past - (10:43) A special feature about costume and production design.  Production designer Rick Carter talks and costume designer Joanna Johnston about capturing the detail of the era and trying to make everything in the film look authentic.Living with Lincoln - (27:04) A special feature about a period biopic and the contribution to make this film feel like it was taking place in the past.  Capturing the look and feel but also through the performances.In Lincoln's Footsteps - (16:35) A featurette about the editing of the film and how it was important to have the long periods instead of constant cuts.  Discussing the visual perspective of the film and the audio.EXTRAS:"Lincoln" comes with two Blu-rays (one for the feature film and the other for special features), a DVD and Digital Copy version of the film.  Also, a slipcover case is included.JUDGMENT CALL:When I was younger, my grandfather, an immigrant from the Philippines would always use Abraham Lincoln as an example for us and why people are fortunate today to be able to have a good education, strive for a good education because of what Lincoln was give people of color a chance of freedom in the United States.He would always talk about the Emancipation Proclamation and I as I grew older, like every child taught in school about what Lincoln did to free the slaves, it was an important order from Abraham Lincoln during the American Civil War.Only until I became an adult, would you realize that there was much more to the story than the simple "Lincoln freed the slaves!" that we have been taught.  Along with the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863, it wasn't until the passing of the Thirteenth Amendment in 1865 which abolished slavery, that the amendment was monumental.But it wasn't easy.  With so much focus of Lincoln on his assassination by John Wilkes Booth, I really didn't know too much about Abraham Lincoln's life until I saw the biographical silent film "Abraham Lincoln" (1930) directed by D.W. Griffith.  While this film focused on Lincoln's earlier life as a storekeeper and rail-splitter and his earlier romance with Ann Rutledge and later being engaged to Mary Todd and the Lincoln-Douglas debates about the extension of slavery, there really hasn't been anything showcasing the passing of the Thirteenth Amendment.I can understand why.  It's not an easy subject for one to craft and make it entertaining for general audiences,  People know how the amendment was historic, but would one want to watch it as a film?That's where filmmaker Steven Spielberg comes in and the fact that he is directing the film, the answer is yes.  If Spielberg can make this film entertaining, it's definitely worth giving a try.Joining him are top people in the industry, from composer John Williams, director of photography Janusz Kaminski, production designer Rick Carter and costume design by Joanna Johnston, and many others involved with the film, you know you have a great team.And what Spielberg is quite effective was building a storyline with showcasing how difficult of a time it was for President Lincoln.  While the Emancipation Proclamation helped give slaves a chance for freedom during the Civil War, if the war was to end, they would not be free any longer, and not too many were in favor of abolishing slavery, except President Lincoln and a few members of the US House of Representatives.  With wonderful production and costume design to keep the authenticity of the film and the amazing performances by actor Daniel Day-Lewis, Sally Field, David Strathaim, Tommy Lee Jones, Joseph Gordon Levitt to name a few, you can't help but be amazed with how wonderful this film looks, but also how powerful the film is thanks to its outstanding talent.Daniel Day-Lewis captures the look of Abraham Lincoln, Sally Field who gained weight for the role was also able to play the unstable Mary Todd and of course other performers throughout the film, made the film feel authentic and real.The film is smart, compelling but also a message about freedom and equality. Also, it's a subject that not many people are familiar with and you learn that freedom did not come easy but also how President Lincoln took a risk that could have had him impeached.  But he was dedicated, persistent and also made others around him persistent, but most importantly have them put their faith in him to make it happen.  A lot was at stake for some people who voted for the amendment, some who were threatened but yet knowing what was right and debating within, whether or not to be loyal to their political party or to side with Abraham Lincoln in giving freedom to the slaves.As for the 4-Disc Combo Pack of "Lincoln", you get the Blu-ray release (two featuring the feature film, the other with special features), a DVD version of the film and a Digital Copy.  Picture quality along with lossless audio is magnificent, special features are good but I wished they were slightly longer.  It would have been nice to have an audio commentary or even other special features on Abraham Lincoln. But that is me being picky!  For the most part, "Lincoln" is a wonderful Blu-ray release and a film that is powerful and another cinematic masterpiece for Steven Spielberg.Overall, "Lincoln" is a fascinating, compelling film featuring fantastic cinematography, production and costume design but also  a magnificent performances by Daniel Day-Lewis, Sally Field and many others.  Highly recommended!
summary: (4.5 Stars) Lincoln" is a fascinating, compelling film!  Wonderful performance from Daniel Day-Lewis and Sally Field!

reviewText: What a gift to be honored with a glimpse into the life of Abraham Lincoln, one of America's most revered leaders, and rightly so. Some may argue that this movie is hagiography and a white wash, but IMHO, no way! The burden of proof falls on the naysayers. Don't get me wrong, "Lincoln" is not perfect. There is the goof up on the 13th Amendment vote (for the abolition of slavery in the U.S. and territories) in the U.S. House of Representatives by the Connecticut delegation. The movie says two "no" votes and the historical record says none. All of CT's representatives voted "yes," as clarified by CT's 2nd District congressman Joe Courtney.Yes, I believe this movie got it right by portraying Lincoln as extremely likeable, even loveable. True, his enemies hated and reviled him, but perhaps mainly because his humble openness reflected their mean-spirited selfishness and bigotry back on them. Lincoln was a man of his times, as betrayed by some of his expressed ideas regarding African Americans, but he could also transcend those times. I've often wondered if someone as backwoodsy as Lincoln could ever get elected today. Now I am convinced that yes, he could -- and would. "Honest Abe" would stand out even more today than he did 150 years ago, and his homespun storytelling and humor would strike a chord in any generation. Add to that Lincoln's empathy and warmth, and you have someone who truly "belongs to the ages."Day-Lewis' Lincoln seemed very realistic. Here we see a man who would swear and pound his fist when angry, but who also showed that greatness of soul forged in the crucible of war. Before seeing "Lincoln," I wondered if Sally Field was too old to play Lincoln's wife Mary. After seeing it, I realized that both Lincoln and his wife had become prematurely old by 1865. As General Grant observed in the film, Lincoln aged ten years between 1864 and 1865. The last photographs of Lincoln bear this out. Tragedy ages a person who really cares for others.Regarding the importance of the slavery issue, again I feel this movie got it right. Slavery wasn't everything, but it was the main thing. The states' rights dispute was based on economics, and the Confederate economy thrived on cheap and always accessible labor. Doing away with slavery would force an unwanted paradigm shift down the South's throat. Today, slavery is unthinkable, but then it was not. The movie "Lincoln" helps us to understand that a little better. All in all, a great movie with several minor flaws, none of which threaten a five star rating. In addition to Sally Field's fine effort and Tommy Lee Jones' portrayal of Thaddeus Stevens, David Strathairn was brilliant as Secretary of State William H. Seward, a wannabe co-president who helped sharpen Lincoln as only another iron will could do. With that said, I am at a loss as to why "Lincoln," after twelve Academy Award nominations, received only two Oscars. Fr. Dennis
summary: Day-Lewis and Spielberg bring us Lincoln

reviewText: I liked this movie and everything about it was great except ,the entire movie was about trying to push politicians into voting to free the salves(13th amendment). The FACT IS...... Lincoln didn't think this was the most important thing in his term of office to handle. He wanted to maintain a unified United States at any cost. He said at one time, if freeing the slaves meant keeping the union together then so be it, and if NOT freeing them kept the union together then so be that as well.Personally he was against slavery for sure, but the movie made it out like this was a do or die issue when it wasn't. He wanted to end the war and preserve the country under one flag is the real story. Why Hollywood seems to feel they can't ever tell the truth is beyond me unless it's just that the truth doesn't usually make for good stories perhaps and doesn't produce as many hero's.

reviewerName: D. Mikels "It's always Happy Hour here"
reviewText: Is LINCOLN Steven Spielberg's finest achievement?  Let's just say there's a lot of competition.  Yet the awards, the acclaim, the accolades, the audience reception of this remarkable film speak for themselves.  Telling the story of the last four months of our 16th President's life, LINCOLN focuses on the passage of the 13th Amendment--the abolishment of slavery.  The Civil War is winding down; Lincoln, fearful that his Emancipation Proclamation which declared the slaves war contraband would be struck down by the courts, takes on a sense of urgency to pass the amendment in the month of January, during a lame duck Congress.  With a slim Republican majority, the president is going to need some Democrats to join the Republicans; fortunately, there are 64 lame duck Democrats--who just might be looking for patronage jobs come March.  Secretary of State William Seward (David Strathairn), the president's right hand man, recruits three self-proclaimed "scoundrels" (James Spader, John Hawkes, Tim Blake Nelson) to approach these Democrats in an effort to "buy" them off.  The machinations of this sausage making is fascinating, and as a Confederate delegation reaches General Grant (Jared Harris) to discuss a cessation of hostilities, the story becomes more layered and compelling.  We all know from history the amendment passes--narrowly--and LINCOLN then focuses on the ending of the brutal war--and the tragic ending of the president's life.Daniel Day-Lewis is an extraordinary actor, and here he gives a spellbinding performance as the tall, slender, introverted, brooding, careworn Commander-in-Chief.  Yet the actor conveys another layer to this complex man; Lincoln might have the weight of the world on his shoulders, but his wit was always razor sharp, and he could relate a plethora of stories at the drop of a hat.  Day-Lewis makes this film work, and work exceedingly well.  The entire cast is stellar, but in particular I was most impressed by Tommy Lee Jones (fierce abolitionist Congressman Thaddeus Stevens), Sally Field (a shrill, feisty Mary Todd Lincoln), Joseph Gordon-Levitt (eldest child Robert Lincoln, who desperately wants to get in the fight), James Spader as referenced above, Bruce McGill (fiery Secretary of War Edwin Stanton), and Jared Harris as General Grant in what was comparably a very small role.  Numerous actors have relatively brief roles as Congressmen or telegraph operators or staffers, yet everyone meshes in elegant believability.This Blu-Ray edition offers several bonus features; all of them are very good.  From interviews with Spielberg, the cast, and the production crew, to showing us how the film was shot in Richmond, Virginia, to behind-the-scenes looks at sets, costumes, props, and musical scoring, it's all material that enhances the viewing experience.  Spielberg has made several remarkable films.  There would be no objection from this reviewer to make the argument that LINCOLN is this filmmaker's very best.--D. Mikels, Esq.

reviewText: Lincoln (the film) is about as much fun as 8th grade civics (or geometry class if you count the Euclid lecture). Everyone in this film is either a pontificator or a wide-eyed admirer of pontification. Not even Tony Kushner, not even Daniel Day Lewis can make Abe or his stories (or backroom politicking) seem remotely interesting. Everything about the film is as leaden as a civil war toy soldier. Its clear that Spielberg has no idea what to do with real historical figures (other than revere them), but the real problem here is that the story is not an uplifting one, in fact its downright depressing, and so Spielberg's signature sentimentalism is all wrong for this material: what this film effectively shows is that the only way to ratfiy the 13th amendment was with bribes, threats, and trickery, so what is supposed to be a film documenting one of our prouder moments as a nation is actually a film that undermines that history/that notion of ourselves as morally exceptional. That is not Spielberg's fault, he's just relating the story here. What is Spielberg's fault is that he doesn't seem to know what kind of story he is telling nor does he seem to be aware that he is leaving a very important part of that story untold: the part African-Americans played in their own emancipation/liberation. We do not see or hear from any educated African-Americans like Fredrick Douglas. Instead we only see (mostly mute) black soldiers and house slaves and the way Spielberg represents the house slaves/servants would make it seem as though the film was made in another century and for audiences not used to seeing African-American subjects with speaking parts. Its vision of African-Americans is in many ways more problematic than the vision of African-Americans offered up by Tarantino, because at least the director of Django Unchained has never purported to be in the realism game. Still, Lincoln fails for the exact same reason that Django Unchained fails--its a movie more about the director's relation to movie history (and his preferred modes of storytelling/representation) than it is about history, and therefore its a movie incapable of commenting on anything or being about anything or generating intertest in anything outside its directors closed and limited cinematic universe. A great director, a great film, tells us something about the world, but with each Spielberg film and with each Tarantino film we can see that the directors are much more interested in movies (Spielberg is fascinated by 1940's films/aesthetics; Tarantino in 1970's films/aesthetics) than they are in real life, and so the films just come out as branded (and self-referential) products from Spielberg Inc or Tarantino Inc instead of as art objects capable of inspiring feeling and generating thought about the world itself. Both directors have obvious talents, but the limits of those talents are more on display in their latest works than are the merits of those talents. Spielberg is capable of making inspiring work, but here Spielberg is trying to be inspiring with a story that is more complex than his sentimentalizing aesthetic wants to allow.

reviewText: {4.5 stars}First off, "Lincoln" is more about the passage of the 13th Amendment outlawing slavery in the U.S. and all the haggling that took place in the House of Representatives beforehand than it is about Abe Lincoln personally. The entire story takes place in the early months of 1865 as the Civil War is winding down.Lincoln does, of course, play a pivotal role as the central character in his proposal and backing of the Amendment (yet still, kind of not wanting the war to end before it was voted upon in order to keep the Southern delegations out of the vote). There is also a fine subplot concerning Lincoln's life with his wife and sons, all of whom are admirably played. Day-Lewis really shines in  his role as a Lincoln who is neither saint nor sinner, with a smooth, velvety, and vaguely southern(!) accent. Many of the supporting cast--most particularly, Jared Harris as Ulysses Grant--are also memorably portrayed.This may not sound terribly exciting to some, but the acting, storyline, scenery and everything else are so arresting that those people are likely to forget not being all that interested. Along with the vital ingredient of plot, some other best things about "Lincoln" are its setting and costume design: This film probably conveys the Civil War period better than any that I've seen. There isn't much actual showing of the war, but a couple of very brief but vivid and ultra-realistic battleground scenes really spice things up. Both in Washington and in the brief scenes elsewhere, the cinematography takes you there in a powerful way.Finally, this film is very revealing about the "buying" of votes in Congress and effectively shows how political processes worked and continue to work. A fascinating bit of historical and political intrigue.A couple of tips:--Younger audiences, unless they happen to have an unusual interest in political processes, are likely to be bored with "Lincoln."--If you aren't all that up on Secretary of State William Seward, Representative Thaddeus Stevens, and some of the various other players (maybe check the character list on imdb?), it might be helpful to read-up a little on them before watching this.
summary: 2.5 Hours that Will Fly By Very Quickly

reviewText: In many ways Spielberg's LINCOLN is an old-fashioned film, portraying the central character (Daniel Day-Lewis) as a strong, yet fair personality who overcomes all resistance to pass the amendment ending slavery in the United States. Day-Lewis is just wonderful in the role, his quiet air of authority contrasting starkly with many of the members of the House of Representatives, who let their hearts rule their heads on most occasions.  Tommy Lee Jones provides admirable support as Stevens, the pro-Abolitionist who is nonetheless reluctant to support Lincoln in his efforts.  Beautifully photographed, with atmospheric music by John Williams, this film is long (140 minutes)m, but well worth the effort. Interestingly, I think that its contemporary message is an important one, as Lincoln uses his political skills to overcome resistance to his amendment and eventually wins the vote.  Would that Barack Obama could do the same in implementing his government policies in his second term of office.  Perhaps he should follow Lincoln's example.
summary: Beautiful Film with a Sharp Contemporary Resonance

reviewText: A young boy lies half asleep in front of a fireplace which provides the only light in an otherwise darkened room. The door opens and his long and lanky father enters, lying down beside him and offering him a piggyback ride to bed. Both father and son are united in affection and grief for the boy who isn't there but whose absence haunts a troubled family. Such grace notes, which lead us deeply into the emotional lives of the Lincoln family, are characteristic of Tony Kushner's masterful screenplay which condenses the political and personal Lincoln in a way that illuminates his last few months as well as entertains its audience with the down and dirty machinations necessary to steer the 13th Amendment to the Constitution through a deeply divided House of Representatives.Abraham Lincoln, perhaps the most loved and influential of American presidents, emerges in all his imperfect and very human glory as political philosopher and tactician, humanitarian, storyteller, husband and father through the brilliantly calibrated performance of Daniel Day Lewis, recipient of a landmark third Academy Award for Best Actor. We come to see, under the sure and certain guidance of director Steven Spielberg, Abraham Lincoln as the necessary catalyst for Barack Obama: no Lincoln, no 13th Amendment, no enfranchisement for African Americans, no Obama presidency.Listening to the hyperbolic and inflamed rhetoric which Congressmen, especially the radical abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens of Tommy Lee Jones, hurl at each other on the floor of the House, as well as Lincoln's amused comment to Secretary of State Seward (David Strathairn) about the progress of Confederate delegates on their way to discuss peace issues, "Do you think that word won't get out...in Washington?", we can appreciate how the past is prologue to the present political paralysis in the capitol.Among the huge and carefully chosen cast, Sally Field gives the performance of her career, blending subtlety, variety, articulation, restraint or passion as the situation requires, into a cohesive whole. Field creates a Mary Lincoln that shatters the received wisdom. Here is a sympathetic, no punches pulled woman who recognizes how much her husband is loved yet blames him for the death of their middle son. She interprets his dreams, agitates on behalf of the 13th Amendment, dresses down her husband's opponents in public and tries to keep her eldest son out of war service. Robert Lincoln, as interpreted by Joseph Gordon Levitt, is the voice of youthful enthusiasm for a fight and the embodiment of integrity, parallel to the young police officer, Robin, Gordon Levitt played in "The Dark Knight Rises."Looking, through the eyes of his black valet, at Daniel Day Lewis's Abraham Lincoln in his trademark stove pipe hat and his ill fitting formal clothes as he walks down a White House hall, is to see the man under those clothes: the rural, story loving, self educated and self deprecating lawyer who fashioned some of the most idealistic, poetic and deeply felt words ever uttered on the national, and world, stage.The Lincoln of Daniel Day Lewis, Steven Spielberg and Tony Kushner will have a very long shelf life, thanks to American history teachers who will keep it alive in high school and college classrooms for the next century or more. At home, with our increasingly more sophisticated video technology, we can appreciate "Lincoln" as a cerebral entertainment as a visceral one. We can comprehend the complexity of the arguments put forth; we can feel them in our guts as well.The very challenging cinematography of Spielberg stalwart Janusz Kaminski ("Schindler's List"), using both natural and candle light, is elegantly rendered on Blu-ray (simply put, I had no problem seeing everything), as is the symphonic score of composer John Williams, and the immersive editing of Michael Kahn. The four disc combo pack, overflowing with extras, is a definite keeper, and maybe even an heirloom.
summary: A performance, and a film, for the ages

reviewText: Steven Spielberg's "Lincoln" is both a sprawling character study and a behind-the-scenes story of how the United States came to abolish slavery. Rated PG-13, the film contains really just three scenes that are too graphic for younger children:  the opening Civil War battle sequence, which is extremely violent; a scene mid-point where Robert Lincoln refuses to go inside a hospital with his father, but witnesses something far worse than wounded soldiers outside; and a scene near the end when Lincoln rides a horse through a battlefield filled with dead soldiers.If you shield young ones from those scenes, and maybe plug their ears for the punch line of a story involving a picture of George Washington hanging in a bathroom, they'd be able to watch "Lincoln"--though I can't imagine any of them lasting very long. "Lincoln" will be too slow-moving and, at 150 minutes, too long for most children. The film is driven by dialogue, and the scenes of backdoor politicking that appeal to adults may seem confusing to children. Daniel Day-Lewis is amazing, Spielberg's attention to detail is phenomenal, and "Lincoln" is a great movie. But it's not a great pick for family movie night.James PlathFamily Home Theater
summary: Great movie, not a great pick for family movie night

reviewText: I hate the Civil War.  In eighth grade I had a history teacher that spent four months of class on the civil war, like nothing else ever happened in American History (hey, what about the Depression, two World Wars, Cold War, Civil Rights, etc...), so I HATE the civil war.  The shining star in that whole conflageration was Abraham Lincoln.  Other than my Father there is no other man I respect more.  Among many things Lincoln was one of the greatest American writers of all time, and it would be fair for me to say that I do idolize him.  Daniel Day Lewis' performance is as close as we will ever get to seeing and understanding what and who Lincoln was, and not to see this movie is to cheat oneself out of a rare luxury.  Spielberg at his best;  Daniel Day Lewis at his best; costumes, script, the issues being debated are as current as they were during the civil war, when appreciated properly.  Get the blue ray to get all the extras on this Lincoln masterpiece.  Trust me when I say you can not learn enough about Abraham Lincoln.

reviewText: The Thirteenth Amendment to the U. S. Constitution outlaws slavery and involuntary servitude except as punishment for a crime.  Steven Spielberg's film, "Lincoln," from a screenplay by Tony Kushner and based on Doris Kearns Goodwin's book, "Team of Rivals," describes the horse trading and finagling that was necessary to pass the amendment in the House of Representatives.  Daniel Day Lewis is fine as the title character; Lewis's plain demeanor, humor, compassion, pragmatism, and eloquent speech do justice to the iconic individual he portrays.  Another standout is Tommy Lee Jones as Republican leader Thaddeus Stevens of Pennsylvania.  An ardent abolitionist, Stevens clashed violently with members of the pro-slavery faction during heated debates on the floor of the House.  The rest of the cast, including David Strathairn, James Spader, Hal Holbrook, and Joseph Gordon-Levitt, acquit themselves well, although Sally Field's depiction of Mary Todd Lincoln could have been more subtle."Lincoln," as political pundit David Brooks wrote recently, reveals the dirty, nasty, and practical side of politics.  In a democracy, there is never a universal consensus regarding controversial issues.  So how do we avoid gridlock?  Savvy presidents try to curry favor among their opponents, twist arms, and make deals.  Goodwin praises Lincoln for reaching out to his rivals and doing what was necessary to bring warring factions together.  He refused to stand on ceremony, since the window of opportunity to get the Thirteenth Amendment passed was rapidly closing.Although "Lincoln" is an enlightening reenactment of a pivotal moment in American history, the film is long (two and a half hours) and talky.  There are brief scenes in which union and rebel soldiers fight to the death, Lincoln visits and consoles the wounded, and the President takes a somber tour of a bloody battlefield.  Aside from these interludes, most of "Lincoln" consists of men arguing about the pros and cons of slavery, the amendment's chances of passage, and how to extract votes from the holdouts.  This does not make for engrossing and fast-paced cinema.Janusz Kaminski's photography is effective, but Tony Kushner's script is sluggishly paced and John William's score is florid and intrusive.  "Lincoln" fails the "watch test."  When I sit in a theater, if I glance at my watch more than three times, wondering how much longer the movie will run, that is not a good sign.  Nevertheless, seeing Daniel Day Lewis take command in such an inspiring role is worth the price of admission.  "Lincoln" provides a reality check for those who naively believe that running a national government, especially during wartime, is anything but messy and nerve-racking.  "Lincoln" earns three and a half stars, raised to four for Daniel Day Lewis's stunning performance.

reviewText: To say that Daniel Day-Lewis inhabits the title role feels like such a total understatement. The iconic role has been the career-peaking touchstone for dozens of esteemed actors since the dawn of cinema including Henry Fonda, Raymond Massey (who earned an Oscar nomination in 1940 for his Lincoln), Gregory Peck, and even cast member Hal Holbrook (who plays Republican leader Francis Preston Blair here), but none have come across with the deceptively casual verisimilitude of Day-Lewis in Steven Spielberg's masterful 2012 historical drama. The versatile actor is able to bring multiple layers of human dimension to a public figure known to us only through books, marble statues, or perhaps a childhood trip to Disneyland where he remains an animatronic mannequin in "Great Moments with Mr. Lincoln". Spielberg and screenwriter Tony Kushner (Angels in America) wisely do not attempt an episodic treatment of Lincoln's life but rather focus on January 1865, a critical month at the beginning of the President's second term when he was undergoing the most important event of his life.Based in part on Doris Kearns Goodwin's superb treatise,Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln, the 150-minute film focuses on the conundrum he faced in pushing the 13th amendment, the abolition of slavery, through the House of Representatives toward legislation while facing immense pressure among all factions to end the now-four-year-old Civil War and reclaim the Confederacy into the Union. The movie's deliberately narrow focus allows us to see Lincoln as a relatable human being, someone with a determined sense of mission but also less than ideal with a surprising albeit understandable streak of opportunism that a broader biopic would have glossed over. It also means the story consists of subtle moments rather than milestone events that would signal the next historical battle. Although Spielberg bookends the film with unblinking scenes of carnage true to the period, the film relies primarily on the human drama that comes from the argument of opposing ideas and the minutiae of political strategy used to win favor among influential politicosIt's a story that has obvious relevance to the Washington political scene of today. The movie also examines the additional burden Lincoln was experiencing with his fractious home life. He struggles to keep the peace with his tempestuous wife Mary still grieving over the death of their third son Willie three years earlier, as well as their first-born Robert who becomes desperate to enlist in the Union Army against his parents' wishes. Kushner's superbly understated screenplay lets the plotlines intertwine organically and keeps Spielberg's tendency toward bravura filmmaking in check. Only toward the end when we recognize what is about to happen to Lincoln did I feel Spielberg's use of unspoken prescience a bit too heightened. The performances are stunning examples of what great filmmaking can generate with the right cast. Day-Lewis' Lincoln is for the ages. It amazes me that Liam Neeson was attached to the project for six years before generously abandoning it because Day-Lewis appears born to play the role. With a choked Midwestern tenor, he vividly evokes a man gifted at conflict resolution and oratory splendor but not above manipulating information to achieve the greater good.Two other performances are nearly as stellar. Tommy Lee Jones hones in on his particular brand of irascibility to bring fiery abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens to life, and Kushner gives him the lion's share of clever vitriol in the script. As Mary, Sally Field is a constant presence but has probably about three showy scenes where she is able to show her considerable talent to the full. Nearly a half-century sinceGidgetand more than a decade older than Day-Lewis, this diminutive actress gained 25 pounds and defies the odds by immersing herself completely into all the conflicting impulses that made Mary such a complicated, controversial historical figure. There are five Oscars among this accomplished trio, and more could very well be forthcoming. Many other actors in the expansive cast are worthy of mention, including James Spader's surprisingly amusing turn as a Republican lobbyist, Hal Holbrook's avuncular bluster as Blair, Gloria Reuben's quiet fortitude as Mary's confidant Elizabeth Keckley, and David Straitharn providing a jittery voice of reason as Secretary of State William Seward. A few actors like the omnipresent Joseph Gordon-Levitt as Robert are not given enough time to flesh out their characters. Regardless, it's a masterful film that captures lightning in a bottle.
summary: Masterful Filmmaking and a Stellar Cast Capture Lincoln During One Pivotal Month

reviewText: Many people, in reviewing this movie at various forums (but not here for some reason) claimed to be "bored" and not "entertained" by Spielberg's Lincoln.But the film's "boring" pace is precisely its greatness. It should be compared to Terence Malick's WWII film "The Thin Red Line" which came out at the same time as Spielberg's "Saving Private Ryan"; many people, who considered themselves mainstream politically or conservative, disliked The Thin Red Line (and liked Ryan)) because like Lincoln, The Thin Red Line didn't pander to expectations; the exciting shots of landing craft racing towards the beach in the beginning of The Thin Red Line failed to be followed by a fight as expected. Interestingly, the audience in The Thin Red Line may be said to be ravening for the blood of images of men who could be their grandfathers while the men who could be their grandfathers are relieved that the Japanese have cleared the beach.Lincoln is "about" the last months of the war when it was at once necessary and Constitutional if containing some chicanery to get a 13th (antislavery) amendment passed before a Union victory. It was necessary to do so because if Lincoln had waited until peace, the reconstructed Southern congress could pass an anti-antislavery amendment which would be a serious violation of the "states' rights" of NORTHERN states who sought to ban all manifestations of slavery within their borders...including the site of slave "coffles": escaped slaves and even freedmen, who'd found sanctuary in a free state like Dred Scott, being sent, in chains, in a FREE state, back to their slave state. This itself shows that Southroners didn't give a damn about "states' rights" because they refused to acknowledge the right of Nothern states not to have to accommodate the slave coffles.Lincoln, having grown up in an Ohio valley where blacks lived in fear despite living in free states, was determined to effectively end slavery by passing a Constitutional amendment, revocable only by supermajorities, that would discourage a reconstructed Congress from trying to re-enable slavery through ordinary legislation, and the viewer of the movie, DVD or BluRay needs to understand this. Otherwise he or she will be "bored".
summary: As boring as it should be

reviewText: Steven Spielberg seems to fluctuate between the serious ("Schindler's List") and the silly, such as "War of the Worlds", but in his new feature "Lincoln" he has come down to earth to present a realistic depiction of the 16th President during his last four months. Lincoln, with his skeletal physique (it has been suggested he had Marfan's Syndrome) and his reedy voice, was not the most elegant President we ever had, but historians believe he was one of the most powerful. Tony Kushner's screenplay presents him unglamorously but at the same time reveals the unusually strong character and the brilliant mind behind the gentle demeanor and the rural, sometimes long-winded anecdotes (not completely appreciated by all his cabinet members, the scenario makes clear). The picture doesn't open too promisingly, an obligatory battle scene, followed by Union soldiers quoting the Gettysburg Address from memory -- to its author! And as the story progresses, and Lincoln is determined to make his Emancipation Proclamation an amendment to the Constitution (it eventually took effect in late 1865) there are long scenes of conversations and confrontations in gloomy rooms, not exactly the type of thing to keep an average action-flick fan spellbound. (Regarding that gloom: viewers living in the 21st Century may have difficulty understanding how dark interiors were prior to the installation of electricity.) But Spielberg keeps things tense, partly by wisely  choosing Daniel Day-Lewis, probably the best film actor of his generation, to play the title role and having an array of excellent character actors -- Hal Holbrook, David Strathairn, Jackie Earl Haley, et al -- to support him. The huge creative team of "Lincoln"  has worked hard to make the political story approachable for general audiences (it's rated PG-13 not only for its mature conflicts but for the harrowing scene in which amputated arms and legs are dumped into a trench outside a military hospital) and also to guide the movie away from clichés; for instance, the  assassination is not shown at Ford's Theater but is announced in front of the curtain at a theater where the President's son Tad is enjoying a pantomime. Altogether Kushner's script, along with Spielberg's direction and the cinematography by Janusz Kamiński (a great deal of it based on vintage photographs) bring Lincoln's world vividly to life. But feminists should be aware it's a very masculine world, scene after scene populated solely by men; and when it's suggested in session that women may someday have the right to vote, the whole chamber rears up, howling with horror.

reviewText: "Lincoln" seems to be a slow start but rapidly picks up momentum of a man trying to end the bloodshed of a Civil War and add a 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution before the South surrenders and is readmitted to the Union. Does President Lincoln negotiate their surrender now, saving countless lives, but also guaranteeing that a represented South will surely kill any chances of the passage of the amendment, an amendment that abolishes slavery? What President Abraham Lincoln doesn't know is that he is in a race against time because this film takes place in the last few months of his life.In order to get the amendment passed in the House of Representatives, the president must get the votes. We witness horse-trading, deceit and intrigues at its finest or ugliest, to get the two thirds majority required for the next step in the process.Daniel-Day Louis is in the title role and wins an Oscar for his performance. He offers us the same high voice that Abraham Lincoln was reported to have. He frequently reverts to his folksy charm during serious or heated discussions with a story or anecdote. He is an adoring father to both his sons, but especially the younger Tad who in real life had a cleft palate that was so bad his food had to be specially prepared so he could chew it.Steven Spielberg gave us many more superb performances from Sally Field as the bi-polar Mary Todd Lincoln, the 16th president's wife. Often seen but still under-rated David Strathairn plays his politically-savvy Secretary of State William Seward. Bruce McGill plays Edwin M. Stanton, Secretary of War, and has one of the most memorable lines in the film: "No, you, you're not going to tell another story," as he stalks off out of earshot of a Lincoln yarn. This ensemble cast continued with Tommy Lee Jones as Congressman Thaddeus Stevens, a staunch abolitionist from Pennsylvania. Hal Holbrook plays a Republican politico who tries to end the war.What you get from Steven Spielberg's direction is attention to detail, right down to the White House wallpaper. You also get extra, perhaps too much extra. Critics say that the film's ending would have been better if we just saw Lincoln walking down the hall, on his way to Ford's Theater. If that had been it, we wouldn't have seen Todd Lincoln scream when a man announces to the audience that the president was shot. The final scene of revisiting Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address added little to the film.Still, you get the two most important events that make a great story, a taut, intelligent script delivered by unparalleled acting.P.S. This movie is history which always drives me to find more, and my focus was on Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones' character), representative from Pennsylvania.  He was living with his black housekeeper for a number of years. He adopted her sons, and offered her a choice of $5,000 in one lump sum, or $500 a year for ten years in his Will. When he died his body was placed in the Capitol Rotunda where he had a black honor guard. 40,000 mourners came to pay their respects; 20,000 were black. He chose to be buried in a cemetery that would not discriminate against the souls buried there.

reviewText: I have no idea why this was an academy award nominated movie. The reason must be the reverence many have for Lincoln as a major figure in American history and the anti-slavery issue/message. The dialogue was tedious and preachy nearly in every line spoken by Lincoln in this film. I wish I had spent my money and time watching something else. If Lincon was actually like this portrayal, it is very hard for me to understand why he was portrayed as so popular.  This was an anachronistic interpretation of Lincoln. The portrayal is of congress as a doing nothing body, divided along strict party/ideological lines opposed to a President who is only trying to do what is "the right thing to do." A president who uses 'speeches' or talking to folks as his style of leadership. This has way too much flavor of what is going on here now in American politics.  This film seems bent on pushing certain current political views, rather than telling the truth or providing an accurate film portrait of the man in history.
