reviewText: LINCOLN (Dir. Steven Spielberg, 2013, 150 minutes), it cannot ever be overlooked, is primarily the story about this nation's titanic struggle to pass the 13th Amendment abolishing slavery and indentured servitude. That is so salient a fact that President Lincoln (Daniel Day Lewis) seemed to be one of the lesser "strugglers". He came to struggle even more, due in no small part to his wife Mary Todd Lincoln (Sally Fields).In this beautifully, darkly and tightly shot film, Spielberg never lets us forget that subject matter - he can ill afford it. The score by John Williams being one of the high marks (and one of his personal high-water marks) of this beautiful classic, I cannot fathom its dreadful loss at the Oscars. What can one say to that? Spielberg has undoubtedly achieved his finest film ever. Therefore, much to my relief, I will not rehearse for my review the entire stunning cast, all of whom are acting at 110%.However, I plan to grouse a bit ....The first problem you'll notice is that you either need to keep the history books at hand or be a Civil War expert just to follow the characters in this film. The storyline/plot, well, those are known history, and there's where the film gets educational, fun and interesting. Being blessed with that historical knowledge, I found I could barely keep up with the characters I was seeing. It's tough going at certain moments, and the anachronistic swearing, while hilarious as all get-out, was of little help.THE VERY BAD: There are more than a few complaints I have, as a Lincoln historian, about the Lewis interpretation of Abraham Lincoln - which I can only describe as either bad acting or just plain "sick". This film was based on the bookTeam of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln(one of President Barack Obama's favorite books), but I have never wholly agreed with that scholarly lady's view of Lincoln or of the behavior of the team that surrounded him in his Cabinet. They're an abominable and rude bunch, which I doubt was ever the true atmosphere at the White House or the Telegraph Office. Spielberg made the error of allowing the jungle that still is the House of Representatives spill over into the president's lap.Secondly, I have very fresh bones to pick with Lewis. In Lewis I see an essentially cold, cunning and calculating politician in the guise of President Lincoln. His voice was high-pitched and irritating, to be sure, but Lewis makes him sound as if he came down from the wilds of Minnesota - nowhere near either Kentucky, Illinois or Indiana; this in the face of Lewis' proclamation that he gave Lincoln "a Kentucky accent".What he did was give Walter Brennan's voice to Lincoln, and that is unforgivable because it's what I call an 'actor's cop-out'. Worse, Lewis' Lincoln is cruel, to Mary and their eldest son, galactically rude to everyday people he encounters, and at one point in the film shrieks at his Cabinet about how he is "clothed in immense power". Folks, Lincoln shrieked that phrase becuase he knew he was NOT so clothed. Spielberg, or perhaps Lewis, just keep getting it wrong. None of the Lincoln scenes represents Lincoln quite rightly.That is because, aside from being a truly humble, lovable and nice man who was sad and often angry, he was, as Rep. Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones) puts it, "the purest man in America". Spielberg missed his target by avoiding the sad, pathetic Lincoln who at worst could be described as a 'vacillating Hamlet'-type figure.Whether burdened by the history, himself, Spielberg, the role or the film, Lewis fails badly all around - I do not even like him for trying because he tried THIS. Lewis seems to me to be catching at various performances of the past, and doing it badly. The physical match and perfection of the makeups is no substitute for a good actor: just look at Hal Holbrook or Sam Waterston in their old portrayals of Lincoln.All this reduces my estimation for this film, personally and deeply. However, it does not blind me to the essential need for this film. Its importance may only be marred by Spielberg's insistence on anachronistic swearing, which begins at a lusty pace sometime just before the midway mark. That rules out this film as a good family film. I thought Spielberg was pushing it with his opening scene of up-close brutality of hand-to-hand combat. But his insistence on one character habitually utilizing the f-word was just stupid.As if I cannot proclaim it enough: I think it was a gross error to cast Lewis in this, and the role ought to have gone to the original star for which it was intended: Liam Neeson, who finally begged off, pleading age, after a decade of waiting for the phone call. Imagine the difference that would have made.THE STUNNING: This film shows us the birth not only of the original liberal party (Republican) but also the birth of lobbyism and lobbyists. Seward (David Strathairn at his level best), at the behest of Lincoln and with his blessing, hires three lobbyists to get lamed reps to agree to vote for Abolition. The historical hilarity that ensues from this, what I call "Seward's Greek Chorus" as indeed they are in this film, well, it's priceless.The best humor comes from these three clownish men, and all I can do is direct you generally to the scenes: the lobster meal they have with Seward, the attempt of one lobbyist (a BRILLIANT James Spader) to win over a murderous representative, and of course their running commentary at certain moments in the House. With reservations, I do give Lewis high marks for relaxing into the role enough to tell a dirty joke with tremendous effectiveness.Such funny moments are balanced by the tear-inducing drama of some of Lincoln's scenes, such as his late-night conversation with Mrs. Keckley on the portico. In another scene when Mary says, "My head hurts," I wept. These are the moments that prove Spielberg and his actors haven't lost their touch!In spite of its flaws, it is a film I cannot fail to own, and will own as soon as my budget allows. You would be insane to pass it up, not to have a place for it on your top DVD shelf. If it interests you, I recommend you acquire the old TV miniseriesGore Vidal's Lincoln(see my review) and see how Sam Waterston, my absolute favorite, holds up to Lewis, who is among the least of my favorite actors.REVIEWER'S NOTES: 1) I read NO reviews of this film at all and still have not; 2) I cannot understand the remarks I have heard that this was a claustrophobic film. Spielberg was trying to convey the early Victorian intimacy but he also wanted to convey the very realistic fact of President Lincoln-as-prisoner.That's all!
summary: Two men I love are here: Lincoln and Spielberg

We all know he was shot in a theater but it would have been better if we had seen his final moments and what he may have been thinking but you just hear of his death, you don't witness it and the reaction after is short. reviewText: I was excited and a little nervous goin in to Lincoln... tried to stay away from other reviews so I would go in 'blind' so to speak:) still heard wonderful things in general about the film... really relieved my theater got it (though I would driven an hour or two just to see it)'Lincoln' was beyond amazing... Words can't describe this film enough, Daniel Day Lewis disappears into the role, I really felt like I was getting a glimpse into Abraham Lincoln, the man.. An ordinary yet remarkable person.. If you see one good film before year's end...see this:)You can tell each person was chosen with care for their role and that this was a project of love for the Director :) It feels like you are transported back to 1865, not as on outsider but as a participant/observer... even though I knew the outcome, I was still biting my lips, and on the edge of my seat at times.You can  see how the burden of what's going on weighs on everyone, and the inner conflicts they face... who knows how a lesser man would've handled what Lincoln did?Daniel Day Lewis does an exquisite job of bringing this ordinary/complex/extraordinary man to life.. you forget about the actor completely after just a few minutes... Sally field is well-matched with him as Mrs. Lincoln... you weep with them, feel their frustration,and rejoice with them when the Ammendment is past (i was fighting happy tears myself)..I say again: Absolutely brilliant, well thought-out film... a slice of history brought to life at the right time...in the film, Lincoln wonders if (to paraphrase) if we are fit to the times we're born in... one of the Soldiers tells him he thinks he is, and I would have to agreeAs you see the dates countdown to when the war ends/ammendment passes/the assasination date... my heart squeezed when I saw and heard him speak about what he wanted to accomplish, the night he left for Ford's Theater... not knowing he only had hours left to live *bows head for a few moments*the end of the film, not to spoil anything... is very fitting, and the score wasn't overwhelming.. compliments the film nicely.can't recommend it enough... go see it if you are able, you won't regret it:) I'm defintely gonna try for a repeat viewingnot an expert reviewer or expert in political stuff hehe, but here's my humble opinion :)

reviewText: Profiles in Leadership: From Caesar to Modern TimesThere have been many movies about Abraham Lincoln.  This is one of the best in terms of giving us a portrayal of Lincoln the person, the personality, the challenges and the times.  The acting, the setting, the scenery, the people and the political atmosphere are splendid.  The direction, of course, is marvelous.We get a feel for who Abraham Lincoln really was an individual, a leader and why he was our greatest President.  For those who wish a longer, more detailed and even more compelling portrait, I suggest the Lincoln Mini Series starring Hal Holbrook.  I believe the Mini may be the finest of all the bio films done on Lincoln.  That being said, I strongly recommend the latest Lincoln without question or reservation.Emilio Iodice, author of Profiles in Leadership from Caesar to Modern Times, North American Business Press, 2013.

reviewText: I'd wanted to watch this movie for a long time. I thought I'd love it. I love Spielberg and his knack for telling history. I love history. But I found that while I like and enjoy this movie, I didn't quite love it.Maybe Lincoln is too iconic a figure, but Daniel Day Lewis never quite seemed to fit the man's admittedly large shoes. I think he's got the looks down, but the voice is a bit to light for me. Maybe it's historically accurate, but nothing about the voice says "authoritative" to me. Sometimes this works to actually humanize Lincoln a bit better. It's nice to see our greatest president depicted as human and not a myth. Lincoln does some very human things in the movie.Many have complained that the film is slow. While I normally have no patience for the movie tastes of today's ADD/hyperactivity generation, I do think there's something to this. I think part of the problem is that the film often seems to be going from one "HUGELY IMPORTANT SIGNIFICANT MOMENT" to the next. Whether it's Lincoln telling yet another story or Stevens speaking in Congress, it feels like every moment is drawn out and important. Individually, many of the scenes are really worth taking in. But together the viewer gets the sense that the movie is going nowhere fast. There are no scenes of frantic bustling in the House of Representatives to give the impression of the passage of time or things getting done. Rather, we hear the vote of nearly every single representative on the amendment, which was a bit much. In short, it's slowness without substance.The movie was adapted from a book (Doris Kearns Goodwin's famous "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln") and it shows. There are dozens of smaller scenes scattered throughout the movie with little to no context. One of Lincoln's sons, Robert, went off to enlist in the war. We never got to know him beforehand, but it's made into a big deal. Then, afterwards, we never see him again. It seems like Spielberg thought it was an interesting scene but it doesn't fit with the story and never gets introduced or resolved. There are a few other scenes, such as the assassination and Lincoln's inaugural, that really have little to do with the passage of the 13th amendment. I'd say this movie could have been streamlined into a much tighter and more compelling story.Again, I really like this movie. It works more often than not. But I can also understand how it didn't win best movie Oscar for 2013.
summary: slow pace and uneven, but brings Lincoln to life

reviewText: Some may point out minor historical inaccuracies, but this film is still a remarkable achievement for how marvelously it humanizes the historical giant that is Abraham Lincoln. The weight and responsibility that pressed down on this great man is portrayed magnificently, and no matter what one thinks of the choices he made, one recognizes the gravity and severity of the situation he was placed. Needless to say, Daniel Day-Lewis' performance is simply incredible, bringing genuine life and feeling to a person we know simply as a marble statue in D.C. Lincoln is a monumental film precisely because Steven Spielberg chooses *not* to portray Lincoln as a legendary figure, but rather as simply a moral man who rose to the challenge that the evil of slavery presented, in a time (like any time) when moral men would prefer to stay seated. "Lincoln" presents a portrait of a man who did what is right the best that he could as he saw it, which is more than what most of us can say, and for that beautiful and inspiring picture, I salute and thank Mr. Spielberg and Mr. Day-Lewis.

reviewText: In the age of film and television there have been many movies and miniseries about the Civil War period.  One of the best appeared in 2012, when "Lincoln" garnered wide acclaim--it recalled the sixteenth president's successful effort to get the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution successfully through the House of Representatives.While the film portrays the fight to pass the most important bill to move through Congress in American history, those who follow politics closely will recognize issues raised by the film that are common to politics in all ages on all types of issues:  friction between the president and Congress, debate in the White House over when the most propitious time to send legislation to the floor would be, soul-searching that legislators must do on when to stand firmly on principle and when (and to what degree) to trim their sails to forward their ideals to (hopefully) the greatest degree.  "Lincoln" also portrays the pressures from all different directions, including family members, with which a president must deal.Daniel Day-Lewis took home the Academy Award for Best Actor for his performance (the film was nominated for a dozen Oscars), and the cast included other big names such as Sally Field and Tommy Lee Jones.  The cinematography is a credible re-creation of mid-nineteenth century Washington.  There are a couple of harrowing scenes that would not be appropriate for younger children, but "Lincoln" is a must-view for all history geeks from high-school age onward.
summary: The End of Slavery in the United States

reviewText: Steven Spielberg is one of THE notable directors. His movies may not always be perfect but they're all worth watching. This may very well be his best effort.Here's the scoop. The Civil War is dragging on into its fourth year. Lincoln wants to both end the war and pass the 13th amendment freeing the slaves. More than one person has told him he cannot do both. Accomplishing one will scuttle the other. He pulls out all stops to prove them wrong.This is a remarkable effort. Whatever great things you've heard about it from paid reviewers are all true. Daniel Day-Lewis is unbelievable. I didn't feel as though I were watching an actor. I felt as though I were watching Lincoln resurrected. The rest of the cast is outstanding as well. James Spader, as W.N. Bilbo is a real hoot. The character was written well and he plays him up in spades. Sally Field, as Mary Todd-Lincoln, is as good as she's ever been. But I cannot single these few out. Everyone did a great job. What I liked most was that this wasn't a biography of the man. It showed him at a specific time, performing a specific task so you got to see him as a man as well as a great politician.The production was top shelf. Costumes, hair styles, sets all transported me back to that time and place. I wasn't watching a movie. I was looking through a time portal. All the top people involved in this film have all worked together with Spielberg in other films but they all reinvented themselves here. This is not like earlier Spielberg films.I cannot say enough about this so I might as well stop now. One might have a minor quibble about this or that in the film but it is about as good as a movie can be. So if you are at all disposed toward period dramas this will give you the thrill of a lifetime.
summary: A Whole New Level for Spielberg

reviewText: Given the difficulties of America in the 21st century, it is oftentimes difficult to remember that America has faced much more challenging and much more tragic circumstances throughout its history.  The biggest challenge America ever faced was not a war for freedom in some faraway part of the world, but a war for freedom on its own soil.  The Civil War, in which Southern states split off from the rest of the Union over the issue of whether African-Americans should remain enslaved, tore America apart between 1861 and 1865; and only one man was able to settle the issue.  That man was Abraham Lincoln, our nation's 16th president.  The last three months of Lincoln's life, in which he managed to accomplish so much only to have it end in his assassination, is what is detailed in LINCOLN, director Steven Spielberg's impassioned and highly involved American epic.Stepping into the shoes of "Honest Abe" is English actor Daniel Day-Lewis, who essays a Lincoln not as we thought we knew him, with a stentorian manner of speaking, but a high, reedy-voiced man reflecting his origins in Kentucky and Illinois whose word nevertheless carried considerable gravitas, even as he presided over the messiest conflict America would ever see.  Not only does Day-Lewis preside over the immense task, after having won a second term in office, of trying to end that conflict, but also to resolve once and for all the issue of slavery by the ratification of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution.  Making things worse for Day-Lewis, even members of his own cabinet, including Secretary of State William Seward (David Strathairn) are torn on the issue of compromise with ending the Civil War and passing the amendment with the required two-thirds majority needed in the House of Representatives.  The task for Lincoln thus falls in no small measure on two prominent Northern politicians, Preston Blair (Hal Holbrook) and Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones), to not only keep his Republican majority in line, but also to cause twenty Democrats to defect from the hard line of keeping slavery in place, come hell or high water.  The debate in the House, particularly with Jones commanding so much attention, is as bitter and rancorous as any we've seen in our modern era; and the final vote is 119-56 (with eight abstentions, it is just enough to allow the 13th Amendment to pass).  In the end, Day-Lewis visits many of the Civil War battle sites and reflects, in the days before his violent demise, the cost of war and the battle of ideals.Spielberg had handled great American historical issues and eras before in such films as THE COLOR PURPLE, AMISTAD, and SAVING PRIVATE RYAN, but LINCOLN was clearly a personal obsession for him; indeed, this project was twelve years in the making.  And while he may not have been that much of a history buff either in grade school, high school, or while briefly a student at Long Beach State in the late 1960s, he nevertheless developed a taste for it throughout his career.  The impact of the Holocaust as shown in SCHINDLER'S LIST is what almost certainly fired his imagination, to understand the why of that tragedy; and in LINCOLN, he does very much the same thing, in illustrating why Lincoln was so important to America, not only of his time, but of all time, leading up to the 2008 election of our nation's first African-American president.  And here, he allows Day-Lewis to give a portrait of Lincoln that rates right up there with Henry Fonda's portrayal in John Ford's 1938 film YOUNG MR, LINCOLN, and Gregory Peck's in the epic 1982 TV miniseries THE BLUE AND THE GRAY.  Sally Field is also superlative as his wife Mary Lincoln; and Holbrook and Jones, seasoned veterans both, are excellent as the men fighting the good fight.The usual excellent score by John Williams (with some period music thrown in) and the cinematography by Spielberg's usual DP Janusz Kaminski, along with the performances, make this 149 minute-long epic extremely breathless; and Tony Kushner's fine screenplay (based on Doris Kearns Goodwin's book "Team Of Rivals"), gives the cast and Spielberg plenty to work with.  As LINCOLN proves once again, Spielberg is a director capable of bringing the most difficult subject matter to dramatic life and understanding more about ourselves as human beings and as a nation at large.  Great filmmaking does that, and, without question, LINCOLN is an example of great filmmaking, certainly one of the great films of 2012.

reviewText: I've been fascinated by Abraham Lincoln my entire life. I'm sure it has to do with the fact that he was assassinated and there's quite a bit of mystery and intrigue surrounding his presidency and personal life. He did so much in his terms in office and changed our nation for the better while overcoming all sorts of political opposition. I knew I would need to see Steven Spielberg's "Lincoln" as soon as it was announced in production."Lincoln" focuses on the man's obsession with getting the 13th Amendment pushed through Congress before the Civil War ended. Abe was honest, but would see his mission of obliterating slavery accomplished by any means necessary. His drive and the toll it took on his family life are explored in great detail.Director Steven Spielberg takes what could have been a disastrously boring two and a half hours of non-stop dialogue and somehow makes it engaging and tolerable. The success of the film is based around Spielberg's casting of Daniel Day-Lewis in the lead role. Day-Lewis owns every moment he's on screen and demands your attention with every word he speaks. He's merely the cherry on top of a brilliant and dedicated cast that includes James Spader, Tommy Lee Jones, Sally Fields, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, John Hawkes, David Strathairn, and many more.Although they only took up a few moments of screen time, the scenes of the Civil War battlefields bore a lasting impression on me. The savageness of hand-to-hand combat was hard to watch. These soldiers fought hand-to-hand, which made it more personal. It wasn't a faceless war like today's, where we just drop bombs on each other and never have direct contact with the people we're fighting."Lincoln's" high-definition audio and video transfer couldn't be any better. The picture gives viewers the best visual experience possible and highlights the extravagant set and costume designs. The 7.1 surround sound guarantees every uttered piece of dialogue, whispered or shouted, is heard over John Williams' incredible score. The battle scene is effectively chaotic, noisy, and nerve-wracking as well.There are two short featurettes included in the 2-Disc Blu-ray / DVD Combo Pack. Steven Spielberg and his team of filmmakers discuss the shooting location and making of the film in "The Journey to 'Lincoln'" and "A Historic Tapestry: Richmond, Virginia." They both clock in at about 13 minutes combined.The fact that I stayed awake through two and a half hours of talking is a true testament of how well-paced and captivating "Lincoln" is. I'm really not one for talky and long-winded movies, but Spielberg's devoted obsession with the historical figure and Janusz Kaminski's masterful cinematography make the movie stand out and demand your undivided attention. It's a movie that requires multiple viewings, as there is so much being said so quickly that you're guaranteed to miss something important.

reviewerName: Fabulinus "To err is human. To forgive for no...
reviewText: When I saw the previews for "Lincoln" and found out that Steven Spielberg was producing and directing it, I knew I would be in for a treat.  What I didn't know was how much of one.This movie was magnificent.  I've not seen anything like it in years.  There's so much to like... the acting was exceptional (by all!), the set and costume design were top notch, the musical score (by none other than the brilliant John Williams) was beautiful and the dialog was clever/wonderful.  The film is based on the book "Team of Rivals:  The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln" by author, historian and Pulitzer-Prize winner Doris Kearns Goodwin who has chronicled the political lives of other past American Presidents.  Essentially, "Lincoln" is about the passage of the 13th Amendment (after the Emancipation Proclamation had already passed and he had been re-elected) and how difficult it was for President Lincoln to get members of his party and even of his cabinet to pass it.  Clearly some artistic liberty had to be taken with various parts of the movie's dialogue, but the House of Representatives dialog where many of its members would publicly stand to address each other and the issues at hand must have been accurate due to the reporters in the chamber!  The reporters were the public record keepers writing down the words of the congressmen and publishing them in all of the popular and well regarded newspapers of the day which are probably available  (perhaps at the Library of Congress?) for public viewing.I don't know what other movies will be competing for movie of the year or who will be competing for Oscars with Daniel Day Lewis and Tommy Lee Jones, but I sure hope this movie wins big.  See this.  You will not be disappointed!!
summary: A New Classic That Will Live Forever - Beautifully Done!!

reviewText: This will be a very brief review. Steven Spielberg was obviously Oscar-hungry during the production of Lincoln. This film is a horribly wasted opportunity to shed light on one of America's most interesting presidents in one of America's most turbulent of times. Instead of showcasing something honest, gripping, or even titillating, Spielberg uses this time to cater to the already initiated ranks of the most rigidly corrupt brotherhood in all of art, The Academy Of Motion Picture Arts And Sciences. I'm not sure if Spielberg ever had a brave bone in his body, but after watching Lincoln, I wonder if he even has a soul. Lincoln is a soulless film. It is very difficult to make a film that deals with all of the interesting historical events that Lincoln is centered around boring, but Spielberg seems to do that effortlessly. What's more, Daniel Day Lewis churns out a boring and half-hearted performance, as do most of the actors in the piece! Its as if Lincoln was made by a half-interested company for a built in audience that were completely uninterested in fanciful concepts like intimacy, empathy, and courage.Lincoln is not a film, it is an instructional video for all future hack-job directors on how to make a movie about something as multi-faceted as the presidency of Abraham Lincoln seem watered-down, hokey, and as accessible to as many people as possible. Ken Burns should have been an adviser on the film in some capacity, as he seems to know a thing or two about intimacy and courage. Spielberg never tried to give us anything more than the bare minimum the Academy required of him. He didn't even try to give us one actually fleshed out and interesting character. I know he can take a historical event and present it in a brave and intimate way, how Spielberg treated Schindler's List is a great example of what I'm talking about. Spielberg made a brave film then, not just something the Academy wanted, but something that he wanted. He didn't even try to that with Lincoln, he didn't even try...
summary: Blame The Captain Of The Ship

reviewText: Since the day a tyrant's bullet took him from our nation, Abraham Lincoln has been immortalized by a wide variety of mediums - ranging from one very impressive marble statue to countless impersonations, not to mention several films and television portrayals.  Because of the Lincoln myths, he is one of our America's most recognizable faces and is arguably the most important president in the history of the United States.  More books have been written about Abraham Lincoln than anyone other president, and still to this day authors and historians continue to make discoveries about The Great Emancipator.Discoveries aside, it's also fun to emulate visions of Lincoln as more than just a man - but also a superhero. In Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, he is portrayed as the man that freed the slaves, as well as the man that helped defeat the vampires. However, on a more serious note, another recent film - The Conspirator tells the post assassination story of Mary Surratt, the first woman in American history to die by a hangman's noose just for being in the same house as John Wilkes Booth as he planned Lincoln's demise. So you see, it's not just Lincoln that's famous - it's anyone that's ever had anything to do with him.  And, now that Steven Spielberg and Daniel Day-Lewis have decided to show us their take on Mr. Lincoln, they will most likely go down in history as the two men that gave us the best interpretation of the 16th president to date - in the 2012 film, Lincoln.Steven Spielberg directs Lincoln, based on Doris Kearns Goodwin's book, Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln, which gives a condensed version of the months leading up the vote on the 13th Amendment - a vote to abolish slavery.  Abraham Lincoln (Daniel Day-Lewis) is only a few months into his second term as the Civil War winds to a close, but the issue of slavery is still front and center.  President Lincoln pushes his cabinet to find the votes in the House of Representatives to add an amendment to the constitution, putting an end to slavery once and for all.  Back door dealings, personal loss, and family turmoil are the backdrops as Lincoln struggles with some of the most stressful months in American history.Already earning him several prestigious awards, including a Golden Globe for Best Actor in a drama for his portrayal in Lincoln, Daniel Day-Lewis will most likely also earn himself another Academy Award for Best Actor.  After years of studying Abraham Lincoln, Spielberg went to great lengths to make this film one of the most realistic portrayal of Lincoln to date, including creating some of the most elaborate settings that cinema has ever seen.  This film is meant to show an aged, run-down Lincoln during one of the most tumultuous periods in United States history.  And, who better to an actor than Daniel Day-Lewis for the role of Lincoln?  From his real-life high pitched voice, Day-Lewis does a spectacular job of showing Lincoln as a conflicted, yet melancholy man who refuses to give in to failure.  The future of the union rested on one man's shoulders - a future destined to end in greatness, and tragedy.Top to bottom, Lincoln's cast is an absolute marvel.  Sally Field gives an Oscar-worthy portrayal of Mary Todd Lincoln, an overly depressed, angry woman dealing with her own inner demons.  After the loss of a child, Willy (not seen in the film) and her unwillingness to lose her oldest to the war, we are given our first real cinematic glimpse at the tragic downfall of Mary-Todd Lincoln, prior to the death of her husband.  Also starring in the film is Tommy Lee Jones as Thaddeus Stevens, an elder, radical Republican dead-set on abolishing slavery.  The role of Stevens has also garnered Jones a great deal of acclaim.  Jones' ability to steal a scene is masterful and it's quite possible he's Oscar-bound in the supporting actor category.  Joseph Gordon-Levitt (Robert Todd Lincoln), David Strathairn (William Seward), Hal Holbrook (Francis Preston Blair) and James Spader (Rep. William Biblo) also shine in their respective roles.As previously review when the film was initially released, it seemed the only downside about this film was the length of the film.  Running at an estimated 2 hours and 30 minutes, it can feel a whole lot longer than it is for anyone that doesn't have a heavy interest in Lincoln or history.  While this is a biographical film, it is not a film about Lincoln's entire life - and mainly focuses on the passage of the 13th Amendment.  The span of this film is only over a few months and certain scenes can feel like they drag more than others, however, the emotional payoff is well worth the wait.Overall, this is not a film for everyone - but it should at least been seen by everyone.  It is a superb work of art by Steven Spielberg and all of the actors involved.  Still, it doesn't qualify well for date night.  Yes, there will always be more entertaining films out there with more action, laughs, and crash scenes.  At the end of the day, Lincoln is about one man's dream for the direction of the United States.  It's about a man that suffers all his life through depression, but fought through it to reunite a nation.  This is a far more emotionally-charged and meaningful film that any other film in theaters.  Lincoln comes HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for Spielberg fans, history buffs, and Lincoln enthusiasts - and should be seen by everyone at least once, especially the young person sitting in classrooms right now.Overall Film Grade:  A+FNDNreview.com

reviewText: I have watched this movie twice, have read Doris Kearns Goodwin's book, and have gone to law school, and I still found this movie to be confusing. There are too many characters, most of whom are not well-developed. The story of the Emancipation Proclamation and the Amendment to eliminate slavery is a central part of the American story. I would have told the Goodwin story of the rivals in Lincoln's Cabinet in more depth and I would have told the stories of the central men in the federal legislature in more depth. I would have shown the shame involved in the way slavery evolved in South. I would have explained the difference between Lincoln and those who believed that they had been forced to secede from the Union. Lincoln never believed that a secession from the Union had occurred.I was disappointed in the way the movie was structured. It was well-cast.
summary: This movie tries to cover too much and would have been better as a mini-series

Believe me, that had me holding on to the bannister at the movie theatre, praying to The Almighty that this would be the first and last of any excessive sentimentality in this film. I was really worried, believe you me.)At any rate, I'm happy to be on board now as a Spielberg fan. It was a long time coming.

reviewText: I liked the movie but I felt that the real legacy of Lincoln was overshadowed by another point. The movie focused a tremendous amount of dialogue and scenery to the legislative portion of the 13th amendment which abolished slavery in the Unites States. However, Lincoln's real legacy is that he fought to keep the union together. He staunchly refused any offer of truce or surrender that did not bring the southern states back into the union. His leadership in this conundrum of a civil war is the reason that the country as we know it exists today. He did many things during his tenure as the President of the United States and to focus so much on just one aspect of his presidency is superfluous and it really takes so much away from all the other great deeds that this man was responsible for.
summary: Good Movie about a great man in History.

reviewText: When I first saw it, I have to admit, I was put off by the high voice.  For some reason, I had it in my head that one of the most characteristic traits of Lincoln was his deep sonorous voice.How did I get that impression?  Grade school indoctrination, perhaps.  Perhaps envisioning those powerfully worded speeches being delivered simply cast them in an authoritatively deep voice in my mind.  Further research indicates that this tall, lanky man was indeed a tenor.So, I have to get past that, which is harder than it should be.But, I think even that superficial misperception underscores how difficult it is to really understand the uncertainties of that period of American history.  We can look back after it's all settled and nod our heads, but how it would all turn out was a much bigger question in the day it was happening.The portrayal focuses on the slavery issue, but the real issue to Lincoln was the preservation of the union, which he was willing to enforce at any cost - including suspending the constitution and ignoring the fact that the southern states had ratified the constitution only with the proviso that they could secede.  Slavery was secondary (he certainly was vehemently opposed to it), and was adopted enthusiastically late in the war - mainly as a propaganda to maintain public support for a conflict that had dragged out much longer and become much more vicious than anyone had anticipated.We like to think of the ultimate outcome of the war as the abolition of slavery, but perhaps a more pernicious outcome was centralization of power in the federal government - a centralization that has continued to expand to proportions that extend into almost every aspect of life, today, and has for all intents and purposes usurped the sovereignty of the states.  An expansion that is increasingly accepted and even desired by a population with much different expectations of the nature and role of government from that of the 1860's.The interaction between Lincoln and Mary is explored interestingly, but how accurately is anyone's guess.Bears more analysis, I think.

reviewText: LINCOLN is a film with brilliant performances, flawless art design, a stilted script, and an unimpressive plot.  It is akin to looking at dead flowers pressed in a book for two and a half hours.Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865) is arguably the greatest of the American presidents, but you get little sense of that from this 2012 Steven Spielberg film, which focuses very narrowly on the presidents determination to shepherd the thirteenth amendment through a polarized House of Representatives and thereby abolish slavery in the United States.  In consequence, the film consists of an endless array of political plots and counterplots, back room arm twisting, public bickering--most of it presented with a lack of interest that renders the film increasingly tedious.If the great failings are the script and direction, the great successes are in the performances.  The sparkling highlight of the film is a very unexpected performance by Sally Field as Mary Todd Lincoln.  I never questioned her performance, and although her screen time is limited, she conveys the complexities of this most complicated of first ladies beyond any possible skepticism.  In watching her performance, you never think of Sally Field playing Mary Todd Lincoln; you only think of Mary Todd Lincoln.  It is an astonishing achievement.  In contrast, the script significantly underserves Daniel Day-Lewis.  Although he has considerably more screen time than Field, he seems less complex than one expects, and while I never questioned his performance I often wished it had more scope.  The same is largely true of the rest of the cast, who seem hemmed in the constraints of the "let's pass the thirteenth amendment" story.In addition to its performances, the film is remarkable in terms of art direction.  It possesses an attention to visual detail that few other films have, from Mary Todd Lincoln's jet jewelry to Abraham Lincoln's inevitably unruly hair.  From fire light to candle light, from horse and buggy to battle weapons, you really feel that this is how it looked and sounded.  Unfortunately, this attention to detail is quite frequently undercut by the script, which has an unfortunate way of alternating between speech that sounds correct for 1865 and speech that sounds more like 2012.  It is an awkward amalgamation.  As for historical inaccuracy, I leave the battle to the experts--and, quite typically, none of them really agree.Bonuses depend on what version of the DVD you purchase.  The single disk version offers a making of documentary that is worth watching, but nothing more.  The elements are pristine.  But in the end, one has to ask: is this movie really worth watching?  My answer to that would be yes, but it is qualified yes.  It is a movie worth watching, certainly, but not necessarily a movie worth re-watching.  You may prefer to rent it than own it, for one viewing will likely be enough.GFT, Amazon Reviewer
summary: Brilliant Performances Undercut By Stilted Script

reviewText: Not when there are already dozens of reviews, some excellent, some abysmal. Not when the subject involves so many antecedents and complexities. I couldn't imagine doing the film, or myself, justice within the scope of a few hundred words. However, an amazon friend, a citizen of Germany working in China, has sent me a request to explain why I found this film so successful. Here's my answer, which I might as well share:"You might need to have spent some of your youth celebrating Lincoln's birthday, or noticing Lincoln's picture on the penny, or reading some of the pop boys' books about the War. You might need to have read Walt Whitman's Civil War poetry, especially "When Lilacs Last etc", and more than once. Lincoln is a powerful shamanic totemic figure in the American mind, and seeing him made human by DDL is like being told yes, there is a heaven for pets or yes any child can become president. But the film handles the assassination with the greatest cinematic subtlety. Of course I've know about the assassination in great detail all my reading life. Of course I know the Gettysburg Address by heart (though generations younger than I am probably don't). Well, there came that moment in the film when the capstone had been placed, when the passage of the 13th Amendment had been achieved -- and any blathering fool who still argues that "the War was not about slavery" should have his mouth taped shut as teachers used to do in the USA in 'the good old days' -- that moment when in effect Lincoln had become immortal morally, and at that moment I sat in the theater agonized by foreknowledge, horrified by anticipating the next scene, which could only be the assassination. Oh no! No! Not now! let the Glory wave a short while! I'm not a guy who cries in cinemas, but I couldn't stop myself from bawling as if a close friend or sib were dying in my arms. Lincoln's death became a personal tragedy for me, for the first brief time, at that moment in the film. My dry historical awareness of the tragedy will never be merely intellectual again. Wait! Not yet! Spare me the scene of his death! I WANT HIM TO LIVE!And the film did spare us. The indirect treatment of the assassination was superb, humane, decent film-making. Proof, I'd argue, that "less" is sometimes "more", that dispassion can be more poignant than blaring cinemascopic 3-D amped-up violence.Perhaps not everyone in the audience was as affected as I was. There are people who quibble with DDL's portrayal of Lincoln as insufficiently awesome. There are people who ardently despise Lincoln as a tyrant and desecrator of "our" Constitution. My response to the film was personal and private, linked to my own life experience in the Civil Rights movement. But that response was more intense than I expected when I bought my ticket. More intense than at any film I've seen in many years."
summary: I Didn't Plan to Write a Review ...

reviewText: All the accolades for Daniel Day-Lewis in his portrayal of Lincoln are well-deserved.  He really is as good as you've heard.  He completely transforms himself into Abraham Lincoln and captures the many sides of a complicated man and President.The film itself is quite engrossing - especially when you consider it is essentially a 2-and-a-half hour movie about Congressional vote wrangling (and one where the viewer already knows the final outcome).  Credit goes to screenwriter Kushner, who has managed to capture the import of the vote and the subtle ways in which Lincoln could cajole and arm-twist using his resolve, his humor, and his natural charisma.  After watching this you will really feel as if you know Lincoln the man better than you ever did through a history book, and that is high praise for any biographical film.My only quibble is with the ending.  The film ends just after Lincoln has been assassinated - I doubt that qualifies as a spoiler - and I wish there was a little more time devoted to this.  It is passed over so quickly that Lincoln's death has little emotional impact in the film... Instead there is a brief flashback of Lincoln delivering a speech, and then the movie fades to black. My suspicion is that Spielberg was trying to focus on his tremendous accomplishment in abolishing slavery, which would far outlive his mortal life and in a sense lessen the tragedy of his death.  I just felt that this great man's death deserved a little more import in the film, and it made the ending somewhat unsatisfying.At any rate it is an excellent film and definitely worth watching for Day-Lewis's amazing performance.

reviewText: LINCOLN is one of those films that defies anyone to say anything negative about it.  It seems that Steven Spielberg joining hands with the national hero Abraham Lincoln and the racial equality issue is a sacred marriage and to offer dissident views of the film as a film approaches sacrilege.The film is basically the last four months of Abraham Lincoln's life and the manner in which he struggled to end the war and pass the Thirteenth Amendment abolishing slavery only to be assassinated at Ford's theater For this viewer the strongest aspect of the film is Tony Kushner's magnificent script, a script that places words befitting the times in the mouths of the men and women surrounding the final days of the war and the contentious governmental debate about slavery.  It is pungent, poetic, inspiring, both raw and refined, and captures an era and a time in this country's history that will be difficult to match.Yes, the cast is strong - massively collected from among some of the finest actors in film today. Everyone has crowned the head of Daniel Day-Lewis for his portrayal of Lincoln and Sally Fields as his borderline adjusted wife Mary and Tommy Lee Jones as the acerbic and convincingly committed Thaddeus Stevens, but the others in the cast deserve listing: David Strathairn, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, James Spader, Hal Holbrook, Robert Latham, Bruce McGill, Tim Blake Nelson, Lee Pace, Boris McGiver, David Costabile, Stephen Spinella, Colman Domingo, David Oyelowo, Lukas Haas and on and on.The battle scenes are as atrocious as war is atrocious and the lighting and camera work throughout the film capture that dark period in our history magnificently. Doubtless the film will always be regarded as perfect, but for some it is overly long, occasionally pretentious, at times trying - but always rescued by Tony Kushner's fine screenplay adaptation of Doris Kearns Goodwin's novel `Team of Rivals'. Grady Harp, March 13
summary: `No one is loved as much as you by the people. Don't waste that power.'

reviewText: 'Lincoln' is a movie of inestimable worth.  Production values fill the screen from the first shot to the final frame.Forging a lasting work to be sustained in the multitude of films, books, videos, documentaries, docudramas, etc., that form the Lincoln canon is a challenge in itself.  Director Spielberg plays well to the task, knowing he will be expected, but even more, desiring through his love of film, to chronicle history that will be sustained.His choice of Day-Lewis for the rail-splitter becomes obviously inspired from the moment Daniel appears.  Preoccupation with the minutia of daily life was brilliantly captivating, giving one that marvelous perspective of being the famed 'fly-on-the-wall.'  Film aficionados will study this movie with relish.Day-Lewis' hunched-back, reedy colloquialisms framing perspectives from scholarly promontories distinguish the living portrait, hungering the audience for more.Stellar performances abound, dripping over one another like honey over cake.  That viewers are forced to demand if this or that was truly historical only hammers home the realities that were found.  Challenges to plumb the depths of historical documentation flower from such work as this.The telling marks of time well spent were first, this reviewer's fascination with the playing out of the movie.  The second would be the falling into quiet sleep of my wife after a very long day, at my side in the darkened theatre, during the continuing unraveling of the momentous closing days of the Civil War, acted out in the fires of power broking, literally at times in smoke-filled rooms.  The final coup de grace was my fifteen-year-old's summation of the film, walking the parking lot to the car."Man," he said, fear in his voice at uttering the wrong thing on such a momentous occasion, "that movie sure was fast!"  "Yea," I agreed, thinking to myself, we're gonna have to watch that one again.  This time at home, with no distractions.For historical background:America: The Last Best Hope (Volume I): From the Age of Discovery to a World at WarTL Farley,author,Distant Reaches-Autobiography from a Pub in Ireland to a State Police interrogation.

reviewText: Steven Spielberg's superspectacular "Lincoln" looks great on Blu-ray, and actually works well within the intimacy of the home screen. With all its battle scenes and meticulous costuming and art direction, ultimately it's a people story brimming with characters and human conflicts. The trademark Spielberg back-lighting and other touches are very much in evidence, but the director does not take center stage and allows his cast to shine.And shine they do. I can't add anything to the praise earned by Daniel Day-Lewis, who redifined Lincoln to millions who either remember early depictions by Henry Fonda or Raymond Massey, TV miniseries with actors like Hal Holbrook (who appears in this film as well) and perhaps most significantly, Royal Dano's voice and the Audio-Animatronics version at Disney Parks on both coasts -- a characterization that has been in the mass mindset since the 1964 New York World's Fair.Lots has been said about Lincoln's voice, but I had no problem with that. He also comes off as a little bit of an eccentric, whose numerous stories and long jokes cause sighs and eye rolls among his staff and associates. In Literature 101 terms, he would be called the "Christ-like figure," speaking in parables to make his points and even dying at the end (hope that's not a spoiler!)Sally Field, because she simply cannot be unlikable, brings that quality to Mary Todd Lincoln. She's never a villain or a harpy. She doesn't quite disappear into her role as Day-Lewis does -- for Pete's sake, it's Sally Field, whom we've loved for over four decades! Perhaps for that reason, and some powerful acting, few could create the Mary that she does. The argument scene between husband and wife is electrifying.Why did I say this movie isn't about Lincoln? Because I believe it's more about the people few of us know about. From the African-American soldiers to those three frazzled men who risk wrath and even shooting to get support for the Amendment. Tommy Lee Jones' character isn't legendary, yet he spent his life trying to abolish slavery. And the remarkable David Strathairn -- perhaps Hollywood's most underrated actor -- is a standout as Secretary of State Seward. Everyone, regardless of their walk of life, can share the accomplishment. Lincoln of course, is the ultimate in leadership, but it's nice to see the little guys and ladies get their spotlight, too.There is no commentary. Like War Horse, Spielberg offers his comments in bonus documentaries. Unlike the War Horse home release, the docs are shorter, but certainly fascinating and worth watching. The DVD only contains one short bonus feature; the two-disc Blu-ray contains more material.

reviewText: Especially for people whose families were in the Americas long before the Revolutionary War, but who were not included in 1787 when citizenship began, I highly recommend this particular cinematic version of President Lincoln. The story is well-known; however, the inclusion of other historic figures, such as Stevens from PA, who played pivotal roles to unify the country was something high school students could later become history majors in college. Inspiration from taking the heat in the Congress while advocating rights to the most repressed groups in America? Read more of Thaddeus Stevens!Native People, African Americans, Hispanic & Franco Americans were all denied, despite the many treaties as America implemented its own form of Nationhood. President Jefferson called his policies of militaristic genocide toward Native people "incorporation." Meaning, if you give us your lands, deny your way of life, accept Christianity, and sign this "treaty," we will call you citizen with no rights while we march you further west. Keep praying, keep marching? By the time of Abraham Lincoln, black slaves were no longer economical investments: absolute social order and control was necessary to continue separating the North & South divisions.Spain, France, and their own promises to cultural regions were insignificant to America's westward thrust and conquer. Of all the treaties with France & Spain promising full rights as citizens and to hold lands in America with free passage to and from?? Why are we still waiting for the 22d Century to grant such treaty rights? Yet, the movie "Abraham Lincoln" tells us: it's in the many lifeless bodies. Somehow, we can understand his pain ... Then, to the west with trains: Asians slave & their rights are denied by State laws and eager courts, especially the U.S. Supreme Court.The Congress sits, deliberates, and the ardent elite politicians play every measured angle while the Civil War continues past the Great Signing at Appomattox. While the elite, white men gather their thoughts, America continues in near collapse. The religious minorities, like the racial and ethnic minorities, struggle for acceptance; the whole country struggles to regain a sense of "country." The feeling of Country in the 16th - 18th century was something understood by White America. Hence, citizenship was never questioned in 1787.However, by the end of the Civil War, it was no longer clear what citizenship meant. The amendments: the 13th, 14th, and the Civil Rights Acts, with the power to enforce, were the absolute to stop the prevalent violence in America. The War had continued; only, most Americans have never considered hearing it from their "minority" friends. Hell, the country was barely productive without the enslaving railroads that stole Indian lands, and would later destroy labor unions with military support. Carnegie bought European technology, and without immigrants to supply the intellect, even the trains, electricity, and later the automobiles would have been delayed.Lincoln traveled on a timeless ship: it was powered by his pure mind and devout belief in God. As he sailed in his dream, we saw only a portion, I am positive he envisioned our time. Not much has really changed: the religious, racial, ethnic, cultural, and sexual minorities still strive for acceptance and commerce; the white elite still control the purse strings & companies - now reaching international; and, the Hispanic & Franco populations still wait for the U.S. Congress and their unforgotten promises.As a Black man sits in the White House, a highly educated and talented man and his family, we watch an imprisoned man cautioned by the ruling class and their Press. Warned of great doom by the Banks, Investors on Wall Street, and we all must pay taxes? Including the wealthy? And, all of this because the Black slaves wanted their freedom? It's a most unusual, but rewarding experience to watch history unroll into our current dilemmas that trouble the owners of this Country. It is more than Truth: it is our Mirror.

reviewText: Caution: May Contain Spoilers. I saw "Lincoln" yesterday with my two closest friends, and... Before I get into that, I just have to mention that the show time I had planned to see the film at was sold out (I'd expected that for the final installment of "Twilight," but not for "Lincoln"), and the theater house where the 4:50 show of "Lincoln" was playing was almost entirely packed, I kid you not. I was surprised, as I thought most people wouldn't be interested in a historical drama, but at the same time, I was pleased at the turnout for the movie.Now to what I think of the movie. "Lincoln" is a well-acted, well-directed and more or less well-written depiction of the days in January and several days of April 1865 where President Lincoln struggles with his divided Cabinet to get the Thirteenth Amendment ratified. The opening scene is all the glimpse we get of the Civil War. The remainder of the movie is straight-up talk. Don't let that stop you from experiencing this monumental motion picture, though. Daniel Day-Lewis, Sally Field and Tommy Lee Jones play Abraham Lincoln, Mary Todd Lincoln and Thaddeus Stevens very well. I think we can expect Academy Award nominations for all three of them come Oscar time. Other actors who give good performances in the limited screen time they have are Gloria Reuben (ER) as Elizabeth Keckley, confidant and dress-maker to Mary Todd Lincoln, Jared Harris ("Sherlock Holmes: A Game Of Shadows") as General Ulysses S. Grant, Joseph Gordon-Levitt ("Angels In The Outfield," "The Dark Knight Rises") as Robert Todd Lincoln, S. Epatha Merkenson as Thaddeus Stevens" housekeeper, James Spader as W. N. Bilbo, David Straithairn as Secretary Of State William Seward and Hal Holbrook as Senator Preston Blair.The music by John Williams is excellent and perfectly captures the mood of the era. There are some light-hearted moments to balance the heavy drama, which includes grieving over the loss of a beloved son a few years earlier. Younger children who see this film may find those moments difficult to understand. Content-wise, though, the film has some problems. The intense scene of war violence and a brief scene of severed limbs being thrown into a pit, along with several uses of the N-word are historically accurate to the time period, and were, I felt, not thrown in to shock viewers.The combining of God's Name with a mild curse word is unfortunate, however. That may be how people spoke back then, though infrequently, but it can always be implied (a sound like a whistle or a mill or somebody falling muffling the blasphemy) if necessary. The throwing in of an f-word or two is also unfortunate, but the one time it's clearly audible it is done in a humorous context, and I felt was not thrown in for shock value.With the above-content enumerated, I recommend this film, which may be of particular interest for history buffs. For those interested in a film that depicts the Civil War, but without the gory violence and pervasive language so prevalent in war movies these days, I recommend "Gods And Generals" and "Gettysburg." Both films have excellent acting, gripping storylines, well-written characters, beautiful musical scores, a strong commitment to historical accuracy (both movies were produced by Ted Turner, a Civil War buff) and most importantly, respect for God by both sides, North and South. "Gods And Generals," the prequel is rated PG-13 for intense sequences of war violence. "Gettysburg," made almost a decade earlier, is rated PG for intense war sequences and some language.2nd Note: I have since found out that President Lincoln strongly disapproved of profanity, and I regret going to view this movie in the theaters. Plus, the screenwriter likes men.EDIT - 3/4/13I stand by everything I said above. I just want to add something. The f-word was rarely, if ever, used in the 19th century. In fact, it was so infrequently said that the word did not appear in American dictionaries until 1965, 100 years after the end of the Civil War. Plus, Lincoln rarely, if ever, used profanity, and I very much doubt that he swore, as depicted in the film (ie. combining God's Name with a mild profanity, thereby turning it into a strong religious profanity). The fact that the screenwriter, who is a man, is living with a man is also a huge issue for me, which I am not here to debate or discuss. However, I bring it up because that's been pointed out in almost every news article and one Q&A; video about the film. It also means that those who pay money to view this movie, as I stupidly did, are thereby contributing to their perversions.
summary: Well-Directed & Well-Acted Drama Depicting The Struggle For Slavery's End. However...

reviewText: Historians will enjoy. Fictional portrayal as real as it can get. Lincoln, the man & his troubles in the last days. Spielberg sprays his magic wand glitter over every aspect of this film.Cast is outstanding;cinematography is spellbinding in itself,the music period precision,costuming exacting right down to the sweat and body odor.Story is compelling and edgy.However, I found myself laughing heartily during strange moments at very funny lines mixed into the dialogue of late Civil War days. It points to just how much of the black prejudice story has remained constant. Congress fights with words and actions, with little based on ethic . . . sound familiar. I don't know if the screen play/book writers deserve that credit or did Spielberg touch those aspects too?I'll refrain from reviewing the book here. This is the film/DVD listing. This film adaptation will be a blockbuster.DVD SUBTITLES in English, Spanish, and French.Much will be said of the near perfection in stature and acting of Daniel Day-Lewis's portrayal of Lincoln. He plays the statesman, the angry husband, Christian, a manipulator, and a heart-wrenching depiction of loving father. Crawling on the floor to his sleeping son before the fire hearth brings a near tear.Sally Fields gives what surely will be a nominated performance as Lincoln's wife, elevating her acting career to another new height.The list of stars and significant performance highlights is endless. It's impossible to cover all that happens in this 2  hour film that moves with such suspense and action that it seems less than half that length. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll beg for more when the credits roll.Set in 1865, almost 150 years ago, but this film puts you right there in Lincolns chair, his office, his boots and hat, most convincingly. Lincoln will win you over, even if he has to pay for your support. He's obsessed, just like I am at now wanting to OWN this production, even though I watched it just yesterday in the opening theater matinee. It's that good.If you liked WAR HORSE, you'll like LINCOLN.Different wars, same director/producer. This historical drama is a heart drama, and regardless of age, your heart will be touched in some way.

reviewText: I saw Zero Dark Thirty in the same week as I saw this film, in both cases I had a good idea of the plot beforehand, yet the Bin Laden movie was gripping and dramatic, whereas Lincoln was leaden.But first the good bits, it definitely made me want to read the book Team of Rivals.  The details of why Lincoln needed the Amendment, after he had declared Emancipation are well explained,  (though not really through Dialogue, the explanation comes in a meeting, but it was as if Lincoln was reading a paragraph from the book).  I had read William Safire's Emancipation long ago, and while it was a wonderful read, it stopped at the Declaration. This film gives some idea of the sheer difficulty of eradicating the conditions which rendered slavery normal.The other good bit is Daniel Day Lewis' acting.  He brought Lincoln to life as a gangly, astute, manipulative, wise-cracking, tortured man.  I think Day Lewis is overpraised, and I thought his last two roles in `There will be Blood' and `Gangs of New York' were outrageously over the top, but this was good.  A lot has been made of his accent, which I think is decent - but I did think it slipped back into Anglo-Irish when he raised his voice to Mrs. Lincoln.So overall though  I thought it was undramatic, and overly respectful.  I couldn't figure whether the story was asking us to  focus  on  Lincoln or Congress or Slavery.  Lincoln is given great wedges of text, but very little cut and thrust, he tells a few tales, but we know however close the vote, he will succeed.  The Congress debates are failures in two ways - the anti-Amendment side is not treated with any understanding - this may be a signal of the USAs ability to change completely, rendering the anti-Amendment arguments incomprehensible to today's generation - but as a result the opponents are portrayed as Caricatures, we get no feeling for the vehemence of their opposition. Also the debates are highly stylized, I presume the language is authentic to the times, but comes across as arch and false, the multitude of characters themselves - some manipulative, some fearful, some corrupt , all with huge amounts of facial hair, add to the strangeness.One of the characters says that if this amendment passes, whatever would come next  - voting for Blacks?  And the congress gasps,  Intermarriage?  More gasps, votes for women ? Outrage.  Ok , so we think they are dinosaurs, and this scene is sort-of played for laughs,  but I think the film would be more honest it could portray their fears more clearly.  Even Tommy Lee Jones, who has a goodish movies, goes home and hops into bed with his black servant, who, we presume, would be his wife if such a marriage were allowed, but we know the actress as the tough police lieutenant from Law and Order, so even this seemed (to me) to fall flat.And then, there is the Spielberg emotional manipulation -  we all know that when Lincoln is leaving for Ford's theatre, that its his final journey.  The scene shows Lincoln walking away  framed against a starry night sky seen through an arched window.  I looked to me like Spielberg was trying to say `See his going towards History now!', but it conjured up for me a scene from ET.  We also see Lincoln's Butler well with tears as Lincoln leaves - but as far as the Butler knows, he's just off for a night out.  Oh dear.So overall I think the movie fails for not knowing what its purpose is, we are not convinced about the depth of the arguments on each side, about how precarious the vote was, and because I think the makers are too concerned to be respectful to the past and  faithful to the facts without showing us the life and death drama of the times..
summary: Dull, more a waxwork exhibit than a movie

reviewText: While I have never been a fan of great people in history movies, Spielberg's "Lincoln" wins my respect for how it takes a larger-than-life person like America's 16th president and builds an accurate narrative around him during a very defining time in the country's history. Spielberg artfully combines the character of a national leader with a complex chain of interconnecting events whirling around him to produce an authentic sense of very special times. Back in the early 1860s America was at war with itself and Lincoln, the Republican president, wanted to keep the concept of the union alive in the national consciousness. While supportive of the idea of the emancipating slaves, his main task was to find a way to win the war while avoiding a compromise with the Confederacy. As the film illustrates, Lincoln ever the cautious pragmatist and opportunist, looked for that key moment when the tide of war was turning in favour of the Union to deliver on emancipation, but since that was on a wartime proclamation, much more had to be done in Congress to make it a constitutional reality. It is early 1865 when this version of history really gets going. Both the North and South are war weary and some members of the Republican and Democrats are talking about negotiating a peace. If this move ever went through, Lincoln's presidency could likely have failed to achieve the saving of the nation and the six hundred thousand soldiers lost in the conflict would have died in vain. It is at this critical juncture that the Lincoln White House got the Republicans in Congress to sponsor an amendment to federally make it unlawful to keep slaves anywhere in the country. While I always knew that Lincoln was an inveterate teller of yarns, I never appreciate how effective it was as tactic to getting people onside until I watch this movie. The enduring wisdom and patience of this iconic man, in the midst of great adversity, within and outside his family, is definitely a strong point in this production. While I have been used to appreciating the fullness of Lincoln over five decades of political maturation, this film emphasizes the importance of seeing him at important moment when all could have been truly lost if he given in to less resolute minds. The supporting cast does a credible job in bringing out those noble traits in the man as he humbly tried to make sense of his destiny without getting too far ahead of the events at hand.
summary: The Measure of the Man Inside the Essence of Time

reviewText: Daniel Day Lewis really captures the spirit of what I picture Lincoln to have been. His character is so poised and gentle 95% of the time. He is a sociable giant, a peaceful leader and a great orator. But the lamb to lion transition is acute and instantaneous. I loved watching Lincoln bare his fangs every now and again, taking his cabinet on the rollercoaster which was his administration and in essence telling them to take it. There are several humorous bits dispersed throughout the film that make the length very bearable. Sally Field plays a grieving mother with such sharpness that it is hard not to tear up during her emotive scenes.But to my mind Tommy Lee Jones was hands down the best part of this film. He has a command of the room that is breathtaking and a wit that leaves the audience gaping. Tommy Lee is forced to say things which he does not believe, to make a case for things he finds objectionable in order to pass legislation. You can see the turmoil in his demeanor as he vies for a greater good with words that disgust him.This film is exceptionally well-made.

reviewText: To the uninformed, the politics of this movie may seem to make sense. However, to anyone that knows better, it is socialist propaganda, through and through. How many times does one have to hear "EQUALITY" over and over again before they understand what the people behind this movie are trying to promote. Let's be realistic, there was more to the Civil War than this nonsense. From what I have heard, there are quite a lot of myths going around about Lincoln's beliefs, why the war was really fought, among other things. And I'm inclined to believe much of it, because I understand human nature.There are numerous problems with lower-income African-Americans in our nation today. I have witnessed them firsthand. It annoys me to no end to see black people portrayed as complete victims and deified on film. That just is not true. Some of the most racist people that I've ever met were black, but I will not go into it. I will not state my exact heritage, but I look Arabic or East Indian, but I'm mixed, and am part black. I was born and lived in another country that had a sizable black population. I've worked with many American blacks in the past, and their attitude leaves much to be desired. I understand why there is so much racism against them in America. So it enrages me to see liberal advocates, politicians and Hollywood directors, writers and actors portray African-Americans as perpetual victims, portrayed as angels. This is not an accurate depiction. An accurate depiction would display their abhorrence for education, family values and safe, properly run communities, organizations and businesses. Now, bear with me, I am not talking about all of them, but quite a few. Quite a few. It's a cultural problem. White people have nothing to do with it, and believe me, I would not hesitate to address this if it applied.That was one thing that bothered me, but since the rest of the film was simply atrociously written and edited, I could not finish it. It's just bad movie-making. Spielberg is an action movie director. That is what he is best at. When he does movies like Amistad or Lincoln, his weaknesses as a film maker are massively exposed. Despite the fact that masses of sycophants and film snobs will pretend to like these movies at the beginning, they will not stand the test of time and will soon be forgotten. Lincoln was torture to watch, and I could not imagine any school teacher showing this to their kids, because it is an ultra-boring political procedural and not even a decent movie about Lincoln's life. It was Oscar bait, through and through.

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: Is That a saga or is it history ? We can ask the question and wonder. The inspiration from Walt Whitman is quite obvious and strong, showing Lincoln as the father of the nation able to filibuster like any other senator or representative, sacrificing his own life, his own wife, his own sons to the only objective he had in mind: to save the union by defeating the secessionists, which he did.But the film centers on the crucial period after Gettysburg and the famous address, after the "government of the people, by the people, for the people" till his death and his funeral. Those crucial two years of his presidency and of his legacy. To finish the war he had to cast in iron the freeing of the black slaves and that could only be performed with a constitutional amendment to the constitution, the thirteenth to be more clear, and then the rest and the next two amendments are what will come after him. This battle is essential and Spielberg plays with the situation with obvious pleasure. Votes of representatives or bought up, not with money but with administrative jobs. The promise of defeat to some Democrats in the North is also vastly used when necessary.In that debate in the House of Representatives in January 1865 some declarations by the slavery-leaning conservatives are funny in retrospect: menacing the House with the Black vote, with Black Representatives and Senators, and after that where will they stop? The menace of the vote of women and all other catastrophes that could happen if the Black slaves were finally freed by the Constitution. And the vote was won with a simple argument: "I am not for the equality of all things, but only for the equal rights of everyone in front of the law." A typical compromise on the side of the anti-slavery camp. The US Constitution cannot declare everyone equal in real terms but only in rights. Yet it will take one more amendment for that principle to become true, the fourteenth amendment that is at the core of the debate on same-sex marriage right now, the Supreme Court's decision pending on the subject.This is so true indeed that what is important is not the real equality of people in material terms but their equality in rights. Then the equality in real material terms has to be built, constructed, won step by step, one step at a time. That's the American way. They do not look after every single individual case, but they state in general terms rights for everyone and then everyone is supposed to conquer the implementation of these rights. Real equality for the Black slaves was won only one century later, in 1964-65 with the laws on equal rights and the vote, one century after the full freeing of the slaves. A long, very long time and delay, but that's what it took for the slaves and then their descendants to get beyond the Post Traumatic Slavery Disorder (or Syndrome), for them to re-conquer their soul, rebuild their mind, reconstruct their self-pride and their future. And it took them more than forty more years to reach the top, and yet the President is not a descendant of slaves. The trip to equality is not complete yet, but it will be some time soon now.The film insists on a picture of Abraham Lincoln as a fast aging man surrounded by personal tragedies, like the loss of a first son to the war, and then the enlistment of his second son against his mother's wish and his father's advice, and then the crazy emotional state of his wife who is constantly oscillating between headaches and breakdown, with some moments of sane political vision. She was instrumental in Lincoln's life and decisions, but not as a direct inspirer, rather as an obstacle to negotiate, and that obstacle when negotiated opened doors to the next step or steps on the road to eternal gratitude of the Black people, by the White people and for the Black and the White people. Lincoln turned Gettysburg from a deadly defeat to a shining victory, and of the whole humanity as for that. We still owe him a bundle.The last element to say is of course about the marvelous performance of the actor. It is a challenge for any actor to impersonate a historical character of this magnitude. Daniel Day Lewis is one of the greater American actors in the line of the greatest like Dustin Hoffman or Jack Nicholson in the previous generation. It is so difficult to embody both the crumbling physical shape of the man and his building up resolve and stamina on the essential question that will make history, unluckily after his death. A brilliant performance.Think when you see the film of what the Lincoln Monument has become in Washington D.C. and you might understand the depth of this history in the making that is only coming true today nearly 150 years after the end of the Civil War. I will regret though the fact that Grant's and Sherman's sweeping fire trail down into the Deep South in 1864 and 65 is only alluded to and not shown. The horror of the war is rather discreetly evoked with one or two strong pictures here and there but very little altogether.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
