reviewText: This superb motion picture focuses on the intense political maneuvering and bargaining during January 1865 that led to the passage of the Thirteenth Amendment in the House of Representatives.  While many of us may have considered the Emancipation Proclamation (published after the Union victory at Antietam in September 1862 and effective on January 1, 1863) to be the event that "freed the slaves" and for which Abraham Lincoln has been considered our greatest president, the actual outlawing of Slavery throughout the United States did not come until the 13th Amendment to the Constitution was passed in both houses of Congress and formally ratified by the States at the end of 1865.  The legal necessity for this Amendment is carefully and clearly explained during this movie and gives gravity to this immensely important legislative activity.This is not a sweeping biographical study of Lincoln nor even the depiction of his entire presidency as was the dramatization of Gore Vidal's LINCOLN (1988) so ably performed by Sam Waterson and Mary Tyler Moore.  It is, rather, an intense focus on one set of events near the end of Lincoln's life and presidency that captures with greater clarity and precision the essential greatness of the man and enormous implications of the political debates facing the Congress at the time.Daniel Day Lewis gives what is certainly the single best interpretation of Lincoln I have ever seen, but the supporting cast is also extremely effective.  Tommy Lee Jones (as Congressman Thaddeus Stevens), Bruce McGill (as the irritable and blustery Secretary of War Stanton) and Sally Field (the acute, but deeply disturbed Mary Todd Lincoln), all render memorable performances.  The human toll of war are also presented without resorting to such faux battle re-enactments as were presented in the 1988 TV movie.  Wagons of severed limbs and mangled bodies portray the carnage in this film without resorting to inadequate action sequences.This will undoubtedly be a prime Oscar contender for 2012 and probably be numbered among the great motion pictures of all time.
summary: Compelling Portrayal of Lincoln at Work

reviewText: What cannot Steven Spielberg do?  I continue to be amazed by the breadth of this master director's gifts, and in choosing to film the story of Lincoln's last months with this consummate actor, Daniel Day Lewis (and the wonderful Sally Field as Mrs. Lincoln), he has created another masterpiece. Title: N/A

reviewText: There's no denying the following: Daniel Day-Lewis is one of the best living actors. That's just fact. He disappears into every role he's ever done. He's a true chameleon and he deserves every accolade that could ever be heaped on him. His work in this film, Steven Spielberg's LINCOLN, absolutely 1000% deserved the Golden Globe and the Oscar as well as any number of other awards he won. And this is a film about who is largely considered the greatest president in American history, written by one of America's premier playwrights and directed by one of the greatest directors to have ever lived.So, why did this film leave me wanting?LINCOLN is not an epic portrayal of Abraham Lincoln's life, from humble beginnings to great heights and tragic assassination; as written by Tony Kushner, it is laser-focused on Lincoln, his wife Mary (the incomparable Sally Field), his chief of staff William Seward (the always great David Strathairn) and his motley crew of assistants (played by the marvelous trio of James Spader, John Hawkes and Tim Blake Nelson), and radical Republican abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens (the eternally gruff Tommy Lee Jones) and the months leading to the vote in the House of Representatives for the Thirteenth Amendment, essentially abolishing slavery for all time in the United States. This amendment, for Lincoln, serves two purposes: The end of slavery and the end of the long and bloody Civil War. But complications arise when The Confederacy sends envoys to Washington for peace talks. Lincoln wants the war to end, but he can't, in good conscience, allow the war to end and for slavery to continue. He also can't, in good conscience, allow the war to go on, with hundreds of thousands of Americans dying. Through what some might consider "impeachable" offenses, Lincoln secures the necessary votes to have the amendment pass, but his victory is short-lived for the man himself, since not much longer after the amendment's passage, he would meet his end by a coward's bullet.The first sequence of the film shows a brutal battle sequence followed by Lincoln visiting a Union Army camp and being confronted by a black soldier who understands that while he has been proclaimed to be equal by the leader of this country, he is not even equal while he and his brothers fight and die for this cause. It frames the film succinctly and beautifully in such a short period of time, and I wished that there were more moments like that throughout the film. The film is peppered with Lincoln telling anecdotes to just about anyone who will listen (there's a great moment where a Union Army general actually leaves the room, refusing to listen to any more of Lincoln's stories), and they're indicitive of the gentle, wise, and soft-spoken man who did everything he could to bring equality to all men. Every scene with Lewis is magnetic. You can't take your eyes off him, and what's more indicitive of how brilliant of a performance it is, you never get the sense that this is Daniel Day-Lewis "pretending" to be Lincoln; he simply IS Lincoln. Spielberg speaks again to his perfect casting instincts with Field as the barely-restrained Mary Todd Lincoln and Jones as Thaddeus Stevens, who has deeply personal feelings about and furious contempt for slavery, and as a man who's mind will not be changed, Jones is the perfect actor to play that. And the film is almost over-populated with great actors, like Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Lee Pace, Hal Holbrook, Bruce McGill, Walton Goggins, Jared Harris, and Joseph Cross, but many of these other actors seem to be making not much more than cameos.The only problem with the film, really, is with how much it feels like a stage play. Kushner is a brilliant writer, and if this were just about any other quality director, this would feel a bit more complete as a film because of its theatrical monologues and intimate scenes. It feels very much like Spielberg's AMISTAD, which, while powerful, also lacks the epic scope of the films the name Spielberg evokes. Ironically, Spielberg's last film, the excellent WAR HORSE, was actually based on a stage play, but had a more sweeping and epic quality to it, making it a more "Spielbergian" Spielberg film, and therefore, a more fulfilling cinematic experience. Aside from a few sequences in this film, such as the opening sequence, there's very little to make this feel like it's not much more than a stage play.The film is absolutely worth watching for a number of different reasons, mainly for the performance/disappearance of Lewis, but LINCOLN ends on such a note that it felt like it wasn't necessary to take it that far, and while you have time to reflect and recognize the greatness not only of the man the film is about, but also of the craftsmanship of the people involved, you also will find yourself glad you saw it, but not much else.4 out of 5 stars.
summary: A towering performance by Lewis but lacking Spielberg's epic scope.

reviewText: Ok, so here's the skinny on this movie and why it is so very worth investment of money and time.  Most drivel that comes out of Hollyweird is banal and appeals to the lowest common denominator (usually sex, profanity, bathroom humor).  I'm all for some of that in a comedy but seems like these days it is everywhere.  I admit I was a bit daunted by the length of the movie--I thought there is no way I can sit through what I thought would be a docu-drama that took a lot of poetic license.What I found as I sat in the theater with my large soda and popcorn was a highly engrossing movie.  I'll be the first to say I'm not exactly a history buff or fan, but I found the characters so compelling.  I could hear myself in my head warning old Abe to watch out for the theater!  Don't go!  I found myself cheering for him to keep on with his efforts in the war and his desire to free the slaves.  I laughed out loud as Tommy Lee Jones' character berated and belittled his fellow elected officials in such a way that half the time it almost appeared to be a compliment!In these days of nearly constant CGI, this movie was a refreshing return to real movie making--with actual locations, actual actors and stuntment.  I just bought the DVD and I look forward to getting on the couch under a comfy blanket and a big bowl of popcorn and a cold beverage so I can watch this movie again!

reviewText: Brilliantly directed by Steven Spielberg-his best since SAVING PRIVATE RYAN, IMHO-with a performance by Daniel Day-Lewis that does not just impersonate Abraham Lincoln but embodies him, LINCOLN is one of those rare historical dramas that does not try to give the essence of a man by giving us a pageant of their entire life but does so by taking one segment and illustrating within that segment what made this great man tick.  Supported by an extraordinary cast including Tommy Lee Jones, Sally Field, James Spader, Gloria Reuben, Hal Holbrook, David Strathairn and S. Epatha Merkerson (in a powerful cameo) with beautiful behind-the-scenes work from Janusz Kaminski on camera, John Williams with music, Michael Kahn's editing, a brilliant script by Tony Kushner from Doris Kearns Goodwin's book "Team of Rivals," this is one of Spielberg's greatest achievements.  Get the 4-disc set-has more extras than the standard Blu-Ray edition and well worth it.
summary: Spielberg's best film in ages and Day-Lewis' greatest performance

reviewText: "Lincoln" is a marvelous portrait of our 16th president and his times, splitting the difference between hagiography and straight history. Spielberg has grafted the savvy conniving politician of Doris Kearns Goodwin's "Team of Rivals" with the otherworldly, solomonic martyr of post-Civil War history. The film focuses on the events of January 1865. The Civil War, all but won by the Union, is drawing its final labored death gasps. Lincoln is torn between an offer by Confederate representatives that might end the war (though short of an abolition of slavery) and the possibility of passing a constitutional amendment (with a Congress full of Union supporters) ending the practice. The film deals with the backroom dealing (including practices that were second cousins to flat-out bribery) that pressured lame duck congressmen to either support the amendment or to abstain from voting.Those who have read "Team of Rivals" won't be surprised by the portrayal of Lincoln as a complex man and a savvy politician. He brings the DC telegraph office to a standstill with a still-funny bawdy story about a portrait of Washington in a British privy. He and wife Mary get into a fight about Mary's worry about son Robert joining the army. Lincoln opines on his presidential powers to a rapt cabinet in one scene, then in another, bellows at them to get into line behind his leadership.Daniel Day-Lewis is masterful is Lincoln, inhabiting his character to the point that you forget you are watching an actorly portrayal. But the biggest surprise was watching Sally Field (!) bring a lively (if questionable) portrait of Mary Todd Lincoln to the screen. Fields' Mary is tough, with a sharp tongue for politicians too eager to investigate her expenses than providing her with a livable White House. Her "madness" is explained away as a consequence of grief over son Tad's death in Lincoln's first term. Your mileage may vary, however, as did Robert's in later years, when he confined Mary to an asylum.Spielberg did a nice job bringing the look and feel of 1860s Washington to the screen. The Capitol dome was painted blue, the streets were unpaved (if unpoopy) and the president ferried around the city in an unroofed carriage. Tad Lincoln had the run of the White House and Robert Lincoln WAS at Appomattox for the surrender of General Lee's forces. The loving fatherly scenes of Abe and 12-year-old Tad were touching and beautiful. Some critics might wonder whether Abe was really as saintly as Spielberg made him out to be. In some scenes, a halo is all but visible, and the adulation of those around him borders on the mawkish. A scene in which ordinary soldiers recited the Gettysburg Address was moving, yet discordant in its unlikeliness. Certainly, there were more than a few - Democrats and Southern sympathizers - who considered him a figure of satire and cruel vilification. And while Spielberg put drama into the passage of the anti-slavery 13th amendment, the celebratory scenes at its passage seemed doubtful. But all in all, "Lincoln" brought a measure of complexity to one of the most pivotal figures in American history.

reviewText: We streamed the HD version and had no problems. The story revolves around the end of the US Civil War and the approval of the 13th amendment to the US Constitution and much of the politics surrounding those times in Washington. Some people have issues with this package, and I believe that Spielberg created a big, ambitious project doing this. The scope and story are large and to squish it all into less than a few hours requires some compromises. Viewers wanting a perfect outcome will be somewhat disappointed. Those expecting a happy ending need to brush up on US history.The large collection of actors did a stellar job on their characters, I thought.  The dark undertones of the sets kept the War in my mind throughout the story. The raucous nature of the House and its collective, historical characters was expected and delivered!  Was this a condensed dramatization of historical events? Yes!  Was this well acted, well directed, and excellently produced? Yes!  It surely raises the bar for historical theater in my opinion. I would love to see a few more of these created for other major historical events.  Oh well, back to my books.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Let's all be honest.  The main reason this film achieved so much was because of Daniel Day Lewis and Tommy Lee Jones.  Lewis nailed President Lincoln, from his accent to his mannerisms to his love of storytelling and witticism.  Lewis BECAME Lincoln.  Sally Field also did an excellent job portraying the mentally complex Mary Todd.However, all of this fine acting, great casting and pretty good writing is confounded by the disjointed plot.  Frankly, if I were ever to watch this again, I'll take notes so I can remember who is who and when things are occurring.  It is very difficult to remember who each character is because there are far too many of them, and then to try and remember which side they were on politically is also an arduous task.  The sheer magnitude of the number of characters in this film is overwhelming and, I believe, takes a very great deal away from the film.Another grievance is the fact that they don't lay out a little time line so viewers can know when things are occurring in relation to Lincoln's inevitable assassination.  They don't say, "February 21st, 1865".  Again, this can be confusing because a great deal of time passes between major plot points.Finally, there is far too much going on at one time.  From trying to pass the amendment to winning over lame duck democrats, to the civil war, to Lincoln's domestic trouble...  It was simply far too much for anyone to take in because the viewer was being bombarded with different story lines.In any event, I would recommend this purely for Jones and Lewis' acting performances because that is what made this film so popular.  As far as rewatch value, there really isn't any.
summary: Disjointed plot joined by great acting
Title: N/A

reviewText: A star-studded cast has been gathered for this amazing picture from Shephen Spielberg.The time is January, 1865.  President Lincoln (Daniel Day-Lewis) has been re-elected and is awaiting inauguration. Lincoln wishes to add the 13th amendment to the Constitution which would abolish slavery. It is Lincoln's hope to pass the amendment before the inauguration.  Acting on information from Secretary of State Seward (David Strathairn), Lincoln learns that he will need 20 Democratic votes to pass the amendment.  Lincoln and Seward target several lame-duck congressmen who will be out of office in the hopes of gaining their vote for the amendment.Meanwhile, Lincoln's wife Mary (Sally Field) is still mourning the death of son Willie.  To make matters even more difficult for her, her son Robert (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) wants to enlist in the army.  This is almost too much for Mary to handle.The action in Congress continues to boil as the vote draws near.  Plus, the bloody Civil War rages on.  A delegation has been sent from the Confederacy to Washington to meet with Lincoln to see if a peace settlement could be arranged.  But this delegation could threaten the congressional vote on the 13th amendment.I'm a big fan of American history, and I found "Lincoln" to be compelling and dramatic.  Spielberg has done a masterful job of assembling a fine cast of actors.  Daniel Day-Lewis was the perfect choice for Lincoln, and Sally Field does an equally impressive job as Mary Todd Lincoln.  Of course, I can't forget Tommy Lee Jones as the racial-equality congressman Thaddeus Stevens.  I thought the movie was historically accurate, and I'm glad Spielberg chose to focus on the last 4 months of Lincoln's time in office.  It was interesting for me to see the battle over passage of the 13th amendment and how some of the political manuvering took place.I give "Lincoln" my highest recommendation.  Daniel Day-Lewis is excellent and the story is historically correct.  Don't miss this fine film about the final four months of our 16th President.

reviewText: Daniel Day-Lewis is magnificent as Lincoln, the war-weary president. I've read a very good Lincoln biography (Malice Toward None by Stephen Oates) so I knew about his travails with his generals trying to get them to engage the enemy, but I didn't know as much about the political war Lincoln also was fighting trying to get the 13th Amendment passed. This film shows that brilliantly and even though you know it passes, you're still on the edge of your seat when the vote is taken. Sally Field is superior as Mary Lincoln, emotional immaturity and all. Tommy Lee Jones also turns in a fine performance.

reviewText: Maybe I have been spoiled by the superb work of HBO-with its superb rendering of David McCullough's JOHN ADAMS series, and maybe I watch too much PBS--but the silly opening of this film said it all. It was a prelude to the sheer sentimental pap that would follow. But it's my fault. I've been spoiled by excellent biopics and such and forgot that Spielberg did this silly mess. But I was still a bit surprised. After all, THE COLOR PURPLE is quite good, and SCHINDLER'S LIST is also noteworthy--but he does give us sugary sentiment served up on a platter here--one from the White House collection, to be sure.Again, the opening scene was all I needed to give me what I was going to be presented for another two hours. There's no way any black man in that time period would have had the temerity to walk up to any white man, much less, Lincoln, the President, and complain about white men making three dollars more than they. It was laughable. And cringe-able--these two black soldiers wax eloquent with Abe like he's Santa Claus and they just graduated from Harvard. Then we have two white soldiers, portraying the myth of the noble Yankees, of course, and their ridiculous discourse.Lincoln, and this is a fact, did not give one hoot about blacks. He was a white man of his time, and this was purepolitics of dismantling the lucrative South (and the fruits of slave labor therein) first and foremost.Any black person of this fair land will tell you that the Great Migration 60-70 years later was about finding manufacturing and better-paying work in the so-called Free North, foremost. There was no welcome mat for them, and certainly, circa 1860, no Yankee got up their firearms to defend them. It was about dismantling the lucrative agrarian south. The bit about defending slaves is pure whitewash (pun, unintended) myth.  And it's astounding, the denial in our collective consciousness applauding this hooey stuff about this very conflicted and complex President--who-- by the way, ordered the mass hanging of Native Americans for their rebellion against the White Man's unjust tactics in defending their United States. (This is a verifiable fact, so look it up, Spielberg).In conclusion: HBO, PBS--some plausible entity--now do the real story of Lincoln, please.

reviewText: Last month, my mom commented that her grandmother 'hated Lincoln'.  I couldn't imagine how anyone could despise one of our greatest presidents...but after watching this movie, I gained a new appreciation of all the political maneuvering that happened, and the desperation people felt during the civil war.  I was also moved by the great performances of both Tommy Lee Jones and Daniel Day-Lewis  (Sally Field too!).  I could start to fathom how dissidents of the day could actually murder him.I made sure that my kids watched the movie with me and we've had loads of discussions about how politics work and the impact that 'real-time' news has had on our lives and the world in general.There are so many take-aways from this movie....It's not just historical fiction.  (at least partial fiction)

reviewText: As a Spielberg production, "Lincoln" is often a highly manipulative tearjerker, but it can at times also be an intelligent, thoughtful, and complex work.  The movie is supposed to be based on Doris Kearns Goodwin's "Team of Rivals," but I think the script owes more to Robert Caro's Lyndon Baines Johnson biography.  In "Master of the Senate," Caro reveals Johnson as the master prevaricator and vote counter, knowing exactly how many votes he needed to pass the bill, which Senator was voting which position, and if and how the Senator's position could be switched.  Spielberg's "Lincoln" very much follows the same lines -- how Lincoln would ultimately pass the 13th amendment through manipulation, bribery, compromise, procrastination, and ultimately prevarication.It's the first week of Lincoln's second term, which he has won by an overwhelming majority, and he is determined to use his power and his popularity to pass the 13th amendment, which would strike the right to own slaves from the Constitution forever.  Lincoln feels urgency for two reasons.  First, the North is soon about to overwhelm the South, and if that were to happen whatever popular support for the 13th amendment would vanish with the winning of the war.  Second, Lincoln, as a lawyer, knows that his Emancipation Proclamation is filled with legal contradictions that a Supreme Court, no longer afraid of a wartime president, would strike down immediately.  To pass the 13th amendment, Lincoln must use all the immense power and popularity he has amassed for himself, and the entire movie offers a clinical study of how Lincoln would manipulate his wife, his most trusted subordinate (Secretary of State Seward), the different factions of his own Republican Party, and Democratic congressmen with a conscience to pass the 13th amendment.  That Spielberg could fill such a legislative triumph with high melodrama is a testament to his film-making prowess.Ultimately, what makes "Lincoln" so compelling to watch is Daniel Day-Lewis' precise portrayal.  Day-Lewis imbues his Lincoln persona with authority and compassion, but also grace and elegance, and it's simply a delight to watch Day-Lewis onscreen.

reviewText: When I grew up, Abraham Lincoln had achieved the status in the minds of Americans as a man who changed the world and America forever. He is viewed in many ways in America, as a man who lead the fight to abolish slavery and also as a man that suffered heavily with the burden of the Civil War and the deaths of so many people.I watched this film thinking that is was about his life and how he became president and the issues that he had to deal with. Part of that is in the film but in reality, very little. It is more about an insight into the politics in Washington during the presidency of Lincoln. It tells how Lincoln, his aids, the army and his supporters fought for an amendment that in their hearts they knew had to be passed and implemented if America was ever to truly become the land of the free and a world leading country. The film is based on a book titled Team Of Rivals: The Political Genius Of Abraham Lincoln and that is what the film is about.While this film was not what I expected I still enjoyed it and I found it intriguing and entertaining. The acting was superb and Daniel Day-Lewis played the role to perfection. The cinematography was awesome and from the scenes of Washington DC in that time period to the battlefields it made you understand the time and the sadness of the war and slaughter that took place.This film is very good and I am glad that I watched it. It is a part of American history that we should not forget. It was presented with an excellent cast and a well written storyline. I rated it 5 stars and I recommend it as a good film.
summary: We have the fate of human dignity in our hands!

reviewText: Typical Spielberg garbage in the guise of "history". Two and a half ponderous, pretentious, stiflingly boring hours about a few weeks in the life of the most overrated president in history. If he hadn't been assassinated, he might be seen now as the wildly destructive crackpot-on-a-mission he really was - a 19th century George W Bush - instead of as the wise, easy-going, deeply compassionate but pragmatic martyr this silly movie makes him out to be.Because Lincoln refused to allow the southern states to secede, which they had the right to do under the constitution, nearly a million people were slaughtered and the economy was ruined. Although he won his war, the damage he caused the country still has not healed 150 years later. Anybody who believes that this is a united country has his head in the sand. The South is and always has been a separate society in every way and has NEVER fit with the North.Just look at a red-state/blue-state map! The United States is made up of two distinct nations: one from the southeast westward, then up to the Canadian border and a skip northwest to Alaska; the other in the northeast, the west coast and Hawaii. It's a natural, organic division that has been here as long as there have been European settlers, and no amount of brainwashing or sappy movie-making will EVER change it. This has NEVER been a united country; it will never BE a united country. It's like trying to force Ireland to stay in the United Kingdom: it doesn't work.We are TWO countries, not one. It was a bad marriage from the beginning. The South should have been allowed to leave peacefully 160 years ago, to effect an amicable divorce when amity was still possible. But Lincoln the zealot refused, and the mess he left is still tearing these unnaturally "United" States apart.Slavery obviously was a peripheral issue, because it's long gone but the problems remain. Left on its own, the South would have eliminated slavery eventually anyway, as has every other civilized nation on earth. All Lincoln did by ramming it down the South's throat was to destroy the country, enforcing a union that has never worked, from 1620 until now.Stupid movies like this just preach to the choir, reminding Lincoln-lovers why they love him so much and celebrating his stirring triumph over the bad old South, when a TRULY visionary leader would have let it go. The South might very well have WANTED to rejoin the union later, after it had learned for itself that slavery is unspeakably evil, but it never had that chance.Lincoln did his best to destroy the South, and although he won his war he failed to annihilate the enemy. So now we have the South using Lincoln's very own Republican Party to wreak their vengeance on the rest of the country. Thanks a lot, Abe.
summary: Mind-numbingly pretentious, manipulative and boring garbage

reviewerName: John D. Muir "oldies and pies lover"
reviewText: This movie focusses on an aspect of Lincoln's career that doesn't usually get much attention. Lincoln is known for his oratory, his pithy quotes, his leadership in the Civil War and his progressive views on slavery and the role of government in society. There's a tendency to overlook the practical matter of getting political decisions supported in the House. This movie redresses that missing element.The film is surprisingly intimate, given the dramatic circumstances of the time in which it is set. It begins at the start of 1865 with the Civil War going badly for the South, but no immediate prospect of peace. Lincoln sees this as an opportunity to force through an amendment to the Constitution making slavery illegal. Most of the film deals with the political machinations, including not a little chicanery, needed to obtain the necessary 2/3rds majority required to pass a Constitutional amendment. We see Lincoln as master manipulator, knowing where and how to apply pressure to get what he wants. He must satisfy not only his own Republican party, but also a sufficient number of Democrats to back the motion and the back-room deals and the dichotomy between what is said in private and what is put out for public consumption is fascinating (and still very much a part of politics today). Incidentally, those not familiar with the period may be surprised to learn that in 1865 the Republicans were the party in favor of expanding the role of government and protecting human rights.Daniel Day-Lewis gives a wonderfully impressive performance as Lincoln. Although he maintains his calm and rarely raises his voice, he is a magnetic presence whenever he is onscreen and it is easy to believe that he is able to bend people to his will. My wife, an Illinois native, assures me that his accent is authentic to the Kentucky/Illinois region of the midwest and he looks very much as Lincoln is usually portrayed. The manner in which Day-Lewis is able to slip from genial homeliness to ruthless political leadership to concerned husband and worried father is amazing; acting of the highest quality which will surely receive an Oscar nomination. He is well-supported by a team of veteran actors, among whom Tommy Lee Jones, as the leader of the progressive faction in the Republican party, stands out. I find the sub-plot involving Mary Lincoln's reluctance to let their son go to war is a distraction rather than an essential part of the film, but it does allow the actors to show their range and it incorporates a human element into Lincoln's character to sit alongside his more driven political persona.The movie is limited in scope and if you are anticipating much about the military side of the Civil War you will be disappointed. Because of this lack of breadth this might not amount to an Oscar-winning film. Nevertheless, it's a fascinating look at 19th century politics and boasts a towering performance by Daniel Day-Lewis. Recommended.

reviewText: If potential viewers knew that this movie was about the passing of the 13th amendment to the constitution, it may not have been as compelling. As is, to me it is a most excellent well acted historical drama.Remember the opening scene of that other great wartime  Spielberg epic?  This one starts in the same dramatic way. Lincoln then settles down & that is about the extent of the action. This movie covers the last months of Lincoln's life & the Civil War.It would be difficult for any actor to portray as indisputably great an American as Lincolnwithout moving pictures & sound. But Daniel Day-Lewis does it so well & captures Lincoln as I imagine him. Sally Fields does a fine job with an easier task. She plays Mary Todd Lincoln as she rapidly descends into madness.In this version Congressman & abolitionist, Thaddeus Stevens is key to the passage of the amendment. This difficult part is played by Tommy Lee Jones in what may be the best performance of his often uneven career. He must control his passion & snarkiness,  in what he says & doesn't say as leader of the radical Republicans. He must sway oppositional  Democrats to pass the amendment. Presently our president is a Democrat & the recalcitrant party is the majority Republican congress. See the parallels? In any case 147 years ago things worked out. Slavery was legally abolished in the United States for all time. The bad news was of course, Lincoln was killed a few short days after Lee surrendered to Grant.I'd say this is the best movie of the year, period.
summary: I love history & couldn't be more pleased.

reviewText: Steven Spielberg's "Lincoln" is destined to be remembered as one of our greatest cinematic tributes to an important figure in American history, President Abraham Lincoln, with Irish actor Daniel Day-Lewis' riveting portrayal of him as perhaps the finest ever depicted on either stage or screen. Acclaimed American playwright Tony Kushner has written a compelling screenplay which documents one of the most important months in Lincoln's presidency, January, 1865, noted for the passage of the Thirteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution by the United States House of Representatives, banning forever, both slavery and involuntary servitude (except in prisons) throughout the United States and other territories under its jurisdiction. Based in part on American historian Doris Kearns Goodwin's "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln", Kushner introduces us to a Lincoln (Daniel Day-Lewis) who is both a crafty, extremely astute, politician and a funny storyteller much like another famous Illinois resident, Lincoln's future successor as President of the United States, Ronald Reagan, but, unlike Reagan, one who is plagued by a mentally unstable wife, Mary Todd Lincoln (Sally Field), still traumatized by the tragic death of their son Willie early in Lincoln's Presidency, and a rebellious older son, Robert (Joseph Gordon-Levitt), who wishes to serve in the Union Army commanded by General Ulysses S. Grant (Jared Harris), instead of continuing with his undergraduate studies at Harvard University. Daniel Day-Lewis' portrayal of Lincoln is one destined to be remembered as the finest ever given on stage or screen, giving us a man tortured by his own personal family demons, while remaining both steadfast and confident in his duty to uphold the Constitution of the United States by waging a bloody war against the rebellious Confederate South and in ending forever, the scourge of Afro-American slavery. Having admired Day-Lewis ever since I saw him in his celebrated cinematic debut as Christy Brown in "My Left Foot", I was still surprised that he could give viewers such a compellingly realistic, quite sympathetic, portrayal of Lincoln as the self-educated thinker conversant in American law and the mathematical philosophy of Euclid, and as the brilliant politician and statesman during the worst crisis in American history, the American Civil War; without question this is his greatest performance in an exceptional cinematic career noted already for distinguished work in films as diverse as "A Room with A View", "In The Name of the Father",  "The Age of Innocence", "Gangs of New York", "The Unbearable Lightness of Being", "The Crucible" (in which he portrayed John Proctor in the acclaimed cinematic adaptation of his father-in-law Arthur Miller's noted play), and "The Last of the Mohicans" and one which warrants an Academy Award nomination for "Best Actor".Daniel Day-Lewis' memorable portrayal of Abraham Lincoln isn't the only reason to see "Lincoln". "Lincoln" is replete with exceptional performances by David Strathairn (Secretary of State William Steward), Tommy Lee Jones (Representative Thaddeus Stevens) and Sally Fields (Mary Todd Lincoln), but there's excellent work too from the likes of Joseph Gordon-Levitt (Robert Todd Lincoln), Lee Pace (Representative Fernando Wood), Hal Holbrook (Preston Blair), Bruce McGill (Secretary of War Edwin Stanton) and from James Spader too, who steals virtually every scene he is in as political operative W. N. Bilbo, portraying him as a Civil War version of  Watergate scandal mastermind E. Howard Hunt, using dirty political tricks and bribery in persuading lame duck Democratic Representatives to vote in favor of the Thirteenth Amendment. "Lincoln" is memorable too for long-time Spielberg collaborator cinematographer Janusz Kaminiski's exceptional photography of Civil War battles and political intrigue within the White House and on the floor of the House of Representatives. Another long-time Spielberg collaborator, composer John Williams, has a compelling musical score that harkens back to those he composed for "Schinder's List" and "Angela's Ashes" in his excellent usage of both solo instruments (piano and violin) and an entire orchestra (the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under the baton of its music director, Riccardo Muti), drawing upon musical influences as diverse as bluegrass and Aaron Copland. "Lincoln" is an excellent cinematic portrait of a man, President Abraham Lincoln, who must decide whether it is more important to end the Civil War by peaceful negotiations with a militarily exhausted, on the verge of defeat, Confederacy or to end forever, the scourge of Afro-American slavery; without question, it will be revered as one of the most important films pertaining to the American Civil War and for its portrayal of Lincoln.

reviewText: Historical movies, in general and even the most effective ones, are inevitably daunting and biased affairs.  No matter how objective a director thinks they are in presenting a historical figure, the period and themes they choose in depicting the figure often betray the director's subjective purposes and interests about him.  We can never learn "the truth" about anyone, especially historical figures we cannot witness first-hand.  Despite the lofty mountain of research he has inspired, this is true of Lincoln himself.  Spielberg certainly realized this and focused his saga on the final, fourth year of the Civil War, on the beginning of Lincoln's second term in office, and most specifically, upon efforts to ratify the 13th amendment, which basically abolished slavery and by extension all forms of servitude.  In reviewing "Lincoln", I will not relate all the specific characters, settings, and details; so many reviewers, Amazon and otherwise, have thoroughly seen to that (and more authoritatively than I ever could).  I wish to narrow my focus on what I see as one of "Lincoln"'s most ironic and prominent themes - the "ideal" of noble selfishness.I believe that, at heart, we are all selfish, or if you prefer the euphemistic adjective, "self-concerned".  Even when we do things for and help others, our primary objective is "what do we get out of it?".  This is not to detract from charitable, magnanimous, and self-sacrificing deeds.  What I am saying is that, in my opinion, no one can achieve pure altruism, e.g. complete selflessness.  But, I think we can achieve the next highest ideal: noble selfishness, that benefits many others besides yourself."Lincoln" argues that successful politicians adeptly use noble selfishness to achieve their objectives.  Even in our current period where revisionist Lincoln scholars have striven to demythologize and "humanize" our 16th president, presenting that theme takes no small courage. Lincoln's efforts to compel a 2/3 majority of obstreperous, "self-concerned" Representatives (2/3 of the Senate had voted in favor) - many of them Democrats (not Lincoln's party, the Republicans, who ironically, to many, resemble today's Democrats) revealed traits that have negative connotations for many of us.For example, as the movie showed, Lincoln exhaustively chatted up, or had lackeys chat up, many 13th amendment dissenters, even to the point of quid pro quo.  Early in the movie, we see throngs of supplicants and job seekers waiting to see Lincoln to seek favors, patronage, and legal advice, in order to show that conciliatory, compromising, manipulating tone was part of Lincoln's character.  Although historically shown to abhor slavery, arguably Lincoln had another, perhaps paramount, purpose for passing the 13th amendment - to disenfranchise the South, weaken their fighting morale, and acclerate their surrender and the Civil War's end.  In the movie, some representatives claimed that a Southern delegation from the Confederacy's president Jefferson Davis wished to see Lincoln to discuss peace terms.  The claim seemed dubious but did threaten some representatives' resolve to pass the amendment.  In the movie, Lincoln hastily pens a letter and has it delivered to the House, stating that "as far as I know", no delegation was forthcoming, which some representatives denounced as a "lawyerly dodge".  Lincoln was even willing to use a type of "eminent domain" to thwart the South by seizing the slaves as "property" from the South, then employing the Emancipation Proclamation, enacted earlier, to set them free.  Lincoln even tries mathematical logic, stating that if two things are individually equal to a third, then they are equal to each other.  This, which incorporated with Thaddeus Steven's assertion in the House that even if all men were not really created equal in nature, they were equal under the law, attempted to circumvent those representatives that thought that African-Americans were fundamentally inferior.And so it goes.  The movie shows Lincoln employing every political, legal, and logical weapon to flatter, wheedle, coax, intimidate, persuade, and entice as many representatives as possible (especially the 20 House democrats necessary to achieve the 2/3 majority) to vote for the 13th amendment.  Again, some audiences may have been shocked by the seemingly base, hypocritical, self-contradictory, and unscrupulous tactics the 16th president used.  Basically, it's a concession to the old adage that "the end justifies the means".  In any case it worked, of course, the amendment is passed.  Tellingly, the deciding vote, by the House speaker, stemmed from his desire to "make history".Of course, "Lincoln" has its other virtues like Daniel-Day Lewis's spellbinding portrayal of the President, Tommy Lee-Jones tour-de-force as the savagely but amusingly brusque, candid, and insulting Thaddeus Stevens, and the re-creation of the oppressive, anxious Civil War zeitgeist.  But above all, I think, "Lincoln" will have relevant, enduring value because of its assertion that compromise, however superficially distasteful and beholden to the innate selfishness of others, is really the only way to get grand political accomplishments.  I hope Obama and congressional members see the movie and retain that message.
summary: Lincoln's Noble Selfishness - A Template for Modern Politicians

reviewText: 3 stars, mostly for the acting. However, while the acting is top notch - Tom Lee Jones in particular is fantastic - Spielberg's direction of Daniel Day Lewis' Lincoln results in a portrait of a president who is not a quiet and reflective man of iron resolve, but rather a shrinking and frail man of iron resolve. While it is understandable that Lincoln's presidency took a toll on his health, Lincoln's physical stature appears to be a liability in Spielberg's eyes. We don't know what Lincoln was like in real life, but I don't think he was the man Spielberg tries to convey. Spielberg misses on another account, that being his focus of the Lincoln presidency during ratification of the 13th Amendment; it is the decidedly safe route to go as far as Hollywood is concerned. Despite the importance and the legacy of the 13th Amendment, I wish the movie had taken a less myopic view and captured all of Lincoln's presidency, especially for a movie that is going to clock in a 2 and 1/2 hours. A good effort that could have either been grander in scope or been tightened up a bit. Maybe next time, Steve-O.

reviewText: Imagine an episode of Star Trek (The Next Generation) that consists entirely of nothing but the Captain, Worf and Data sitting around a table in one of the conference rooms talking.  No action.  No plot.  Just talk.  That's what Lincoln was like.  Nothing but several hours of slightly archaic language about Lincoln's efforts to get together all of the votes that were needed to pass the 13th Amendment.Pure boredom...beginning to end.  My personal opinion is that it shouldn't have even been called Lincoln.  "The 13th Amendment" would have been a better title.  In a movie about Lincoln, I would have preferred to hear about his history.  Where was he born?  What were his parents like?  What was it like to be born in a log cabin?  Was he ever in the military?  What was he like as a lawyer?  What was his wife like when they were courting?  When and how did she go crazy?...etc.  What were the Lincoln/Douglas debates like?  This movie says pretty much nothing about Lincoln personally.  They don't even show the assassination.No thank you.  This movie was a waste of great actors.  Mr. Lewis, Mr. Strathairn, Mr. Jones, Ms. Fields...etc. have made wonderful movies over the years.  This one was garbage though.P.S. The one star is not an exaggeration.  I literally had to force myself to stay in the theater seat.  Staying in the theater seat was work.  The movie was sold so hard to everyone, had so many great actors in it and was about such an important topic that I decided to give it every break I could.  And, in the end, I can't justify the time or money I invested in it whatsoever.  I wish I had that time and money back.  But, I will never see it again.  Mr. Spielberg needs to realize how much time and money he has cost the world with this one.  Billions of dollars?  Billions of hours?  When you waste that much time and money of others...  How can you do something like that to people?  It's not a crime...and I don't think it should be...but, if I were a lawyer and it was my responsibility to protect a director who had made a very bad movie and had cost the world billions of dollars, I would have a very hard time finding arguments to support my client.

reviewText: Despite the title, this movie is not a bio-pic about American president Abraham Lincoln. Rather, it tells the story of his fight in late 1864 and early 1865 to pass the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution that abolished slavery in the United States. The story is dramatically told with the typical Spielberg visual flair.Even though the film is not a bio-pic, it gives a fully-rounded character portrait of Lincoln. We see him as a father comforting his young son and trying to keep his older son out of combat. We see the turbulent relationship with his wife Mary Todd Lincoln (ably played by Sally Field). He deals with congressmen, soldiers (high and low ranked), government workers, and everyday people. Lincoln often uses his penchant for storytelling to make his points. He's decisive and forceful when he needs to be. He is politically adept, which often means skirting on the edges of (if not crossing over) what's moral to achieve his ends. Viewers see his lawyerly mind working all the different facets of legal issues, especially when he discusses (though really it is a monologue) the legality and the impact of the Emancipation Proclamation. Daniel Day-Lewis gives a great performance, capturing the voice and look and world-weariness and optimism of Lincoln. So perhaps the title is justified.The political and moral wrangling over the amendment is interesting. Many different factions in the House of Representatives need to be satisfied--hard-lining abolitionists and Southern sympathizers and middle-grounders. Lincoln's staff works with sympathetic congressmen to make sure they don't push so hard they make it impossible for others to join the cause. They hire some men to offer patronage to wavering congressmen to secure their votes. When patronage doesn't work, blackmail is also tried. Meanwhile, a delegation from the Confederate government is invited to negotiate peace (thus placating those hoping that a diplomatic solution has been tried before the amendment is passed) but Lincoln struggles with accepting their potential offer (which would kill momentum for the amendment but end the war) and his desire to pass the amendment (which would end the evil of slavery but kill the peace negotiations). The movie gives plenty of food for thought on the right way to handle such situations and the need for compromise and chicanery in politics.Check out more commentary on A Good Story Is Hard to Find podcast which is what inspired me to watch.
summary: Good story of 13th Amendment and Portrait of Lincoln

reviewText: Lincoln knew that winning the Civil War was not enough to stop slavery.  The 13th Amendment was needed to  "seal the deal."  This film demonstrates his down-home folksy wisdom in playing the necessary sophisticated political game to make this happen.  There are many great intimate scenes with Lincoln and Mary Todd Lincoln, him and his co-horts, him and his adversaries.  There are scenes where a group listens as Lincoln tells a story that at first makes no sense, but later swings round like a Zen koan with a bite.  Occasionally there are familiar shots of Lincoln in silhouette, dramatizing his historical significance;  whereas after the assassination, his dead body appears to be a simple, gentle, humorous man taking a nap.  What a gift Spielberg, Daniel Day-Lewis, et al have given us by revealing the lovely ordinariness of this extraordinary man who graced our history and continues to inspire our nation!

reviewText: Given the fact that anyone who's attended school in the United States knows who Abraham Lincoln is, I'll exclude the summary portion of this review. Now I'm going to warn you in advance that I've never been particularly fond of history so I already knew going in that this wasn't going resonate with me like it did with other people. To be completely honest, I'm ok with that. History is one of those subjects that you either love or hate, there's no real in-between. With that said, from a cinematic standpoint this film does a lot of things well and that's what kept me watching the entire way through.I, like my mother who watched this with me, went into Lincoln expecting the film to cover his entire life or, at least, his entire presidency. Instead, Lincoln covers the last few months of our 16th President's life. So what the viewer sees is Lincoln attempting pass to the 13th amendment and end the Civil War. This, of course, would outlaw slavery in the United States. Because this was a big turning point for our country, and Lincoln's biggest accomplishment, it only seems fitting that this would be the main subject discussed in the film.Visually the film is beautiful. From the sets to the costumes you can tell that there was a lot of hard work put into recreating this time period. Daniel Day-Lweis' transformation into Lincoln is most notable. He doesn't look perfect, of course, but the costume designers really did a great job at creating a very strong resemblance to the real Abraham Lincoln. The script used for the film, while flawed, does its job of telling the story without sounding redundant in comparison to everything we've read in the classrooms. What keeps it from being perfect is the fact that we don't know who most of these people are. You know Lincoln and his family, but everyone else seems like just another face and the viewer doesn't really know what their job is or how they're relevant to the story.My biggest gripe with the film is that none of the performances really stood out. Everyone involved felt like they were acting just to act which made some sections of the film excruciatingly boring. For a film to be two and a half hours long the last thing you want is for scenes to feel boring. Day-Lewis gave a solid performance, but he didn't necessarily feel like he was Lincoln. Sally Field's performance as the First Lady was solid as well, but at times felt a little overdone. There's a pretty extensive list of people involved so I won't break them down one by one. I will, however, say that Tommy Lee Jones, in my opinion, gave the strongest performance out of the entire cast. His character Thaddeus Stevens is one filled with so many conflicting emotions that it becomes difficult to pinpoint what his motives are, but once you reach the end it becomes very clear and you can't stop yourself from going "whoa".Lastly, I found it odd that they didn't really do much to cover his assassination. I was expecting it to be a very dramatic part of the film, but it felt like they just brushed over it. All they did was have a character come into a scene and yell, "The president was assassinated". Considering that this was a major thing when it happened it felt wrong that they made it seem like a minor detail. I don't know, maybe I was just expecting too much.Overall Score: 7/10 - Look, for the history enthusiasts there's a lot of enjoyment to be found in Lincoln. Assuming that most, if not all, of the content in here is legit, they touched on a lot of things I was unaware of. I knew going in that I wasn't going to leave blown away and this probably isn't a movie I would watch again, but I can't deny that the end result is very well done. What would have made it better, for me, would have been a cast that showed a little more enthusiasm. That's not to say that anyone performed poorly, I just found majority of the performances to be pretty bland. With that said, I would have a hard time not recommending this to fans of history or fans of Abraham Lincoln because even though I'm not crazy about the subject I don't regret spending the time to watch this.

reviewText: Lincoln isn't a perfect movie (what is?) but it is extremely impressive.  It only suffers in comparison to what a "perfect" movie about Lincoln would be.  In comparison to mere mortal movies, it gets 5 stars.  I can't believe that it would get any competition for a Best Picture Oscar from silly films like Django Unchained.  Argo was good, but not nearly as good as this one.  Lincoln will enthrall those who are interested in this dramatic, amazing time in US history.  Yet it's not a war movie, it's a look at Lincoln the Man and how he navigates his role as US President, masterfully.Daniel Day Lewis is wonderful as Lincoln.  For an Englishman to play Lincoln so masterfully, he deserves the Oscar for Best Actor.  The look and feel of the movie is amazing.  You believe that you're in a time machine and that you're really THERE, in Washington, in 1865.  The portrayal of Lincoln's political infighting with an entrenched and arrogant Congress to get the 13th Amendment passed, is intriguing and intelligent.  Day inspires as Lincoln throughout.  One really gets the feeling of a storm of swirling voices in a desperate time of war, crying to be heard and followed, while Lincoln is the Man of his time, calmly staying strong and resolute in the midst of this chaos and grinding out his policies.  If Lincoln hadn't show great Leadership and pushed the 13th Amendment at the time he did, who knows when the country would have gotten up the courage to abolish slavery again?The secondary performances are great, including Sally Fields as Mary Todd Lincoln, Tommy Lee Jones as the Abolitionist Congressman Stevens, James Spader as a shifty Republican operative, David Strathairn as Secretary of State Seward, and Joseph Gordon-Levitt as Robert Lincoln.  Fields in particular played a very difficult role (of the suffering and neurotic Mary Todd) very well.  ALL the performances were so well played -- like I said -- you think that you're really there in 1865.Lincoln, the movie, doesn't pull punches.  I hope that the producers made sure that they researched their material well and stayed true to the facts, because it makes SUCH an impact.  Film-goers who always thought that the Democrats were for freeing the slaves will be surprised to find this truth out: Demos in those days were absolutely for slavery and it fell to the Republicans (split into two camps: the Abolitionists and the Conservatives) to push the 13th Amendment through.  The sentiments of the anti-13th-Amendment crowd in those days is also portrayed with shocking candor.  Racial fear and hatred is expressed openly in the movie.  It's hard to swallow at times: was this really the mood of the people, or was this played up by Spielberg artificially?  Let the viewer watch it and decide!  I'm personally going to read more first-person accounts of that time of history.I have a few "small" criticisms of the movie:  some of the scenes where citizens seem to me to be insolent in front of the President were hard to take.  (An opening scene with some soldiers talking to Lincoln in a very familiar and non-respectful way; a scene where Lincoln bursts in upon a lobbyist who exclaims, "Well I'll be F****ed!")  I would think that coming before the President would cause 99.9% to be utterly respectfull if not petrified!  Also, the opening scene of black Union soldiers hand-fighting & killing Confederates up close & personnal, is disturbing for those not thick-skinned.  I'm really not sure that that scene needed to be in there as it was.  But if the viewer can suffer these small annoyances and look at the overall magnificence of this film, I believe that he/she will be impressed with Lincoln's intelligence, power, realism and emotional impact.
summary: Intelligent, Impressive Look at Lincoln and the Times; Gotta Give it 5 Stars

reviewText: I give 4 stars to every well made historical film just for the socially redeeming value. I wanted to like this film, but there are significant flaws. Daniel Day Lewis' acting saved this film for me. Although Steven Spielberg is an excellent director (Schindler's List), the film suffered from the safe and mundane interpretation of the life and times of Abraham Lincoln based on mainstream school textbooks. Like the real reason behind the assassination of JFK, Oliver Stone would have told a better story on who killed Lincoln and why he was killed. Unknown to most people, there is a common denominator in the assassination attempts on the lives of Presidents Jackson and Reagan and the successful assassinations on Lincoln, Garfield and JFK. Every American deserves to know the truth. Likewise, although slavery is one of the causes of the Civil War, it is not the only major cause as portrayed in the film. The film would have served generations of Americans better if the real story was exposed.

reviewText: Boring TV movie, with thick, stilted dialog--did they really "talk" that way then-- that would make even poor old wordly Shakespeare balk. As a PBS enactment of a certain period in Lincoln's life, with commensurate expectations, it would be watchable, and maybe, if not enjoyable, amusing. But as an overwhelming Oscar winner, as a proclaimed "masterpiece",  it's absurd, a joke. Lewis is very good, but not great. He's got the posture nailed, and the accent nailed--whether or not they're like Lincoln's is almost irrelevant--with, for better or worse, plenty of croaky hoaky artifacts from Gabby Hayes. But when you compare Lewis in Lincoln to Joaquin Phoenix in The Master, you have to conclude the Oscar, that bulsh exercise, was literally stolen from Phoenix, who is in my book the best actor going these days.

reviewerName: J. White "Book lover to the max"
reviewText: Got this from the library - I was excited because I waited almost 2 months for it.  I figured it HAD to be good if it is that popular. WRONG!  Its a typical Spielberg, using his films to push an agenda.  Lincoln was not believable and the acting was so so.  It was a vehicle for "messages" starting with soldiers quoting the Gettysburg address.  Soldiers, dirty and tired, born in the 1850's, in the midst of a bloody war, memorizing a speech and repeating it with perfect recall, grammar and diction like college grads.  REALLY?  We watched about half and since I love history, truly wanted to enjoy it, but couldn't.  It dragged, it was boring, it was dark (both filming and the story).  I've read plenty of Lincoln biographies, studied the Civil War from all sides and I can tell you, this is merely twisted history with a heavy thumb on bloody scenes.  I like a political film now and then, but when history is "tweaked", and an historical character is not even close to real - there should be some sort of pre-warning that this is not accurate history and produced from the viewpoint of its creator.  When Spielberg goes back to making those great sci fi movies, I'll watch one of them.
summary: Didn't bother to watch the whole thing

reviewText: Lincoln is a docu-drama that focuses on the 16th President's tumultuous final months in office. reviewerName: Jym Cherry "Writing Under The Influence of Ro...
reviewText: As a reviewer sometimes movies are on the edge of a rating and you have to think was this movie a three star or a three and half star movie? Or should I hedge the bet and average it up? Or down? But Steven Spielberg's "Lincoln" is unabashedly a five star movie!"Lincoln" isn't a biography of the President, but covers the time from just after his reelection up to his assassination. It focuses on his efforts to get the 13th Amendment to the Constitution passed before the new Congress is seated and the all the wheedling, machinations, deals, and plain old politics that went into the passing of the Amendment. The dramatic vote on the Amendment, which may be the second most important roll call in American history (next to the roll call on the vote for the Declaration of Independence), may also be the second most tension filled roll call of cinematic America since the movie "1776." As the roll is called and the Congress votes, even though we know how the vote turns out, we're on pins and needles trying to figure out how each Congressmen will vote. Will they adhere to party lines, or will they crossover?Although "Lincoln" isn't a full blown biography (which are at best highlights of a life on film) we're able to get a sense of the man. Daniel Day-Lewis' Lincoln is a man with the weight of the world on his shoulders and it weighs on him almost literally. Lincoln is also a man that loves his children, but has a contentious relationship with his oldest son Robert (Joseph Gordon-Levitt). Lincoln's marriage to Mary Todd Lincoln (Sally Field) also teeters from her being an astute political ally of Lincoln's to the edge of madness. Day-Lewis doesn't so much as turn in a performance or channel Lincoln, he seems to inhabit him, it was like looking into the eyes of Lincoln."Lincoln" also fleshes out the members of Congress that were important to the vote, and demonstrates the more things change the more they stay the same (they just had funkier facial hair then). That some of our `leaders' are truly that, leaders, while some have all the courage of the convictions of their party and not their own, and some are downright malleable. The ultimate lesson of "Lincoln" (and the Civil War) is that democracy and this country are what we make of it.The cast is a long and distinguished one, including David Straitharn, Joseph Gordon-Levitt, James Spader, Tommy Lee-Jones, Hal Holbrook, Bruce McGill, Jackie Earle-Haley, and a whole list of instantly recognizable names some of which have carried movies on their own, and each turns in an excellent performance, which mostly makes the actor invisible and the character real as a human being as opposed to our history class understanding of them. "Lincoln" is Steven Speilberg's movie. It is like Picasso signing a painting. "Lincoln" is also a pure example of filmmaking. Speilberg blends all the arts and trades that make a movie into a seamless work of art.One of the marks of a great movie, book, or painting, is whether you want to see it again and again to see what nuances reveal themselves.  I want to see "Lincoln" again. This is easily one of the best movies of our lifetimes.

reviewText: We plunged into Lincoln, four of us, each with a different relationship to Spielberg, Sally Field, and Daniel Day Lewis, and so when we filed out again to John Williams credits music, there were at least 16 and probably 256 mixtures of feeling all told.  We climbed into the car, parked several; blocks away from the busy downtown San Francisco movie palace we were at, and avidly discussed the movie until night fell and the stars broke through the low lying clouds on a warm January night.  The main topic of conversation, how lucky for Abe Lincoln to have Adam Driver to turn to on those cold Washington nights when the war was keeping him up, not to mention the madness of Mary Todd.Adam Driver, who plays "Adam" on HBO's Girls, plays "Samuel Beckwith" the lead White House telegraph operator, in Spielberg's LINCOLN.  We wondered first of all why screenwriter Tony Kushner hadn't just called his character "Adam" too, as his other writers do.  Poor Adam must have had a disconnect when he realized he was going to have to answer to somebody else's name.  Thus when Lincoln brushes his hair fondly, mumbles, "Good night, Sam," you can see it in Adam's eyes, he doesn't really know why Lincoln is calling him "Sam," it's not registering, his beautiful eyes fill up with puzzlement, just like on Girls, when Hanna won't answer his calls.  One of our party denied it was Adam at all, citing the blond highlights in Sam's hair that glisten in the thousands of gas lamps and sexy candles that brighten up Lincoln's private telegraph office, complete with bed.  "Adam isn't blonde," our friend argued.  "Well, in the 19th century he was.  Samuel was blond," I countered, believing at the time that "Samuel Beckwith" was a real-life 19th century communicator, perhaps the inventor of the telegram?  Not knowing then, what I know now, that Kushner and Spielberg had made up the appealing character of Sam, to use him as a sort of yes man slash devoted friend, like Sam in The Lord of the Rings, willing to do anything to get his master out of a jam, like Frodo.  "Substitute Lincoln for Frodo," I continued, "Sam for Sam, and the war against slavery for the war against Mordor or whatever it was called, and it's working for me."My wife happened to be in the ladies room during Adam's big scene, and we kept waiting for him to come in at the end, but alas no.  His simple act however of(spoiler alert--)Telling someone in Virginia to stash the peace delegation in a shack somewhere--(Spoilers concluded)Changed the whole course of the war--no, not the war, but he caused the 13th amendment to be signed and slavery abolished forever more.  It was the kind of miracle that Adam Driver fans expect of their idol.  That bravery that competence with machinery, and otherwise the dumb look of a man who can't keep it in his pants for very long, and maybe that's why, we speculated (except for the one of us who denied that it was Adam at all) maybe that's why Daniel Day Lewis kept him within arm's reach, to warm his pallet and to bring back the simple joys of boyhood.
summary: Like the Lord of the Rings, sort of.

reviewText: Totally overrated.So you have the name Spielberg attached to it, a beautiful production and cast and Oscar-winner Daniel Day-Lewis...HOWEVER, underneath all that, this is one BORING film.What do we go to to the movies for? Mostly entertainment. Spielberg and this film seems to totally forget that element.It's obvious the screenwriter is more of a playwright than knowing the smooth flow, dramatic transitioning, and pacing translating it on film. The film is just talking heads the entire film and seems better suited for a stage performance or TV series.In the making, they mentioned the first draft of the screenplay was over 500 pages (generally, one page is worth 1 minute of screen time); so, originally, it would have been over an 8 hour film. Spielberg had to cut it down a lot, and he decided the most important part of the book adaptation was the "13th Amendment" section.The title of the film "Lincoln" is very misleading. It really should have just been called "13th Amendment" but of course that would be a horrible marketing title. I mean, there's a few scenes where they tried to show the personal side of Lincoln and his family, like the relationship with Lincoln and his son (played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt) but it really doesn't go anywhere and feels totally incomplete.If one really had no idea or ever heard of who Lincoln was, they really wouldn't get much out of this film either.The whole film just focuses on trying to pass the "13th Amendment" with Lincoln hiring men to convince Democrats to switch their votes. It's extremely boring and frustrating to watch and listen. You might as well watch C-Span. The pacing of the film is really horrible and it drags the entire time from start to finish -- there really is no high point -- yet the ending feels completely rushed.This is by far the most boring film Spielberg has ever produced. Don't be fooled by high production visuals/set and performance.This may be enjoyed by history critics (whether they agree with its accuracy or not), but for people who are looking for a full pleasurable movie-going experience, this film is not it, especially if you don't care for politics.I also feel Denzel Washington was robbed for Best Actor inFlightfor the Oscars; his performance was much more powerful throughout the entire film than Daniel Day-Lewis as Lincoln. Even a 6 year old can play as Lincoln on a school play...This film is nowhere near Schindler's List quality. If you need a cure for insomnia, play this film.
summary: One word to describe this film: BORING. The film should have been called "13th Amendment" instead of "Lincoln"

reviewText: "Lincoln" is brilliant! This is how the story goes: In a nation divided by war and the strong winds of change, Lincoln pursues a course of action designed to end the war, unite the country and abolish slavery. With the moral courage and fierce determination to succeed, his choices during this critical moment will change the fate of generations to come.The cast led by Daniel Day-Lewis (impressive in his Oscar-winning, well-crafted performance as Lincoln), Sally Field (superb in her Oscar-nominated performance as Mary Todd Lincoln) & Tommy Lee Jones (also superb in his Oscar-nominated performance as Thaddeus Stevens) is brilliant. The directing by Steven Spielberg (Oscar-nominated) (also produced) is brilliant. The screenplay (based in part on the book "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln" by Doris Kearns Goodwin) by Tony Kushner (Oscar-nominated) is brilliant.The music by John Williams (Oscar-nominated) is brilliant. The cinematography by Janusz Kaminski (Oscar-nominated) is brilliant. The film editing by Michael Kahn (Oscar-nominated) is brilliant. The casting by Avy Kaufman is brilliant. The production design by Rick Carter (Oscar-winning) is brilliant. The art direction (Oscar-winning) by Curt Beech, David Crank & Leslie McDonald is brilliant. The set decoration by Jim Erickson (Oscar-winning) & Peter T. Frank, set dressings by Alex Brandenburg, Steven Harris, Keith S. Jackson, Beth Morris, Rick Reeder, Jane Sakowski, Eric Luling & Billy Stearne, set designs by Jim Hewitt is brilliant. The costume design by Joanna Johnston (Oscar-nominated) is brilliant. The make-up effects supervised by Leo Corey Castellano is brilliant. The special effects coordinated by Steve Cremin is brilliant. The visual effects supervised by Gavin Miljkovich & Ben Morris, coordinated by John Szebegyinski is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Garrett Warren is brilliant.This is a well-crafted and well-made film that is brilliant and entertaining. Daniel Day-Lewis gives another Oscar-worthy and contending performance that is brilliantly well-crafted and well-done, a performance (awards consideration deserving that is has received, thus far) that is sure to give him (which did, give him) his third Best Actor Oscar, the second in the last five years. Sally Field & Tommy Lee Jones just about match him in performance quality, gives superb crafted and well-done performances that are both deserving of the awards consideration that they have received to date, thus far, just like Daniel Day-Lewis has. This is one of the best films of Steven Spielberg's career and is also one of the best films of the recently done holiday season that began on Thanksgiving last year and ended, of course, on New Year's this year. This is also one of the best films of last year, well deserving of its critical and audience acclaim and also its awards consideration it has gotten to date, thus far, including the 12 Oscar nominations the film has received, possibly being the main highlight of the awards acclaim and consideration that the film has gotten to date.

reviewText: I waited with great anticipation the past year to see "Lincoln". As time grew near for the movie to be released I heard through the great vine that this move was going to be the best of the year.  Finally it arrives and a  friend and I rush to the the head of the line to purchase our tickets and sadly were told its sold out.  What a GREAT DISAPPOINTMENT to us both, so patiently  we waited another week and at last, we have our tickets in our hands and feel as though we won the Willy Wonka's Golden ticket to the candy factory just to walk away after seeing Lincoln disappointed.  "Lincoln" should have been called just what is was, "The Passing of the 13th Amendment".  I had high hopes and was under the impression Lincoln was going to be more about the his life, but instead in was a segment of his life as President during the passing of the 13th Amendment.  I found it a bit boring at times, it tended to drag on and on, I was grateful that my popcorn was keeping me awake through this portion of the movie. The script was filled with very long winded sentences where one wanted to almost jump in and say  "Slow Down,"  "Inhale", "Take a Breath", the dialogue just bounced from one mouth to another mouth like a ping pong tournament. The dialogue was confusing, not people friendly.Halfway into the movie things start to pick up and my attention was revived.  Although the beginning of this movie was not a eye opener, there are many greats about it.  Daniel Day Lewis, OUTSTANDING performance as LINCOLN, Absolutely OUTSTANDING!  Sally Field portrayed Mary Todd Lincoln, another OUTSTANDING PERFORMANCE.  Her performance was touching, sincere, and realistic.  She showed the  personality of Mary Todd as all as she was; a mother, a grieving mother, a wife to the President, a "women" who  truly loved her husband AND even possibly, a hoot as some thought she was.  I found the scene where she was telling off Thadddeus Stevens ( played by  Tommy Lee Jones) outstanding.  She told him  what she disliked about him, how the people felt about him, compared what he was lacking compared to her husband, yet she was very lady- like  still  leaving Thaddeus with a  splinter in his buns. James Spader's performance was a bit annoying, attempting to come across as being humorous, I found him to be a flop. Thumbs up for the customs, 5 star all around, except for the hideous  wig that  Tommy Lee Jones wore, why they couldn't do a better  on that is beyond me., it was actually humorous it was so bad.  I found the subtitles through out the movie  to be a plus, they confirmed the "who", "where's" and exactly "when's". If you wanted to see how the passing of the 13th Amendment came about, this was truly then a 5 star movie, but for me who was wanting to see more of Lincoln's life be told, I have to admit, I was a bit let down.

reviewText: I am an unabashed Spielberg fan. He has had his share of clunkers like "War Horse" and "1941". reviewText: After seeing this masterwork by Spielberg, and seeing Daniel Day-Lewis'performance-for which he will almost certainly win the Oscar in a couple weeks and which is already becoming legendary-I almost feel sad for any future actors who try to take on the role of the 16th President. Simply put, Daniel Day-Lewis IS Abraham Lincoln now and for all time. He incarnates the Civil War President in this movie in a manner that at times almost gave me the chills. There is one particular scene where he is visiting a battlefield hospital and begins to engage wounded Union soldiers by asking them to give their names first. I had to remind myself that I was watching an actor portray a President who has been dead for nearly 150 years.Day-Lewis and Sally Field as Mary Todd Lincoln broke my heart. In fact everyone from Day-Lewis on down is simply first-rate.There are no assassination scenes(there is a brief deathbed scene) and the name John Wilkes Booth is never even mentioned at all. It's almost as if the director felt the assassin was a footnote.. completely beside the point in the epic life of America's greatest President.After reading about what Steven Spielberg went through to get this film done I am so grateful to him. It's a marvelous accomplishment and I cannot recommend it highly enough.

reviewText: Some may ask why, others may not even consider it, but I personally thought the picture was exciting. Yes, the performance of Daniel Day-Lewis is astonishing, so much so that he is not only capable of avoiding a parodic representation of Lincoln but ultimately capturing the nuances of our 16th President at the same time in a creative fashion. If you thought that "Saving Private Ryan" and "Munich" were too concerned with carnage and not enough with character, you needn't have such a fear going in to see "Lincoln." I admit that the timing of the picture was a bit odd, but why not? The moral of the story is that Spielberg is working against his more sensational instincts and trying very hard to make a film that will not entertain so much as it will inspire memories and spark discussions. I applaud Spielberg for NOT trying too hard to keep the audience's attention; after all, how dumb would it have been to simply make another war movie filled with bloody violence? Haven't we seen enough of that already? No, "Lincoln" is the deeper film, with Spielberg in mature mode, handling the subtleties of characterization splendidly. "Lincoln" is a moderately subjective character portrait and some kind of masterpiece, giving the more sensitive viewers among us the opportunity to watch actors really act and listen to characters as they engage in dialogue rather than physical violence. Quite a good film indeed. And, for what it's worth, I think Lincoln himself would have had the good sense of humor to have approved of this picture (I realize I'm pulling the man and his times out of context, but still...).
summary: This is a memorial from Spielberg to Lincoln...
