reviewText: I looked forward to seeing this brand new film.  I am interesting in history and figured that because Stephen Spielburg was involved with this script and there was so much publicity for it that I was going to love it.  I sure was disappointed.From the beginning which started on a battlefield with Abraham Lincoln and two Union soldiers (one black and one white) making politically correct statements and reciting the Gettysburg address, I must say I raised an eyebrow.  The rest of the film supposedly reenacted Abraham Lincoln's political genius in getting the Emancipation Proclamation through Congress.  It was all about the compromises and political persuasion it took.  We all know how this all turned out of course.The acting was excellent even though Daniel-Day Lewis doesn't really look like Abraham Lincoln.  But as far as I'm concerned it was Tommy Lee Jones cast as Thaddeus Stevens whose performance was the most outstanding.Sally Field was cast as Lincoln's wife but I think the screenwriters went much too far in making her sound like a modern feminist.  I found myself reacting negatively every time she opened her mouth.I also think that the trailer for the film which included a battle scene was misleading.  This was not a film about the War in the field.  It was a about a political war played out in Congress and the audience needed to follow the political arguments between the different factions.I wasn't planning on falling asleep but I found myself dozing off several times which does not make this a film that I"m anxious to recommend.  As I like to read about politics though I will probably read the book.
summary: Much too modern and politically correct

reviewText: Lincoln is based, in part, on the book Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln by historian Doris Kearns Goodwin. The film has an impressive cast including Daniel Day Lewis, Sally Field, Hal Holbrook, James Spader and Tommy Lee Jones and takes you behind the scenes of the Civil War battles on the field ro the political tactics of Lincoln in the push to abolish slavery through the 13th Amendment. The movie also spotlights his personal life with his wife and sons. The stress of the Civil War took its toll on the Lincolns as is evident in his pictures, and a carriage scene in the movie depicts the Lincolns looking forward to better times before the fateful night at Ford Theater. With Lincoln being so loved and despised simultaneously, he is a fascinating figure in history who shaped the course of a nation whose foundation was set on the belief that all men are created equal. This movie contains irreverent foul language and racially prejudiced verbiage which may be offensive to some viewers.

reviewText: Please note that I saw this on a movie channel so that I can't comment on the quality of the DVD release or its features.Lincoln is an exceptional movie but not for everyone as the wordy and archaic dialog will be off-putting for some modern viewers (and as I confirmed by reading several dozen of the reviews). But for those with the patience to stick it out, the movie offers an extraordinary and in-depth account of a brief but defining moment in Lincoln's career--the passing of the 13th amendment to the Constitution. Lincoln shows himself to be the consummate politician as he at turns persuades, cajoles, charms, bullies, threatens, and buys his way to the passage of what at first seems a measure that is doomed to fail. Indeed, at first blush his chances appear well nigh hopeless as even his otherwise faithful cabinet seems to doubt him and even his sanity. But Lincoln's energy, zeal, and sheer craftiness and popularity with the public are no match for his opponents. And when tensions run too high, not the least of his talents is that Lincoln always had a funny story or anecdote to defuse the situation.I was also pleased to see so many fine character actors in various roles (such as Bruce McGill and Walton Goggins) who are not as well known to the general public compared to Tommy Lee Jones, David Strathairn, Hal Holbrook, and David Spader, who had major parts. Jones was superb as the fast talking Thaddeus Stephens and of course Sally Fields is a long way from "The Flying Nun" with her riveting portrayal of Mary Todd Lincoln.Overall a fine movie with a career climaxing and defining performance by Daniel Day-Lewis, who shows that, when it came to Lincoln and his 13th Amendment, that if you were against it, "He will find you!" :-)******Note: An allusion to Day-Lewis's famous line in "Last of the Mohicans."
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you are A. Lincoln, you are the President of the United States.  It's January 1865.  This bloody war has dragged on for 4 years, the forces of the rebellious slave states fiercely fight on, but it's obvious the end is nigh.  It is slavery that has rent the United States apart;  it is slavery that must end.Your Proclamation, two years ago, to free all slaves in states and parts of states that remained in rebellion, is on legally shaky ground.  The war could end with the question of slavery unsettled after the horrendous loss of life and suffering to settle this very issue ... only a change in the Constitution will work.Last year, a proposed 13th amendment to abolish slavery passed the Senate, but failed in the House.  Now that, with the elections over, it may be possible to pass it in the House with the votes from a few lame duck Democrats. . . .Note on ending:  The movie closes with Lincoln delivering an unidentified speech;  it is from his 2nd Inaugural Address.Extras:  "The Journey to Lincoln" - 9 minutes  &  "A Historic Tapestry: Richmond, Virginia" (Blu-ray only) - 4 minutes.Picture (Blu-ray-2013): 4.5,  (DVD): 4.If you don't mind the very slightly lower resolution for the DVD, it does have an advantage if you want to stop the movie and finish it later.  To continue the movie where you left off, press play on your remote.  On the DVD it takes a half a minute, on the Blu-ray its around 3 minutes.  If you had subtitles selected, the DVD will remember that, the Blu-ray does not.Of special note:  If you have someone in your family that is visually impaired, select the "English Descriptive Video Service" option;  it turns on narrative descriptions of scenes and actions.
summary: Great Insight into Lincoln and the 13th Amendment
Title: N/A

reviewText: Director Steven Spielberg brings the last four months of Abraham Lincoln's life into this focused historical epic that had been long in the works.As the Civil War comes to an end, and shortly after Lincoln has won re-election, the president is faced with the process of abolishing slavery with his workings to pass the 13th Amendment through a very divided and partisan House of Representatives.  The genuine concern of this issue is palpable through the screen.The film serves not only as a political drama, but a deep character study of the Lincoln family through the turmoil of war, political impasse and the serious emotional impact of life in the White House.  At two and a half hours long, the film has a steadied and deliberate pace that certainly doesn't rush, but is certainly more concerned with maintaining both interest and reveal.Spielberg re-teams with former Munich collaborators: cinematographer Janusz Kaminski, editor Michael Kahn, screenwriter Tony Kushner and composer John Williams.  They were all nominated for Academy Awards for their work on Lincoln.  The production design, costume design and editing are absolutely remarkable, as big-budget historical epics rely on the excelled success of depicting the past, telling a story out of time, and making it feel and look accurate.  Lincoln succeeds in a great manor.When it comes down to the film, however, more than Spielberg's directing, the impact of the film relies on the layered and masterful performances of its actors.  Daniel Day-Lewis obviously won his third Best Actor Oscar for his role as the president.  He is a powerhouse throughout the whole film, yet, in his chameleon way, he strives for the restrained dignity and humanism of his character.  However, David Straitharn, Tommy Lee Jones, Sally Field, John Hawkes, and Hal Holbrook all give absolutely masterful veteran performances as well.  James Spader and Joseph Gordon-Levitt also deliver noteworthy performances.  This is clearly an ensemble film cast and finished by the hands of a master.The dark, brooding look and feel of the film is paired perfectly with its serious, conversational tone.  This is yet another masterwork from Spielberg, which, at this point in his career, his audience never expects anything less.I watched part of the film on my laptop and the second half through my Playstation on the big screen.  The streaming was clear and the sound was even better, probably not as good as the Blu-ray release, but it didn't disappoint. The nuances of the accents and the breaths between the speeches and stories are affecting and rousing.Great film, highly recommended.  One of the few films I had no qualms paying as much as I used to at the video store to watch.  I would love to re-watch in Blu-ray, which always says something about a film that is worthy to view multiple times.

reviewText: My son has to do a big report about Abraham Lincoln in school this week and Daniel Day-Lewis seems born to play Lincoln. So I broke my resolution not to see another Spielberg movie (see my review of "Schindler's List" if you're interested) and the whole family went to see "Lincoln." This is, I think, very much a lawyer's movie, and my verdict is "not great, but not bad at all." Four stars."Lincoln" wisely does not attempt to offer a sweeping account of the 16th U.S. president's remarkable life and times in its two and a half hour running time. Rather, through its focus on efforts to get the House of Representatives to pass the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution abolishing slavery, it offers a character study of Lincoln as arm-twisting political strategist, Commander in Chief, folk philosopher, husband and father.For a Speilberg movie, "Lincoln" is remarkably quiet. We do see gruesome piles of bodies on the Civil War battlefields, and the requisite Spielberg bursting into song at the moment of triumph. ("Battle Cry of Freedom" is sung on the floor of the House of Representatives after the vote passing the amendment. Contemporary northern newspaper accounts I was able to find indicate that there was much exultation and cheering on the House Floor and around Washington after the vote, but I didn't see anything about Congressmen bursting into song.) In a highly unlikely scene, a racially mixed pair of Union soldiers recites Lincoln's Gettysburg address to him when meeting him so that bit of brilliant oratory can be fit into the movie without taking it out of its early 1865 time frame.Overall, though, Tony Kushner's literate and often stylized script gives us intimate scenes of  Lincoln's interactions with his high-strung wife Mary Todd, with his son Robert, and with his troops. Most screen time is taken up with meetings between Lincoln and his advisers about the need for the amendment as both a legal matter to ensure slavery does not continue after the war and as a step to expedite the war's end, the timing for its passage (before the Southern States are back and able to vote it down), and how to get enough votes from among lame-duck Democratic Congressmen who have been voted out of office to pass the amendment. These detailed analytical discussions will appeal to political junkies and legal scholars, but they may drag a bit for the more casual viewer. Our ten-year-old was fidgety and made frequent trips to the water fountain outside the auditorium.Lincoln is beautifully cast so we enjoy a number of remarkable supporting performances: David Strathairn as Secretary of State William Seward, Sally Field as the neurotic Mrs. Lincoln, Jackie Earle Haley as Confederate Vice President Alexander Stephens, and best of all to my taste, Tommy Lee Jones as radical anti-slavery Republican Congressman Thaddeus Stevens, to name a just few.Day-Lewis is off on another planet as Abraham Lincoln, which is both a brilliant piece of acting and, at least for me, somewhat off-putting. While he does a lovely job capturing Lincoln's intellect, political savvy, folksy humor and cynicism, because he has gone so far away into his character, I often felt that he was calling out to the other characters from a great distance rather than interacting intimately with them. The performance might have worked better in a one-man show. The makeup used to create the deep furrows in his brow seemed strangely immobile.Through "Lincoln" we learn, if we did not already know, that passing controversial legislation is a long hard slog through the mud. It's a great challenge to dramatize a long hard slog through the mud, even when the result is as world-changing as the end of slavery. "Lincoln" does the job about as well as can be expected. I have nothing but praise for Spielberg's keeping a curb bit on his mawkish manipulative tendencies and crowd-pleasing instincts in this smart, well-made movie that will not be to everyone's taste.

reviewText: You shouldn't see this movie/waste your time, but you will...and the makers knew it.  Heck, I watched it even after reading the dismal reviews so who am I to judge?  But I'm tellin' ya, don't do it!At the risk of repeating what others have said, it's dark and hard to see, which is, oh, I dunno, maybe Movie Making 101:  "Allow Your Viewers To Actually See What's Going On".  If Spielberg was going for a somber, dreary, old photo kinda thing, he accomplished that but he did it so well that it's like being locked in a dusty closet.  Movie Making 101A might be, "Let Your Viewers HEAR Your Movie Properly".  The sound levels go from a soft whisper to a loud, dramatic, forced sound so that I was constantly adjusting the level on my laptop and that's also ridiculous and hurt my ears.  If visual and audio are not handled well, a good, strong story can save any movie, really.  But, nope, not here.  It's really true.  The movie should've been called "The 13th Amendment: How It Worked" and slapped into high school civics classes the world over.  (With the unfortunate subtitle:  Lincoln, A Laff A Minute!)The only good thing in the movie is Daniel Day Lewis himself.  Perfect Lincoln and a remarkable actor!  A+++ for you.  But, the story line is so choppy and impossible to follow that I gave up and slept for about 20 minutes and when I awoke, it made no difference that I'd missed a chunk of the movie.  It was still grinding its painfully slow way towards the 13th Amendment.  Lincoln's death scene, or should I say LACK of a proper death scene is unforgivable.  They actually show another play going on in another theatre when the announcement of the shooting comes!  I'm not kidding.  To make him look like a buffoon with his lame jokes at inappropriate times is also unforgivable for such a man.  All in all, I'm furious when the subject matter has such grand potential and the seemingly best are on task to tell the story and then it falls apart.  What ARE you guys smoking up there in Hollywood?  I mean that with all sincerity.Just don't go.  Be the brave one who doesn't care if you don't see the Latest, Greatest Spielberg movie so that you can make up your own mind.  Do it for movie makers everywhere who really do do their jobs and thrill us.  No more bowing and scraping to Spielberg.  Not after this travesty.  Luckily, there are a lot of wonderful alternatives available if you want to know the story of Abraham Lincoln.  This movie isn't one of them.

reviewText: Let's start with the brilliant casting. Daniel Day-Lewis's turn as our sixteenth president is simply magnificent. Throughout the whole movie the viewer completely buys Day-Lewis's vision of Lincoln. Never once is the audience jarred from the movie back to real life by a moment of Day-Lewis's acting. I can't say enough about how he brought Lincoln to life. Sally Fields also did an exceptional job portraying Mary Todd Lincoln and the many demons she wrestled with while in the White House.The movie itself is good, but drags. I enjoy the political machinations that go on behind the scenes while trying to get any controversial bill passed - much less something as important as a Constitutional amendment outlawing slavery! - as much as anyone, but I still thought the movie was too slow. Purely personal taste, but to me this is just one of those movies I really have to be in a certain mood to watch from start to finish in one sitting.I did love the history behind the movie and applaud Spielberg for tackling such a weighty subject without taking too much liberty with the facts. I believe he performed a mighty service by preserving Lincoln's dedication to the anti-slavery cause on film, especially how Lincoln proceeded with a deadly war even while reconciliation with the South was possible if he had simply relented and allowed slavery to continue in the Southern states in a postwar union.More things to like: Lincoln's shrewd political maneuvering even as he appeared to be little more than a folksy charmer on the outside. The portrayal of 19th century lobbyists. Even back then they were sleazy! Again, really good movie just a bit slow.

reviewText: This movie had a lot of good individual parts: a really good cast, a great director, and a National icon.  However, in sum this movie didn't live up to what it could be.  The story focuses on the end of the Civil War and Lincoln's push to get the 13th Ammendment through the House of Representatives.  Lincoln talks about how he used the powers granted to him because of the war, to pass the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing the slaves.  He gives a difficut explanation of why he passed it and what he believes in.  He keeps saying that he follows the rule of law or something like that and how African Americans are viewed as property by law.  This difficult to understand reasoning that he provides is one of the many things that undermine this film from being better.There is a good piece of history in this film and we see Congress and the White House well reproduced.  One thing that is obvious is the White House had no fence and no security.  I knew this from reading Killing Lincoln but it was still amazing to see it portrayed so realistically.I had great difficulty understanding what many of the actors were saying even Sally Field started prattling on with 1865 idioms making her difficult to understand.  So many recognizable faces gave me the same trouble whether it was Hal Holbrook or James Spader.Another thing the movie suffered from was it just got boring at times.  Yes there were dramatic parts as Spader and his crew try to sway some of the Lame Duck Democrats to vote for the Ammendment and we saw that the same corruption that exists in Washington today happened back then.Tommy Lee Jones was excellent in his role though he wears an annoying wig through most of the movie.  Joseph Gordon Levitt is excellent as Lincoln's son who fights with his father over enlisting in the war.Finally, Daniel Day Lewis was a good Lincoln, looking a lot like Lincoln, but his voice didn't sound very Lincolnesque.
summary: This Movie Could Have Been a Lot Better

reviewText: LINCOLN is typical Spielberg---broad in scope, beautifully filmed, and reverently manipulative.It's also tedious and often superfluous, heavy on political drama.  Some of the more intimate scenes are filmed at a distance, lessening their impact.Daniel Day-Lewis perfectly embodies the essence of Lincoln, his sensitivity, fatigue and fierce dedication to his cause.  His Oscar is deserved.  Tommy Lee Jones amd Sally Field also give performances validating their Oscar noms.  The large supporting cast is impressive, especially Joseph Gordon Levitt, James Spader, Jared Harris and David Strathairn.  John Williams score is complimentary and majestic.LINCOLN does demonstrate the importance of the President's influence in America's history and Spielberg's dedication to bringing this to life is admirable indeed.

reviewText: This movie is about only one mere segment of Lincoln's life and times,including his stay in the White House. It is only about his desire to abolish slavery--no--not really. Instead, it is about his use of our constitution to end the war between the states. This movie was not painted with a broad brush. It is too bad that Gore Vidal's great book entitled Lincoln wasn't used as a reference. Perhaps if the title was something less than "LINCOLN", I  could  give it a four or five star rating based on the acting ability of the leads. reviewText: "Lincoln" dramatizes the efforts by President Abraham Lincoln (Daniel Day-Lewis) to push the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, which abolished slavery in the United States, through Congress before the Civil War came to an end and enabled Southern states to block its passage. It takes place over the last few months of Lincoln's life in 1865 and consists primarily of conversations  -or more often arguments- between Lincoln and Secretary of State William Seward (David Straithairn), Lincoln and radical Congressman Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones), Lincoln and Republican party founder Francis Preston Blair (Hal Holbrook), and many more, as the President wheels, deals, lies, bribes resistant Democrats, and misleads Congress to get the votes for the 13th Amendment. His own advisors oppose the plan at first, and second, as a fight he can't win, and prefer to use the threat of the 13th Amendment to pressure the Confederacy into a surrender.Steven Spielberg directed this mess, with a screenplay by playwright Tony Kushner. To say it is talky would miss the mark. It's more prattle than talk. Lincoln is a self-righteous windbag who will put on a speech to whomever will listen. It's not believable that anyone would listen after a while. He's distasteful, preachy, and sometimes pretty silly, as when he goes on about Euclid to some telegraph operators. We feel the weight of the War on Lincoln's shoulders, but he does not seem to be a man grounded in reality. I have no idea how the filmmakers intended Lincoln to come across, but I doubt  their intentions were realized. When "Lincoln" is not mired by its title character, it is bogged down in legal and political intricacies. Some comic relief is provided in the form of Republican lackeys who are charged with buying Democratic votes, but that's not as funny as it should be. Thankfully, Tommy Lee Jones steals his scenes as the radical and outspoken Stevens.Though it is refreshing to see people yell at each other on the floor of Congress, rather than the oppressive politeness we have today, those few scenes can't save the film. "Lincoln" is a political drama without the drama. It is far too long at 2 1/2 hours. The conflict Lincoln has with his son Robert (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) is a pointless distraction, as this is less a biography of Lincoln than a chronicle of Capital Hill politics. The last 20 minutes are a sort of epilogue that should have been cut. The super-dark interiors are super-conspicuous CGI. There is no light in the rooms during the daytime. There is light at the window, but it does not come in, as if some invisible force were repelling it. Lincoln and his advisors are left to read in daylit rooms that are...dark. The out-of-doors suffers a similar problem. Everything is blue, and the lighting conditions are perpetually at dusk. The cast is top-notch, however. I really should swear off new Spielberg films. They're dreadful.
summary: A Political Drama Without the Drama.

reviewText: Lincoln is a good movie overall, but not necessarily a good movie on Lincoln himself. The movie should've really been called Slave liberation or something. The film does give some development and conflict for Lincoln, which is good. If the film were named something different, I would have been fine with it. However, again, it felt like they were more focused on the bill, than on Lincoln. The film would have been better, if it was an epic that spanned across Lincoln's life, from when he was young, up to when he was killed.Overall most of you should like this film. I personally do not care for the set-up. Plus, I'm not a huge fan of period pieces anyway, with a few exceptions.

reviewText: Director Steven Spielberg and screenwriter Tony Kushner adapt a snippet from Doris Kearns Goodwin's award winning book and rewards movie goers with one of the best movies of the year.  Spanning less than 4 months beginning in January of 1865, the film and Lincoln's (remarkable Daniel Day-Lewis) focus is on the passing and ratification of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution which abolishes slavery.The nation was begging for an end to the Civil War which had killed over 600 thousand Americans and nearly destroyed the economy.  Although Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation theoretically freed the slaves, Lincoln knew it was a wartime fiat that he feared would not pass muster in peacetime.  He was reluctant to end the war until the Amendment solidified his position.  This was not an easy task.Although his conservative Republicans were against slavery some were concerned this might lead to further rights such as voting.  If trying to hold his own majority party in line wasn't difficult enough he had to convince 20 Democrats to also vote his way.  As a result he was forced to strike a deal with Thaddeus Stevens (Tommy Lee Jones), a Democratic abolitionist to wrangle a few votes.All the while Lincoln was dealing with his wife Mary (wonderful Sally Field) who was still trying to manage her grief after losing her son two year earlier.  Spielberg for the most part, spares the audience the theatrics and focuses on the character of the president and his folksy way of garnering support.  Adept at story telling Lincoln manages to conjure up just the right yarn to make his point.In one scene Lincoln is about to send a telegram to Gen. Grant to bring the Southern peace delegation to Washington, something he does not want to do until the amendment passes.  With only the telegraph operator and an engineer present he asks them if they are familiar with Euclid's common notion.  He then quotes the theory of how if things are equal to the same things they are also equal to each other.  This is a self-evident truth of mathematics.  He decides not to have the delegation come to Washington.The great enjoyment of this educational and entertaining film is the great words, the great acting and the great moviemaking.  Oscar will be kind.
summary: 4 1/2 stars:  Great words.  Great acting.  Great moviemaking

reviewText: Make no mistake about it, Lincoln is a movie full of talking, talking and more talking. There is very little action, but the script and acting are second to none. It also somehow found room for some really good humor. Sure the history is off here and there and it does have a few moments where it seems to drag, but Steven Spielberg has crafted a fine telling of the last months of Lincoln's life and the passing of the 13th Amendment to abolish slavery.Daniel Day-Lewis spent a year preparing for this role and not only does he look like Lincoln (you don't even have to squint your eyes) he pours every ounce of facial and vocal expression to the point where you can't take your eyes off him when he's on screen. He speaks both softly and wisely, with a good story always ready to share with others. I think come February he will be the first man to win 3 lead acting Oscars (he should have won for Gangs of New York too). Sally Field, Hal Holbrook, James Spader and countless other familiar faces are all excellent, but Tommy Lee Jones stands out the most of the supporting cast. You can't help but love his character and he supplies many of the laughs.I'll admit that without the fine performances the movie would likely be a tad on the boring side since it's all word play and no explosions, but due to the dedication put forth you will feel like you've been transported to back to 1865.4 and 1/2 out of 5 stars
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have read so much about Abraham Lincoln that I'm certainly not surprised that this film just covers his second term in office.  While it announces his death, Spielberg spares us the scene which has been shown many times before.  Who wants to see his death when you can see his life?Daniel Day-Lewis is Abraham Lincoln incarnate.  Daniel Day-Lewis is to male acting what Meryl Streep is to female acting.  Both of them transport you into their roles as though you, yourself, are seeing out of their eyes.Spielberg has made an essential film which will always live in the lofty atmosphere of "Schindler's List."Lincoln had messy hair and he hated when it was neat.  He challenged any tall man to stand back-to-back with him and his six foot, three and three quarter inch height usually made him the victor.  Lincoln was undoubtedly the strongest president we ever had.  He had more physical altercations than any professional fighter and came away with a better record than most.OK, there was too little time in this film to dwell on the stuff that made Lincoln a very funny and entertaining man.  To do Lincoln real justice, that other American jewel named Tony Kushner (Angels in America), would have had to have given us another six hour film that could only have been made for the small screen.If you want to know A. Lincoln as few others do. If you want a real treat, read Carl Sandburg's "Abraham Lincoln," and don't you dare read the short version.  Read all six volumes.  It will be one of the top experiences of your life.  A Carl Sandburg sentence is a marvel to behold and the film LINCOLN by Kushner-Spielberg-Day-Lewis & Co. is a gift to the American people of the highest value.ARGO f-yourself took the Academy Award for Best Picture, but LINCOLN was the best picture of 2012 by a country mile.I would be remiss if I did not mention Sally Field for her thoughtful portrayal of Mary Todd-Lincoln.  I throw my hat in the air in celebration of James Spader's representation of W.N. Bilbo.  Hal Holbrook and John Hawkes added importantly to the film.Tommy-Lee Jones has played his best role to date as Thaddeus Stevens.  Kudos and plaudits to Mr. Jones who has the most expressive face in film today.

reviewText: I am anxiously awaiting the release of this DVD. The movie was accurate to a fault, but leave it to Spielberg to go to the extent of using the sound of the actual doors opening of the real courthouse in the story , of the creaking sounds of the actual floor creaking, and even the sound of a person as they stood from the pew where Lincoln actually sat in real life and putting these sounds into the film. Daniel Day Lewis was superb but he seems to like to play roles in historical movies (The Last of the Mohicans), and although I have never been a strong Sally Fields fan her personality flaws as Mary Todd Lincoln seemed totally believable. As an added plus I thought it was tasteful not to go into much detail of the assassination itself, it is almost as if the movie was really focused on the emancipation itself with Lincoln's death marking the end of that period in history. Soundtracks don't often catch my attention but even that seemed to fit the mood of the moment beautifully. I truly hope others enjoyed this movie half as much ss I did.

reviewText: Oh, Boy.  What a fascinating take on Abraham Lincoln.  Shrewd, humorous, political savvy up the wazoo, and kind, sensitive, considerate and tough all in one tall, lanky personage that gave our country more than we could have ever thanked him properly for.  An interesting take on Mary Tood Lincoln and for this interrpretation, Sally Field did some fine acting.  The battle scenes were horrific, the losses suffered on each side dreadful and explicitly emphasized why "War is Waste".  The shifting around in the scenes was a bit irritating at first, but as things proceeded, you were drawn into each scene as each character was filled in and shown who they were and how they felt on the events of the time.  Daniel-Day Lewis gave a fine performance.  Tommy Lee Jones performed the crafy, political savvy rustic coot to perfection.  Steven Spielberg? Another "Bravo!  Bravo!"
summary: Ladies and Gentlemen, the President of the United States!

reviewText: Against my better judgement, saw this in the theater and it was all I could do to keep from screaming.  As a founding member of the National Civil War Center at LSU, I studied Lincoln quite a bit years ago.  I have no idea who this guy wearing the black suit is in this movie, but it most certainly isn't Abraham Lincoln.  This is what Hollywood and the modern political left would like to THINK Abraham Lincoln was like, but this IS NOT Lincoln.  It is a well-made movie, dull at times, but since so many people will take this as historically accurate, it bothers me when they make movies like this.  Decent movie, but it's a complete work of fiction and doesn't portray Lincoln, in his actions or his personal convictions, with any accuracy whatsoever.
summary: Once again, historical garbage passed off as history.

reviewText: The cast is a who's who of actors and they all comport themselves with brilliance. Understated where the character requires it, bombastic when it suits. Daniel-Day Lewis performs the role of his career as Lincoln, Sally Field is extraordinary as Lincoln's wife, as are the children who portray their sons.One is a voyeur into the lives of these people, and it is sometimes uncomfortable to watch, but never overwrought.The political scenes are brilliantly done, and you really get inside the political world of the period.This film spans the last few months before Lincoln is assassinated, and concerns itself with the ending of the Civil War and the Anti-Slavery Bill.This film should be shown in every school in America, so we are reminded of what one human being can do to another, based on colour, race, religion, mode of dress, sexuality, whether 200 years ago or today. The moral of the film remains utterly relevant.A must-see for all.
summary: Lincoln as he has never been seen - sublime, brilliant

reviewText: In recent years, movies centering on historical figures have turned out sloppy (The Iron Lady, J. Edgar) mostly due to the trend of packing a life story into two hours. Speilberg wisely avoids that mistake by focusing on the biggest accomplishment of Lincoln's presidency and the battle to get it done.Here, finally, is a historical drama that is actually well written and directed in addition to having great performances by the cast.This is probably the second most restrained film of Speilberg's career. There is very little melodrama in this film's two and a half hour running time. Even John William's score is mostly quiet, creating a contemplative mood in its viewers, underscoring the mindset of the film's central character.Even though the film focuses mostly on one month in the life of Abraham Lincoln, his life story comes through in his interactions with Mary, Tad, Robert, Seward and others, providing a more complete sense of who Lincoln was than in any other film about him.This is definately a must see film (eventually a must own film in my blu-ray collection) and one that deserves every accolade it should (and most likely will) win.
summary: This is how you make a historical drama

reviewText: Daniel Day-Lewis's near miraculous recreation of Lincoln in Spielberg's dramatization of the last few months of Lincoln's presidency may very well bring him his third Oscar in a leading role. He has strong competition from Denzel Washington, for Flight, who is my pick for this year's best actor, but Day-Lewis's brilliant depiction of America's greatest President, during his finest hour in office, is the most "Oscar friendly" performance this year. This is a perfect role for a richly deserving actor to break that "Two-Oscar-Barrier" for a starring role that has eluded the greatest actors in history from Gary Cooper, Marlon Brando and Spencer Tracy to Dustin Hoffman and Jack Nicholson.To see Daniel Day-Lewis's inspired performance as America's great statesman is to witness the re-birth of a deeper, more involved form of acting, that can only be called a small cinematic miracle. To Spielberg's credit, and to his costume and production design staff, we once again see a supremely capable actor vanishing completely into his part. The transformation is as authentic and enthralling as any in film history. There were moments in this film, when the recreation of the president and his time were so well done that the film seemed like a collection of lost footage of the actual President. The magic of this reconstruction of Lincoln and his time is so complete that at moments I felt as though I had gone back in time to eavesdrop into Lincoln's life, to see how the great man really looked, walked, and talked.The script, grave and full of high matters as it is, focuses on Lincoln's adeptness at playing the political game with his grit and honesty to pass a crucial bill that changes the country forever. The dramatic power of Lincoln's patient resolve, his unstinting instinct for justice and political gamesmanship, this meeting of high ideals and shrewdness in the face of the peculiar breed of political realities he faces shows how one individual can transcend conflict and partisanship for much larger ideals. This exceedingly difficult moment in American history, during the waning years of the civil war, is the right occasion for Lincoln's high ideals, his "true north", to take possession of the national consciousness. This movie is a reminder of how even the grim reality of a darkened world must ultimately make way for the larger ideals of a man of courage and high resolve.The excellence of the character portrayal of the great man, the brilliant evocation of the period of the civil war, however, seemed to stand in stark contrast to the relative ordinariness of the overall film. While Lincoln is dramatically compelling, "Lincoln" does get bogged down in the dramatization of the intricacies and elaborate negotiations behind Lincoln's quest to find twenty additional votes needed to amend the constitution to outlaw slavery before the end of the war. There are many moments during the film when I thought the dialogue gets tired and blunts the dramatic tension of the behind-the-scene political maneuverings.The film has all the ingredients for the makings of an unforgettable film but where it is strong on character and spectacle it is relatively weak at crucial moments in the larger telling of the story. The film just does not succeed in distilling the emotional resonance of this compelling moment of history. The all round brilliance of the main cast and its supporting acting talent from David Strathaim to Tommy Lee Jones fails to lift the film from the relatively flat setting up of the political story that unfolds.The film succeeds in flashes when it shows how Lincoln's family drama compounds rather than alleviates his political problems during crucial moments in his Presidency. These inspired moments come with a detailed rendering of Lincoln's spiritual resilience when it is tested to its limits. The crises being handed down to him by the day, by the hour, only ends up igniting Lincoln's legendary tact and patience. The great magic of this piece of cinema is how it sustains our interest in its brilliant reconstruction of both the public figure and the great man in his private life despite the pitfalls of the laborious story.In sum, "Lincoln" has periods of dramatic dullness largely rescued by Daniel Day-Lewis's inspired recreation of Lincoln, the man and statesman. The patience, wisdom, and political largeness of Lincoln's example shine through in a commanding rendition of Lincoln by an astonishing Day-Lewis performance. The gravity of Day-Lewis's gestures, his slow dignified movements, the near high pitched deliberative, drawl of his speech, goes beyond being just Lincolnesque; it as if a resurrected Lincoln moves before our eyes on screen. The actor, the recreated President, looms imposingly and rescues the film to a large degree.

reviewText: "Lincoln" (2012 release; 150 min.) is the latest Steven Spielberg-directed historical drama (others include Schindlers' List and Saving Private Ryan, just to name those). Not knowing much more besides having seen the trailer for is a few times, I really didn't know what to expect, and was eagerly looking forward to seeing it.Here is what I got: first and foremost, despite the name of the movie, this is NOT a movie about Lincoln as such. Instead it is a historical drama in which Lincoln plays a significant role, and the movie is roughly set up in two major parts: (i) the first half introduces the various characters and ref;lects the debate whether or not the 13th Amendment (abolishing slavery) should be passed before the looming end of the Civil War, and why Lincoln felt it was paramount that it was indeed voted on before the end of the war, and (ii) the second half of the movie focuses primarily on what the Republican-controlled House of Representatives needed to do to get 20 Demcratic votes to vote "yes", so as to get to the 2/3 majority required for passing a Constitutional Amendment, and how President Lincoln orchestrated it all. Lincoln seduces, cajoles, begs, tyrannizes, and even offers bribes (in the form of patronage jobs) to get the required votes. In that sense, this is a movie with a very narrow scope, even if brought on an epic scale.A few additional thoughts: Daniel Day-Lewis is nothing short of brilliant in his portrayal of Lincoln, and I would be shocked if he didn't at least get an Oscar nomination for this (and he might very well win). The other acting surprise is of course Sally Field as Lincoln's wife: in the (too-short) screen time she is given, Field brings a fiery performance. The scene/argument between the President and his wife relative to their oldest son wanting to join the Army is one of the more dramatic of the entire movie and it didn't even have to do with the main theme of the movie (passing of the 13th Amendment). I really enjoyed this movie, although I thought it was a bit over-long at 2 1/2 hours and could've benefited from some tighter editing. Kudos also to John Williams for a very understated, almost sober, yet very fine music score for this film. Lincoln is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

reviewText: Daniel Day Lewis best actor of My Left Foot does an awesome performance of AbrahamLincoln.Bonus Features Include:◦The Journey To Lincoln - Steven Spielberg and his collaborators discuss the challenges and excitement of bringing this story of a complex and very human president to the screen.◦A Historic Tapestry: Richmond, Virginia - Steven Spielberg and team discuss the historical significance of Richmond, Virginia, and why they chose to shoot the film there.◦In The Company Of Character - Delve into Daniel Day-Lewis' portrayal of Lincoln, and discover the authenticity and openness created by the actors and filmmakers on set.◦Crafting The Past - Examine the re-creation of Lincoln's era through authentic period details in production design, costume and makeup.◦Living With Lincoln - Follow Steven Spielberg, the cast and crew through the shooting of the film, from the battle at Jenkins' Ferry, through the epic 13th Amendment showdown in the House of Representatives, to Lincoln's tragic end.◦In Lincoln's Footsteps - Explore the film's editing, sound design, and the subtle yet poignant musical score by John Williams, and discover how relevant and inspiring Lincoln still is today.

reviewText: As a civil war historian, I was curious to see how this film was going to play out. I think this country has turned the Romantic Notion of Lincoln into myth, and has not seriously engaged all his political maneuverings, idiosyncrasies, and suppression of constitutional rights. He did some great things, do not get me wrong, but he also had a dark side that most people don't want to talk about. Combined with that, modern American culture (Hollywood in particular) loves to denigrate and stereotype the South as redneck racists and whatnot. So, I was curious to see how fair and balanced historically this film would be. There have been many numerous historical critiques of this film. There are well documented reviews out there that some of this film is sheer fiction. I won't go into that. I understand the need for creative license for the sake of telling the story.Factual inaccuracies aside, I found the film interesting. The portrayal of Lincoln as a human being, particularly his family life with a wife who had all sorts of behavior and mental problems is worth watching. We often want to view Lincoln as this knight in shining armor or something, and he was a man like any other man. I don't think they got his accent right. He would have had a very crude, Kentucky backwoods accent that was often described as "nasally" and high pitched. Day Lewis portrays him as a much more regal, deep voice, which I found odd, but that's just casting. I did appreciate the way Day Lewis tried to portray Lincoln as a storyteller that would constantly tell these yarns and off color anecdotes that often drove people crazy about him. That is accurate. I was somewhat unhappy that the casting could not find a Southerner (what few there were actually in the film) with an actual Southern accent. This is typical of Hollywood. But this film is more about the North, so that is just a side irritation.Again, it is worth watching, though I think it ran a bit long (almost 2.5 hours). It got bogged down a bit in a few places and could have used a bit more editing. I felt there were some scenes that could have been cut that were not really in keeping with the actual plot.
summary: Fair, but wasn't as great as I was expecting

reviewText: I might be speaking out of term here, but I hope that this film can achieve even just a portion of the historical significance in the film-making world as the events it portrays have in our nation's antiquity.Star Daniel Day-Lewis is rightly celebrated for his portrayal of Abraham Lincoln.  Off the top of my head, I can think of no actor who has done better in disappearing into his or her role.  When I do stop and think about it, this man is still among the best.  Our 16th President came to life on the screen nearly 150 years after that fateful night at Ford's Theater.Another actor who must be celebrated for disappearing into his role is Tommy Lee Jones, who played Congressman Thaddeus Stevens.  Mr. Jones is one of those actors who I can usually readily recognize from their first on-screen appearance.  This film is the exception.  Instead of the actor who's played gruff lawmen, rogue CIA agents, high-ranking military officials, etc., I saw a man truly passionate about a cause which he intended to see through to the end.I have no opinion either way of Sally Field and her portrayal of First Lady Mary Todd Lincoln.  I guess my problem with her is that she didn't contribute anything to the agenda in the film...mainly passing the 13th Amendment to the Constitution and abolishing slavery once and for all.  But in the name of historical accuracy, I'm glad she was in this film and based on what I know about her, Sally Field portrayed her struggles quite well.  I ultimately applaud the performance.Overall, the cast as a whole did great.  A genuine effort was made on everyone's part to make this film as historically accurate as possible.  Even director Steven Spielberg, a man known for going the extra mile for the sake of historical accuracy when it matters (i.e. Saving Private Ryan), has outdone himself here.  I mean, he got one of his crew to record the ticking sounds of Abraham Lincoln's actual pocket watch to incorporate them into the film.The story too was great.  Sure, things were a bit slow at times, but those were short times and had to be included because events like that actually happened.  I loved the trailer for this film.  It was obvious that Spielberg took the most riveting lines and scenes and put together a great preview to draw in his audience.  My favorite parts of the movie were when those lines and scenes were put into full context, increasing their already five-star awesomeness.I also liked learning about where things like the famous phrase "we hold these truths to be self-evident that all men are created equal" came from.  While I can't be sure if all these origins are in fact true, the fact that Spielberg is directing lends a certain validity to the accounts.  I'm definitely inspired to research this stuff further.In the end, I definitely recommend this film as well as the bookTeam of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincolnby Doris Kearns Goodwin.  The film is great, but only a part of the book inspired it...there's a lot more in the latter.  Definitely watch and read both.  Enjoy.

reviewText: An education in American history and in modern filmmaking. I'm no expert in either of these areas but left the big screen venue feeling intellectually satisfied.I did detect some strange anachronisms, though, namely the overtly "feminist"(yet conspicuously prissy), Mary, and an unnecessary concluding scene with Tommy Lee Jones (yes, he should get an Oscar) and Mrs. Lincoln's the African-American assistant at 1600. I think Speilberg made his statement without any semi-patronizing confirmation of Thaddeus Stevens' motives and vision.I was most impressed when I learned that, yes, the problems continued after the Emancipation Proclamation and it took a mass of political battering rams to "codify" the new way of Life. An adjustment to the white guy/slave holder-written Constitution was needed. Lincoln was willing to risk impeachment over, not necessarily illegal, but "corrupt" maneuvers, to influence the other side.All actors do very well. However, the child "Todd", despite his battlefield play attire, and his childlike glorification of the monsterous conflict not far from his door, a tragedy which seemed to have no end, comes off just a little strange in his last scene (in public on April 14th): his reaction to the tragic announcement simply stretches credulity. reviewText: Daniel Day Lewis, Sally Field, and Tommy Lee Jones were the stars of this movie.  This film was unusual in that it really centered on Lincoln's efforts to pass the thirteenth amendment which freed the slaves.  Of course the terrible Civil War was the foremost challenge of his term, but most of this movie is how Lincoln and those close to him went about trying to garner votes for a very controversial amendment.  This is really the first time I've seen Lincoln in a different light.  He comes across as not the eloquent speaker of the Gettysburg Address, but most of the time he is seen as a bumpkin, using bad grammar, telling off color jokes, and really putting across a more human side rather than the larger than life image that we hear about.  Mostly he acted this way around his close advisors and his wife, Mary, and he never appeared shaken and that is probably why the jokes and stories.  It was to deflect from the terrible things that were going on around him.  Sally Field in her role as Mary Lincoln really captures her in looks, mannerisms, and is the long suffering depressed woman that we know.  Tommy Lee Jones as Thaddeus Stephens, the very passionate Congressman who supported Lincoln and the thirteenth amendment did a good job.  I almost didn't recognize him!  Of course, I feel that Daniel Day Lewis was very deserving of Best Actor.  He always seems to do character roles very well.  I'm mindful of Christy Brown(My Left Foot)and Hawkeye(Last Of The Mohicans).

reviewText: All of us know about Abraham Lincoln,  The Gettysburg Address, the Emancipation Proclomation, the Civil War,and his assassination. But, few of us, knew him. I read Doris Kearns Goodwin book on Lincoln, and, I thought I knew a little bit about him. However, Daniel Day Lewis, has given us the real deal!I loved ths film.  Lincoln was performed by Daniel Day-Lewis with such a calm self-confidence. He had the world's worries on his shoulders, and, the man, is more than I can bear, little education, except what he learned from borrowed books. He explained Euclid's theory of two things that are equal to an engineer with such ease. His speeches are long remembered, and Daniel Day Lewis brought the man to life. Sally Field plays Lincoln's wife with extraordinary insight. Many famous character actors appear, but Tommy Lee Jones as Rep.Thaddeus Stevens is simply superb!The film focuses on the last 13 months of Lincoln's life. From the war through the Emancipation Proclomation through to his assassination. A truly superb production by Steven Spielberg and written by Tony Kushner. The politics of the day are just as rough and shoddy as today's. We hear The Gettysburg Address and it brings tears and pride.Superb,terrific film. Highly Recommended. prisrob 03-28-13

reviewText: I haven't been out to a film in a real theater in a long time.  It took something as promising as "Lincoln" to get me to drive to my local cineplex, stand in line, sit way up close in one of the few remaining seats and sit through seemingly interminable previews.  After all, who doesn't love Abraham Lincoln and Daniel-Day Lewis?Be aware that this isn't a biopic of Lincoln's life.  It focuses on one event in his life,  his attempt to pass the 13th Amendment to the Constitution and thereby to abolish slavery.  There is passing reference to ending the Civil War but that seems almost like a side issue.  The parallels to the trials of our present President are interesting.  Here is a second term President, newly re-elected, with an iron will to pass through his own initiatives but is faced with opposition in the House of Representatives.  The Amendment has already passed the Senate some time earlier.  In this case it's the Republicans who are on the side of justice and equality for Blacks and the Democrats who are opposing it.  It would be fun to see the film with Obama and hear his reactions.There is a lot of talk.  It's more discussion than action so be prepared. And it's long.  Personally I would have liked more personal glimpses of Lincoln and his family.  We do see views of Mary Todd Lincoln, played by Sally Field. One of the most interesting scenes to me was the fight between them regarding letting their son enlist in the service.  This was the only scene in which we see Lincoln as a tad less than saintly, but only a tad.  The rest of the time, he was consistently wonderful.  The man probably was so but I actually got a little tired of it, especially his cute-folksy routine.  This is not a fault of Lincoln, nor of Daniel Day-Lewis, the splendid actor, but of the script and Spielberg, I think.The actors are all good.  As another reviewer commented, though, I kept seeing Sally Field up there, acting, rather than Mary Lincoln.  I have to admit, too, that I felt the same about DDL.  He almost overdid it, in my not-so humble opinion.  Likewise Tommy Lee Jones, another of my favorite actors.  He is very funny and steals every scene in which he appears but I have to wonder how accurate this portrayal was of the actual person.  I also wondered if his last scene (I won't spoil it by giving details) was of a real event. His wig is a little over the top.The film is nothing if not respectful, indeed adulatory, of a wonderful man.  To state the obvious, there is not a lot of tension for the viewer since the main problem was to pass the amendment and we all know how that turned out.  If a person had never heard of Abraham Lincoln, if such a person exists and would see this film, he would be blown away by this character.  To us it's a little underwhelming.  It is worth seeing, preferably in the comfort of your own home, with plenty of snacks, and with friends with whom you can comment about the actors.  "Sally Field put on weight for the role," "look, there's Hal Holbrook!"  I'd tempted to give it three stars but lest I be accused of deep unpatriotism, I'm giving it four.

reviewText: Daniel Day Lewis and Sally Field are too of the finest actors in the business, and here neither dissapoints. Lewis' performance is a wonder to behold. He is truly great playing Lincoln, and it's pretty impressive to see. Field, while superb has had much greater performances to speak of in numerous more noteworthy pictures, especially her work in films including Sybil, and Steele Magnolia's. Speilberg's directing is excellent, the script also excellent. Production values, sets, costumes, ect. are fantastic. However the film is painfully slow, but the payoff is pretty good if you are not expecting to see any action to speak of at all. This is a character study and it excells brilliantly with that. It was also a bit dissaponting to me that I was hoping to see the actual event when president Lincoln was actually shot by John Booth. But instead it appears Speilberg felt it would be in better taste to make the audience aware of it through a messenger who appears bearing the terrible news. Perhaps that's respectable now that I think about it. But ultimately 'Lincoln' is a very slow and rather boring movie.

reviewText: An awfully good movie distinguished by exceptionally good acting led by Daniel Day Lewis' justly praised performance as Lincoln.  Several other performances are compelling, notably Sally Field as Mary Lincoln, David Staitharn as the shrewd and urbane William Seward, and Tommy Lee Jones, whose tendency to chew scenery is used to very good effect in his depiction of the admirable Thaddeus Stevens.  More than anything else, this is a movie about Washington politics.  Day Lewis portrays Lincoln as an accomplished practical politician pursuing transcendent moral ends, willing to do anything short of outright bribery to secure passage of the 13th Amendment.  In addition to the high level of acting, this movie is distinguished by considerable attention to historical detail and a number of superb scences featuring Spielberg's considerable talents as a director.  The movie climaxes with the roll call vote for the 13th Amendment; a powerful and suspenseful setpiece capped by a chorus of the great Unionist song, Battle Cry of Freedom.While this movie certainly shows the tremendous racism of the period, it doesn't give a good sense of why even the conservative wing of the Republican party, and by extension, a significant majority of voters in the Northern states, were willing to abolish, as opposed to contain, slavery.  The latter was the pre-war default position of the Republicans.  These men were quite conscious of the USA's status as a republican-democratic experiment in a world dominated by monarchies and autocracies.  Over the course of the Civil War, many in the North concluded that only the extirpation of slavery would safeguard the Republic and were willing to tolerate a world with many, many free African-Americans.

reviewText: The word FREEDOOM means so much more to me now after watching this movie. This movie is about our 16th president Abraham Lincoln (Daniel Day-Lewis) felt that slavery is wrong so he led the Union (non-slavery states) to fight the slavery states to end slavery. This is our country's civil war. The civil war is going strong and many soldiers die from both Union States and Non Union States. Everybody wants the war to end. However, President Lincoln needs to pass the 13th amendment to outlaw slavery before he ends the war. This movie really brings our history to life. I did not understand fully what slavery is all about. Watching this movie helps me understand and realize how import freedom is. So many soldiers died for freedom.The actors in this movie are awesome. Daniel Day-Lewis did an excellent job of portraying Mr. Lincoln. His mannerism and movements are so like the 1800s. It seems like they made him a little bit taller. Tommy Lee Jones does an excellent job portraying Thaddeus Stevens. Also, Sally Field as Mrs. Lincoln totally fits the role. The make-up and wardrobes are so unbelievable. Daniel Day-Lewis looks just like Mr. Lincoln with all the lines on his forehead and the wrinkle skin. The most amazing make-up is Thaddeus Stevens.The cinematography in this movie is mostly done in natural light. In 1865 there is no electricity, so the setting must be dark with candles as light. My favorite part of this movie is when the politicians are bargaining for votes. My favorite character is Mr. Lincoln.  He holds his emotions so well. He has a goal of passing the 13th amendment and he did his best to pass it and end the war. He instructs his general to treat the enemy with respect and release them to go home and not to jail. He is such an awesome person.I rate this movie 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 13 and up due to some body parts and blood. Cheyenne N, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.Video review available at kidsfirst dot org

reviewText: Lincoln in 1861- "I understand a proposed amendment to the Constitution . . . has passed Congress, to the effect that the Federal Government shall never interfere with the domestic institutions of the States, including that of persons held to service. I have no objection to its being made express and irrevocable."Lincoln in 1862,  "If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it, and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone I would also do that.." I guess he changed his mind....Lincoln- before seeing the movie I thought this was about the Emancipation Proclamation and the entire Lincoln admin. It is not. It is mostly about JAN 1865 and the 13th amendment freeing the slaves. The Emancipation Proclamation, from 2 years earlier only "freed" slaves in the south, where Lincoln had no jurisdiction, and no means of enforcement, but not in Maryland Delaware, DC, Pennsylvania, etc and many other places where Lincoln did! It kept the British and French from intervening on the part of the South, which they were planning to do. The other practical effect was to end enforcement of the Dred Scott case, and the Fugutive Slave Act, one of the worst pieces of legislation ever but that's another story. Even as Lincoln is crafting the amendment, he has slaves everywhere serving him...Slavery is, of course, wrong and evil. We see that now, but its wasn't so obvious to people in the Civil war.  People on both sides.  Slavery just was, like the sun coming up. These days most Civil War revisionist movies show a army of right thinking liberals and abolitionists going south to show southerners the error of their ways. Not accurate at all. This movie shows in vivid detail the varying opinions in the North from people who just wanted the long war over and had never thought out the implications of winning the war and as a result freeing the slaves. When asked by Lincoln what they thought about freedom for slaves, one couple says "ni....s would just steal our chickens and then fight our men for their jobs". Some couldn't care less about blacks, some want no freedom at all just an end to the four year war, some don't want blacks competing with whites for jobs, somewhat some limited freedom short of citizenship and some like the Thaddeus Stevens (wonderfully played by Tommy Lee Jones in a wig) want the full rights that blacks enjoy now and there is every opinion in between.It is worth noting that about a third of the Union Army deserted after the Emancipation Proclamation. According to their dairies, most in the Army said they fought to preserve the Union and very few were actually abolitionists.The movie shows Daniel Day Lewis is eerily masterful as Lincoln. Lincoln wants full freedom in the constitution and he wants it now while the war is ending . And like a modern day LBJ, he knows who to cajole, who to threaten and who to plead with. He tells his homespun witticisms and stories endear or annoy congressmen until one threatens to throw something at him to get him to stop. There is true debate here in Congress, Stevens calls another senator a lizard with green slime in his veins and clear proof that "all men are not created equal" because he is so dumb, or words to that effect. Lewis has Lincoln's walk and his stoop shouldered stance and his world-weary craggy face. Sally Fields plays Mary Todd Lincoln and is nominated for supporting actress. Sharp tongued, depressive, flighty. The real Mary Lincoln wasn't that outspoken with Lincoln's political opponents. That would have been unladylike.Not explicitly stated here is why Lincoln was in a hurry. He had no intention of punishing the South after the war. He believed in "malice toward none, with charity for all". It was the Republicans who would disenfranchised all men who fought for the South for a decade after the war, to punish the South for Lincoln's death and the war.  Had men in the South been able to vote on the 13th amendment it might not have passed...A lot of dark "available light" oil lamp shots (the light bulb not having been invented yet) . This movie was mostly shot in Richmond VA (!) where a lot of federalist style buildings remain. There is a scene supposedly the shelling of Richmond and the burning of the Tredegar Iron Works that look like Spielberg actually lit up the real building, still on the banks of the James River waterfront.Very good, very authentic all things considered, very complex. Hopefully this movie will open people's eyes to the complexities of the Civil war, even if I wish it had started earlier with Emancipation. Best Actor- Day-Lewis. Odds-on favorite to win it all, the kind of movie the Academy likes.By the way, soldiers who actually fought in the Civil War or people lived thru those times thought "Birth of a Nation" and later "Gone with the Wind" were the most accurate movies ever done about the period! Now liberals shun these movies. Now we have mostly revisionism. This movie isn't revisionist, for the most part it's accurate

reviewText: I was surprised to see some professional critics remark that the film was nothing but a dry historical lesson. When I went to the theater, I found myself fully immersed in the film for all of its 150 minutes. Like any great movie, it tells a story very much worth telling in a fashion that's completely absorbing and gripping even if we know the outcome. Daniel Day-Lewis' performance is as terrific and deserving of all the awards he won for the part. He creates a performance that feels so lived in and real that he completely embodies our 16th President for all of the film's running time. His Lincoln is a sort mischievous storyteller who has both a folksy charm and a commanding presence, and it's easy to see why the nation loved him. Supporting performances are equally strong, and include Sally Field as Mary Todd Lincoln, Tommy Lee Jones as abolitionist Thaddeus Stevens, David Strathairn as Lincoln's secretary of state, and Joseph Gordon Levitt as Robert Todd Lincoln. The cast is filled with one remarkable performer after another. Scene stealers include Lee Pace, Michael Stuhlbarg, Walton Goggins, and of course, James Spader who creates a remarkably funny character. Spielberg doesn't get enough credit for his masterful direction and Tony Kushner's screenplay is a fascinatingly well constructed work. I could go on discussing the wonderful jobs by all of the film's crew but I won't. Needless to say, each of the film's 12 Academy Award nominations were well deserved and the film deserved more wins that it had on Oscar night.The Blu-ray looks amazing, as should any recent production. Janusz Kaminski's cinematography is perfectly replicated on this Blu-ray disc which is sharp, detailed, and very film-like. The film's soundtrack is equally well replicated in 7.1-channel DTS-HD Master Audio.As you can probably tell, I loved the film enough to spring for the pricier 4-disc edition which includes a bonus disc of special features. In total, they run about 80-minutes. As always, the supplements on Spielberg's films are well produced, but I was disappointed there wasn't more. For a film dealing with such great historical significance and what I imagine was a huge production, the extras could and probably should've gone on for another two hours. They could have explored the real life Lincoln and passing of the 13th Amendment, and taken a more detailed approach to documenting the film's production. But what we get is great stuff and worth the purchase for fans of the film.In summation, an excellent film. One of the very finest of 2012 and an excellent Blu-ray.
summary: Masterfully told movie, Great on Blu-ray!

reviewText: To one who's expecting an action adventure, this film would surely be a disappointment.  To anyone who enjoys history or politics, though, it's an wonderful movie, well worth watching.  Like many movies, I felt this one started off a bit slow, but once I got all the characters sorted out and exactly what the Thirteenth Amendment was all about, it became very interesting.  The actors and the directing were all excellent, and the writing seemed very historically-accurate, also.  For example, I've always read that Lincoln's voice was rather high and thin, but this is the first movie I've seen where Lincoln wasn't played by a baritone.  Daniel Day Lewis was highly convincing, as was Sally Field as his wife, Mary Todd Lincoln.  It was also good to see Abraham Lincoln portrayed as a real, live, quirky human being -- one whom I might believe to be a bit off-putting to his political peers.  Too often his historical importance causes writers and directors to view him as a superhuman who is so obviously correct that it would make no sense for anyone to disagree with him.  In fact, I believe the gritty, contradictory personalities and opinions of all the characters and my wondering how they could possibly be persuaded to change their minds is what created the interest of the movie.  I really enjoyed it, and I felt smarter for watching it.

reviewText: A great slice of history. It's not a standard biopic; instead it focuses on the last four months of Lincoln's life, and the political drama surrounding his efforts to get the 13th Amendment passed, abolishing slavery for good. Based in part on Doris Kearns Goodwin's book Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln. Lincoln felt he needed to get the amendment passed before the war was over so he could present it to the South as a fait accompli before surrender. Great cast of well-known actors, including David Straithairn, Tommy Lee Jones, Gloria Reuben, S. Epatha Merkerson, and Sally Field as a sympathetic Mary Todd Lincoln. Daniel Day Lewis is fine as Lincoln. Political dramas so often focus on the venal; there's plenty of venality here, but here's a (rare) case where nobility wins the day

reviewText: Very rarely a film comes along driven by a central performance of such power and verve that you realize how important is the cinematic art and leaves you pondering why it has become quite so debased. Steven Spielberg's engrossing biopic "Lincoln" is not the usual IMAX fodder and neither is it designed to make many concessions to the audience in terms of historical narrative or political understanding. It is based on a central part of the best political book of recent years Doris Kearns Goodwin's mammoth "Team of Rivals" and does cry out for a depth of knowledge of the American Civil War and the nature of the 13th Amendment to pass the abolition of slavery into the US Constitution. From this you may conclude that its dry and dusty political drama. You could not be any more wrong.At the heart of the film is Daniel Day Lewis. His performance is completely thrilling and overpowering. Kearns Goodwin has paid him the huge compliment when she recently stated that "Daniel Day-Lewis perfectly and uncannily embodies Lincoln - from the way he looks to his mannerisms, voice, speech and conviction". As an actor he is renown for inhabiting the part but here you will never be able to think of Lincoln again without thinking Day Lewis. He embodies all elements of the Lincoln character, he owns the cinema and you realise that you are again watching the greatest living screen actor showing how it should be done. Spielberg has long harbored a desire to make a film about the greatest American President and he has found the right man for the job. Even today the Civil War remains the great fault line in American politics and at its heart is the genius of Lincoln a politician who in the US has almost garnered saint like characteristics (go to the memorial in Washington DC and try not to be moved), The brilliance of Kearns Goodwin's book was to show him as a warts and all politician who could plot and scheme with the best of them. He used his folksy Illinois guile and savvy to navigate his way through the greatest unfinished conundrum left by the Founding Fathers the question of slavery, yet at the same time could rise to the political summit in terms of his breadth of vision and oratorical genius. Somehow Day-Lewis captures all these dimensions.Spielberg's film pitches right into the action with Union soldiers faces squashed into the mud by Confederate boots and Lincoln discussing the Gettysburg address with his troops following the battle. The film is a slow starter as we become aware of the great characters of the age not least Lincoln's "indispensable man," his Secretary of State, William Seward played wonderfully by David Strathain, his tortured wife Mary "Molly" Todd Lincoln manically played by Sally Field and a superb supporting role in the form of Tommy Lee Jones who brings to the great leader of the Radical Republicans Thaddeus Stevens, a performance of such roaring gusto that he steals every scene. His attack on a pro slavery democrat House of Representatives member is a tour force as he spits out with cold disdain "How can I hold that all men are created equal when here before me stands stinking the moral carcass of the gentleman from Ohio? Proof that some men are inferior. Endowed by their maker with dim wits, impermeable to reason, with cold pallid slime in their veins instead of hot red blood". Spielberg has finally done the historical charter of Stevens a great service and rescued him from the "mad abolitionist" of previous portraits. Equally his telling of the story of the passing of the 13th Amendment is a model in terms of tension and pace. The introduction of James Spader heading a team of unscrupulous political lobbyists in the direct employ of Lincoln adds some nice humour.Certainly the film has mistakes. Many will point out that Mary Todd Lincoln never attended debates in the House, that black people in the film are largely "bit part players" and its ending does become hagiographical as it moves into Lincoln's death bed scene and his second inaugural speech. But these are small complaints. This reviewer was lucky enough to see this terrific film appropriately in a packed cinema in Chicago and it has done roaring business across the US. It is proof that not all cinemagoers want endlessly dull 3D Marvel Blockbusters or the great President cast as a "Vampire Hunter"! Films that make you think, that chart the struggles of enlightenment and which resonate for today's events are rare beasts. If there is any justice in the world "Lincoln" will be recognised for what it is; namely a truly great film with a compelling central performance, a stellar supporting cast and subject fully deserving of this lavish treatment
summary: "Lincoln" - Daniel Day-Lewis and the impending Oscar

reviewText: This is a great historical drama and partial biopic of Abraham Lincoln, concentrating on the last few months of the Civil War, and Lincoln's efforts to pass the 13th Amendment, abolishing slavery. I am a history buff, with a concentration on the Civil War; and with the exception of Washington, who is in a category by himself, Lincoln is the best president this country has ever produced. I do not believe any other statesman of his time could have preserved the Union and abolished slavery at the same time. So I absolutely love this film! But it is cerebral and slow paced, so if your preference in films tends toward the fast paced actioner, you may want to pass this one up. Steven Spielberg, performs masterfully behind the camera to craft this film; and no one has done a better job of characterizing the historic Lincoln than by Daniel Day-Lewis in his portrayal. It is eerie at times...almost like seeing Lincoln walk off the pages of a history book...perhaps the fine book upon which this film was based; Doris Kearns Goodwin's "Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln." The support acting is also superlative...in fact everything about this movie is superlative and it therefore carries my highest recommendation.
